content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												I've now finished the game so i've updated my review.This game is a lot of fun, not sure why the professional reviewers hate it so much. Maybe they're expecting it to be a fast-paced action game or something like that which it definitely isn't.It's a detective game with an interesting story and characters that draws you in. It's also pretty novel in that you're playing a criminal-turned-detective's ghost who's trying to find the identity of his killer. You spend the game collecting clues to figure out your killer's identity while stopping along the way to help out other lost souls in little sidequests where you figure out how they died so they can pass on. There are also lots of collectibles, some of which provide background for the story, such as notes left by the main character's wife, or that unlock stories about unsolved crimes connected to hauntings. You end up collecting a lot of clues and you have to figure out which ones will help you solve whatever crime you're working on. They make sense and its fun. I've noticed a few negative reviews saying the clues don't make sense and you end up just clicking on everything till you get it right. I only did this once at the beginning of the game...and all I can say is, try thinking a bit and paying attention before just mashing your mouse. If you do this, you'll pretty quickly get a feel for how the clues work in the game and figure out which ones are useles. You can also posess the living, and while you can't move them, you can help them remember and eavesdrop on their conversations or thoughts. You can, however, posess cats which allow you to reach places you can't reach on your own. Everything about the game makes sense...you can't walk through the outdoor walls of buildings that have been consecrated, the demons you have to sneak past to take down from behind are souls who never passed on, etc. The mood the game sets just enhances the experience, being creepy and immersive.Overall, this game is a lot of fun. Story is great, gameplay is fun, voice acting is well done. Having finished the game now, the story is a pretty good detective story, with everything falling satisfyingly into place at the end and a few neat twists. There are only a few drawbacks: the graphics aren't the best, but they're still decent (especially the lip synching); sometimes when you posess someone and listen to their thoughts you'll hear the same thought in different people; the parts where you have to sneak behind demons and take them out can be a bit tedious. However, all these are definitly worth overlooking.The other drawback is that the game is a bit short. I finished it in 7 hours, and if you check out my achievements you'll see I didn't get 100% completion. I did all the side-quests and found as many collectibles as I could. You could probably stretch it out to 10 hours if you wanted 100% completion which seems totally possible in a single playthrough. Its up to you to decide whether a 7-10 hour game is worth $60 or if you want to wait for a sale.In short, if you like story-driven games, or mystery/adventure games then you'll probably like this game. If you want this game to be a gritty shooter, then go buy Max Payne instead, because you won't get that with this game. Having finished it, I would now give it between a 7 and an 8 out of 10.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is an adventure detective game, which was released in mid-2014 on PC, PS3, PS4, 360 and Xbox One. The game was developed by Airtight Games; which hadn't released anything worthwhile for a while before this game. You play the role of detective Ronan O'Connor, based in a town called Salem in USA. The story is based around hunting down a serial killer by the name of "The Bell Killer". Ronan is killed by the serial killer at the beginning of the game and you are revived as a ghost and must find the killer before he can move on to the afterlife. The game is played in a third person view as you wander around the town of Salem, the town is split into a couple of separate areas, such as churches, graveyards petrol stations etc. As you progress through the story, you learn a few different abilities, such as being able to teleport yourself short distances, being able to possess other living beings allowing you to read their minds or being able to influence their decisions in dialog scenes. The main game play element is solving the mystery of the killer; you do this by investigating the crime scenes for clues on the killer, and trying to predict their next move. This takes on a similar way of doing things as games like LA Noire has done; in that you have to find specific items of evidence scattered, and sometimes hidden around the crime scene in order for you to put them all together in order to resolve the scene. This can lead to quite a few moments of where you need to study all the evidence put in front of you in order to solve it giving it a real detective vibe. On top of these detective scenes, there is a small element of combat in the game - as you are a ghost, living humans are not able to detect you; however the demon souls of the death world can. You have to remain hidden to these ghosts in shadows before being able to pounce out behind them to kill them by pressing a few key sequences in a small QTE - these combat scenes are very few and far between however and aren't really anything to rave about as they become very monotonous as you progress in the story. Visually, Murdered: Soul Suspect looks nice. The whole game takes place in the time frame of one evening, so the darkness of night gives the game a very eerie feel to it. It doesn't have ultra-realistic graphics, but all of the characters are well animated. There are a couple of poor quality textures, however given that this is a sort of open world game, this can be forgiven somewhat.  The story in Murdered: Soul Suspect is something really special. From the opening scene, I was completely drawn into the plot and was able to fully immerse myself in this world being unfolded in front of me. As you progress, you come across other characters who aid Ronan in his efforts to solve the mystery and you grow attached to them too. The story is 100% linear though; there are no game changing decisions which you have to make which disappointed me slightly. But the overall plot which is being shown here is really interesting.As this game is being categorized in the horror genre, I would of expected a little more from the sound effects, but I was let down by the fact that there isn't anything really that scary in Murdered: Soul Suspect; the scariest I came across was the demon's you encounter; and even they are tame and the lack of any jump scares or horrifying scenes was a let-down too. Every character you find in the game is fully voice acted to a high quality though. None of the voicing sounds off or cringy which is always a plus. I found that there was next to zero levels of difficulty in Soul Suspect; the lack of any real combat leaves this game without any skill element, and is purely based on your ability to solve the crime scenes by finding the relevant clues - I was able to resolve all of the crime scenes with a 3 star rating 99% of the time (you are scored out of three). The hardest point I found has to be due to the game's controls which I will go into on the technical issues section of this review. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a vast open world game; you are able to go wherever you want, whenever you want (within reason). There is absolutely tons of stuff to explore and investigate not related to the main plot. There are a number of side investigations you can complete in the early chapters, but these slowly become less and less common as you progress and focus more on the main plot. Another huge part of this game is finding the collectables; this has to be the game with the most collectables in I have ever played - there are hundreds to find.  Each level has its own version of collectable items, and there are also the overall games collectables which unveil even more about the main character's past, and information about the killer. Due to the fact that there are so many of these to find; I felt a little overwhelmed by trying to find them all and just sort of with the approach of picking any up which I come across whilst completing the investigations. I finished Murdered: Soul Suspect in just over thirteen hours; this was with doing all of the side investigations, and collecting over a hundred collectables. I also took the time to playout all of the dialog options with all of the characters and spent a lot of time exploring the town of Salem. Sadly though; there is no reason what so ever to play through this game for a second time; you are not able to change the story in anyway nor are you able to ramp up the difficulty simply because there is no difficulty there in the firstI had a couple of technical problems whilst playing. Firstly I was playing on my high end rig, on 1080p settings and even though the majority of the time the frame rate was over 100 fps, it still felt like it was stuttering at times. I had to play with v-sync off because otherwise this locked gameplay to 30fps which looked horrendous. Cut scenes are also played out in 30fps in the game graphics, which makes the transitions between gameplay and cut scenes feel a little off too. The game's controls during the combat scenes also came across as clunky too; I often found myself not actually completing the QTE presented because it's not clear which buttons you have to press and what you can let go of which meant a lot of running and hiding from the demons due to failed attempts at killing them.  Finally the last issue I had was there are quite a few invisible walls to be found to, these often are in places where you would not expect them, leading to moments where you'll find you are suddenly floating in mid-air because you've walked into a wall and are trying to climb up it - this is something which can affect the immersion of the game and it's a shame that it is still in it given it's been out for well over a year now. I am going to recommend Murdered: Soul Suspect; it has an amazing story which you really do need to experience in order to fully appreciate it, and has an original concept. The linear gameplay, lack of any many action scenes, and a couple of technical issues renders me unable to recommend it more than just that, a recommendation to play. The full price of £19, 99 is also slightly over marked too, so you may even want to wait for it to hit the sales before purchasing.  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Murdered: Soul Suspect is supernatural detective adventure thriller game where you are playing as detective Ronan. He got murdered by a Bell Killer a primary antagonist and now he need to solve his case as a ghost.Pros:+ Great main character+ Voice acting is really good+ Enjoyable graphics+ Good story and atmoshpere+ Lots of collectibles + As a ghost you can walk through walls, read people's minds etc.Cons:- Short ( main story for around 6 hours )- Combat is poor ( you basically sneak behind the enemy and do fast QTE) - Only one type of enemy- Most of NPC's are just clones/duplicates- Only 4 optional quests ( to finish them you need like 5-10 mins each)

It's just a normal detective game. Yeah, maybe it's too short, but it doesn't mean it's a bad game.Pros++Story - You won't know who is the killer, even when all suspects seem to be guilty...+Collectibles+Investigation+Uncovering story of Ronan, his wife and other people+Easy achievements, you can easily do 100%+Game has a good sense of humour+As ghost, you can do specific actions - walk through walls, possesing people and animals, teleporting on short distance, being poltregeist...Cons--Short story-Some passages are boring7/10

Posted: May 26, 2015
An uncommon title, yet it suffers some shortcomings // Recommended for those who seek a story-rich experience**You'd likely prefer it at sale price+ Voice-acting is excellent+ Facial movements and lip synchronization are above average+ Character makes a ghostly 'impression' on walls and objects as they are passed through; this makes it easy to keep track of areas previously visited+ Mechanics in place to facilitate ones investigation are inventive and refreshing+ Ephemeral bits of Salem's past look fantastic, and work with the mortal world to create a uniquely hybrid environment+ Disposing of demons is a somewhat satisfying experience, and is the only time in the game that really requires situational awareness and a tactical approach+ 'Unfinished business' side-quests are interesting and well-scripted+ While Ronan isn't exactly a unique, well-written character (he isn't), he and Joy are, at least, well fleshed-out and see a satisfying level of development throughout the story+ Successfully creates a dark and unsettled atmosphere; gameplay is very immersive- Choices are meaningless, and funnel into a solitary conclusion- Puzzles/Crime scene investigations require almost no thinking, and the solutions are always quite obvious- NPC models are shamefully copy/pasted- Due to linear story and few 'off the beaten path' collectibles and additions, there is little replay value to speak of- While unique and interesting, the historical remnants of the environment serve only to limit exploration in practiceLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Let me preface this by saying that regardless of my "No" recommendation, I do believe this game is worth playing once. The story is OK and the ending twist is OK. But it is simply not worth the asking price of anything over $10 bucks.You play the ghost of a murder victim in the town of modern Salem, MA. The goal is to solve your own murder...as a ghost! In the same town where the witch trials took place in real life! How could this possibly be bad?!? Well, you'd be surprised. On paper, this should make for an awesome adventure game. Too bad the execution is horrendous. It's certainly not an action game and it's one step above a Fisher Price point-and-click adventure game (and I love adventure games). The world is as linear as the story. The entire game boils down to "walk around and spam E (maybe R, before E occasionally)" until you hit the cutscene. It's impossible to fail any "investigation" (a very strong word to use in this game) until literally the last mission in the game. And even then, you just repeat it until you get it right. Investigations aren’t dynamic, they never change regardless of what you do. You can't ♥♥♥♥ up investigations in any way. But if you pick the wrong item, the developers decided it would be a good idea to make you re-enter the "which item is it?" screen over and over until you get it right. No, it couldn’t just stay open, that would make too much sense. The controls in general are bad. You can’t mouse click anything and the camera sensitivity is high no matter which setting you use.The NPCs standing around are useless. If you're like me, and you like to absorb story in your games, you'll learn pretty quickly to not even bother "possessing" them because nothing they say is ever relevant or interesting.There are demons in this game. Demons, in a game about souls....whodathunk. Too bad they're the most irritating part of the game. They are obviously in the game as filler and annoying filler at that because they tend to pop up when you have to backtrack (which you do a lot of, btw). It's like the devs knew this game was short so they needed to find a way to stretch it out. You “fight” the same type of demon throughout the entire game and how you deal with them never changes. They have pre-determined patrol paths and you simply wait until they have their backs turned and then you "execute" them during a quicktime event.None of the characters are very likeable. The main character is kind of a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and it’s very easy to forget the name of the others. In a game filled with ghost, you would think there would be some awesome death or haunting stories, but there really isn’t. Maybe one or two are interesting (mostly in a sick way), but the rest are “waaaaaahhhh, I’m dead! Whhhhhhhhyyy” that you quickly get tired of.And it’s all topped off by credits that are unskippable and seem to go on for 3 hours. Shame, this game had some really interesting ideas that I feel would have been better realized by a more capable studio. The sound effects are really good, and the environment with the old Salem blending with modern Salem is nice to look at. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game filled with souls, but ultimately, it’s really lacking one of its own.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												From the first article I read about this game I was hooked. Investigating your own murder and other crime scenes as a ghost? Yes please! The idea seemed so original and any screen shots I had seen looked awesome.  So I get the game and the first half hour is awesome. You'll have fun getting used to the controls and your own abilities as a ghost, but it didn't take me long to lose interest in walking through walls and making printers/TV's malfunction because at the end of the day, you rarely stumble across anything interesting or you get little to no reaction from the living people in the area. I mean come on! if I'm a ghost I want to be able to scare the living. Not just distract them from guarding that door for 20 seconds. So let's get down to the things that really got on my nerves.(1) Gameplay - It gets repetitive. Honestly, you'll find yourself running across the city/buildings where  your obstacles will be either one of  two things.        - Oh there's a demon there? better sneak up on them and extract their soul.        Or       - Oh would you look at that, a fiery pit straight to hell is blocking my path. Luckily for me there's  this person here I can possess, who's sole propose seems to be walking down this hall for the rest of their lives.  Oh which leads me to another thing, if you give us the ability to read minds, actually have the characters think interesting stuff that's personal to them, instead of the same thing like, "Oh its cold outside" or "I hope they find that killer" Seriously, a little variety never killed anyone. (There's a pun in there somewhere.) (2) Skills/abilities - You will pick up skills as the story progresses, skills like teleportation....eh and umm teleportation. So on top of being able to posses people,(and don't be fooled, the most exciting thing you might get them to do is move their hand from blocking that page you want to read.) reveal the events that lead up to peoples deaths and maybe another ability that I have forgotten about, that leaves you with about 5 (give or take) skills. Not much and nothing that's gonna make you sit up and go F*** Yeah!! with excitement, which is disappointing.   (3) NPC's - If we were back in the early 2000's I might forgive this but there is a serious lack of character models for the npc's (there's about four different character's for each sex, who will either have  one of three different voices, all of whom usually say the same dialogue.) (4) Collectables - For example once you've collected the 15 or whatever amount of saws, a memory is unlocked. Now considering some of these can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to collect, you'd expect maybe a flash back to the event. You know a cutscene, an animation. No, what you get is one image that is some what relateable to the story, with a bunch of  text in front of it (and I mean a bunch) and possibly the most life draining narration I've ever had to injure. (5) Game length - The game is short! I finished it in under 10 hours and this is coming from someone who went out of her way to find as many collectables and whatever other extras there was. (Near the end I gave up, not caring any more and just wanted to finish the game so I stopped putting in any effort.) So for someone who'd only be interested in the story you might be able to get this game finished in 6-7 hours. (6) Connecting crime scene clues. - Honestly I don't know how to describe this. Once you collect all the clues you'll be brought to a window that asks you a question. You have to click on a clue (or three) that answers that question. Being the generation brought up on CSI you're more than likely going to put on your Horatioto glasses and think long and hard about the choices and outcomes. My advice don't. Pick the clue that when you read it you think "Nah, that's not even a clue. more like a statement/common sense." Watch a lets play of one of these, you'll see what I'm talking about. (7) Deus Ex desktop screens - Awesome the first computer screen I saw it on but when every police officer in the station seems to be playing Deus Ex on their work computer no wonder you haven't found the killer. Whoa, okay I've complained a lot about this game. I don't want to come off too hard on it. There are some pro's.Pro's Spooky S*** - There are some legitimate scary scenes and dark deaths and twists in this game. Some that will really make you feel for the characters. Villian - I never wanted to punch someone in the face more. Well done on making a completle d*** of a villian. You get to posses a cat. Press A to meow. Okay I ran out of pro's..... but it isn't that bad. To me I feel that the idea behind the story had so much potential but failed to deliver. The end result is that it seems lazy and half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ which you will feel while playing the game. It's worth a play through but do not buy this at full price. Last word: If Patrick Swayze was a cop in Ghost and Whoopi Goldberg an annoying emo teenager this would basically be the game adaptation.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
“Justice will not be served until those who are unaffected are as outraged as those who are.” ― Benjamin FranklinMurdered: Soul Suspect is a one shot wonder coming from Airtight Games; the last game they developed before closing their doors in July 2014. It is a wondrous detective story with a supernatural background that takes place in the timeline of one evening in Salem, present time. Salem? Does that ring any "bells"?Aside my unintentionally cheesy joke, this game is about Ronan O'Connor, an ex-con and street dog turned his way straight and decided to become a detective to atone for all his past misdeeds, with a pretty gal for him to impress in the mix, of course. The events of our game start with the untimely demise of our main character. We watch Ronan as his life passes before his eyes in a stream of memories - recorded on his body as tattoos representing milestones in his life. The Bell Killer, notorious serial killer who was terrorizing Salem for months now, killed Ronan. But surprisingly, this is the beginning for him rather than an end. Now, he is a ghost, stuck in between worlds until he manages to solve his own murder. Ronan's persistence to seek the truth will take him through an old, dark ordeal in Salem history: Salem Witch Trials.As I continue, I have to note that I loved the character of Ronan O'Connor himself. Aside being an ordinary bad boy, he has vulnerabilities, character flaws and a short temper. His death isn't even heroic as most main characters in video games as we see nowadays. He just ventures out, without having anything to loose and without a thought; and bang! He ends up getting hunted and falling to his death. We are able to read an in-depth backstory for Ronan, with Julie's perception from many collectible memory notes within the game, and put together, it portrays the story of a life. I salute developers for presenting Ronan as an original character, different from any darkened vigilante or street thug. As I was playing, I found myself recalling Mickey O'Neil, a gypsy character that Brad Pitt portrayed in Guy Ritchie's Snatch: a reckless and wild rascal, a swindler with a golden heart. He feels much real than any old book knight in shining armor, at least for me.If we are to talk about the atmosphere, well, sure. It is a success. Graphics and textures are impressive, alongside the modelling of each and every character. The game manages to present you the feel of an open world: the ghostly, dark remains of the old Salem clashing with the modern, physical environment, Airtight presents us a ghost's perception. It is uncanny and impressive. Combined with a successful voice acting for all characters present: this game is basically L.A. Noire quality with less action packed and more on the supernatural side.Gameplay? Sure, it's nothing extraordinary. We run about the town - collecting a huge number of collectibles for either background story, or some independent creepy ghost stories, or trivial facts about Salem history if we feel like so, by the way - and try to predict the movements of the killer. We even gain a living side-kick as we progress: Joy, a snarky teenage who will become our involuntary aid in the world of the living. There are three defining elements to the game: item collecting, demon hunting and investigation. None of these parts are incredibly well-put, but the story being absorbing, you keep playing. Investigations are quite basic, with little to no chance of guessing wrong and combat section consists of a basic stealth kill for some demons in each new area. Could have been much more, but I won't complain.Is it worth your time? It surely is, but still I'd recommend grabbing it on sale, so 30 dollars would be a grand exaggeration for what you're getting yourself. The greatest plus of the game for me, was its story. For one time, I really wasn't able to guess the ending, and the precise position of characters involved. I so hope that Ronan's story wouldn't end here. Would it be so much to hope for? Well, we'll see.Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

Posted: July 7, 2015
												Ah, Soul Suspect. The trailer alone had me clapping my hands from excitement. However, there's a lot to say about the game itself. The concept seems unique at first; a murdered cop who is forced to solve his own murder before he can pass on to the other side, where he can be reunited with his dead wife. It's not an angle you see often. That being said, the game feels empty when it comes to gameplay and the semi-original plot can't make up for it. It feels like all your abilities seem to have huge potential and you have fun playing with them for an hour or so, excited about what more you can do along the way. Then you realise that you're limited to distracting people with flashing lights and walking through a wall (but not all walls, only some walls, obviously) every now and again. You also have the ability to possess people, which seems wicked awesome at first. You can possess pretty much anyone you meet and you have the options of mind reading or influencing them. However, the reality of possession is that you possess a person, read their mind and they're like "Oh man, it's sort of chilly today" or "I hate my job" and you lose interest pretty fast when that's all you hear. In the end, I'm unsure about whether or not to recommend this game. It's visually pleasing, the voice acting is decent and the idea behind it is worth the time. But the final product is just not satisfying in the long run. Murdered: Soul Suspect is another one of those games that you should get if it's 60-75% off, but it's not worth the full price. Overall, it's like a lukewarm bowl of pudding. It's not entirely done and feels a little lacking, but hey, it's still pudding in the end.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is detective-ghost story told through the interactive-medium of gaming. Murdered is kind of like a combination between a TellTale game, LA Noire, and Alan Wake... But honestly the game is more often than not more like an interactive movie, and I think it's with these expectations that you best experience Murdered.Murdered: Soul Suspect tells the tale of a man named Ronan, who at the game's start experiences his own death. He is pushed out of the window by a notorious murderer, who is known as the Bell Killer, who then commences to shoot him seven times in the chest. Ronan grew-up as a criminal in Salem, but changed his ways late in life to become a detective, partially for the woman he loved, Julia. However, he was torn apart a few months earlier, when Julia's life was taken at the hands of a street mugger. At death's door, Ronan discovers he is a spirit to this world, trapped here until he can move on from something that's keeping him bounded here. He finds out that he can be with Julia again in the world beyond our own if he can resolve whatever is keeping him here, so he goes out to try and solve the case of his own murder.Gameplay is rather simplistic in Murdered. You will spend most of your time exploring around, using your ghost powers, and looking for items and clues in the environment. As a ghost, you can freely pass through human-world objects, which essentially makes clipping a gameplay mechanic, but you might be surprised how natural it ends up feeling and due to some good visual cues and sounds it ends up not looking or feeling weird, and makes sense with everything else built up with the game. The only objects you can't pass through are ghost-world objects (relics from the past which are present in the ghost world, and tell-able they're ghost world as they glow with a blue aura), and into or out of buildings freely (ghosts can only enter or exit buildings through open doors or windows). Other powers at your disposal include the ability to possess people, to either read their minds or influence their thoughts, to poltergeist and make objects (mostly machinery) act up, to teleport around by choice, and a few other underutilized but still interesting powers.The game splits-up between 'stages' (bigger interior areas usually), and a Salem hub-world. The stages I thought generally got better as the game went on, and Salem was a joy to explore... At first. The problem is that not much really happens in Salem, it stays the same mostly for the whole game so you can literally almost do everything in it the first time you enter the hub-area (with only a few things you can only do once you gain the teleportation power).As you explore, there's a variety of content to immerse yourself in the world. There's a lot of side areas and areas off the beaten path. You can approach living people to listen in to conversations they're having with each other, made more amusing you can then possess them and see what they're REALLY thinking. You can approach ghosts, and either talk to them briefly, question them about something they're up too, and very occasionally help them via a side-quest to move onto from this world to the next. However, there are literally only about 3-4 side-quest in the game, and there is obvious content and characters that were left around for more side-quests, but were left-out as cut content. Things like items you can observe for no real reason, characters it looks like you would be able to help but then they cut you short from actually helping them.And then there's the collectibles. This game kind of goes overboard with it's collectibles, but they're pretty enjoyable and expand a lot on the plot, the lore, Salem's history, character background's, additional cinematics, and my personal favorite, ghost stories. Extended from this, the investigation scenes usually have you looking for and going about collecting clues, and then putting together the clues that matter to a particular solution or outcome. These typically were rather simple, and sometimes felt more like sort of mindless collecting to get to the point. However, other times they actually felt kind of rewarding. None were really 'puzzles' I would say, but were a mixed bag.The only other real gameplay mechanic is demons, which are rather underutilized. I didn't find them offensive, and I'll admit there was a few times when their screeches or them detecting me legitimately startled and scared me. However, there's only one type of demon in the game, you only face a few of them in the game, and their encounters are often brief and they're easy enough to deal with (you sneak up behind them to execute them, otherwise they spot you and chase you down, where you hide in things until they lose interest).But then this is a game I'd argue isn't really about winning or losing, it's an interactive film essentially, and on that account it pulls some things off really well.Firstly, the audio design is fantastic in this game. The voice acting for the main characters are all well-done and performed, and even most minor characters are rather well-voiced (though you'll find a few reoccurring VAs). The ghost stories you can get via collectibles deserve particular praise, as the acting done here really adds a lot to the story, and honestly are really well-done.But it's not just the voice acting. The music is very good too, with some good creepy vibes, emotional melodies, and songs to go well to the mystery. The ambiance of sounds in the environment also add a lot, with a lot of attention to detail to help bring the locations alive. And even the game sounds, for solving cases, getting clues, etc., are all satisfying and fitting.The story is quite good, especially if you like detective-ghost stories, ala' The Frighteners, Sixth Sense, or the like. While the writing can be a bit hammy at times, they do have some believable dialogue between characters, the story has interesting developments as it goes on, and there are some rather well-done plot twists throughout.Cinematics deserve special mention. The cinematography is really well-done, with fantastic angles, focus, artistic direction, and were a joy to watch. And the characters are well-realized, trope-ish, but manage to be developed and become more than their tropes and have rather realistic relationships with each other. They have fights and don't agree, but come together (sometimes reluctantly), and there are a few heart-warming moments and real development with each other as it goes on.Graphically it looks good for the sort of niche budget title it is. Some nice attention to detail in environments, some good art direction, and some of the models are rather well poly'd. There's some visual quality dips in certain areas, textures... But not a bad looking game at all.Generally, I would label this as a game for gamers who like story, exploring, and world-building above all else. Gameplay really takes a step-down to the game's other elements, and it will definitely strike with its niche. But its lack of action, focus on making what is usually the 'extra' parts of games the main part, and just the general styling and minimal gameplay make it lack that mainstream appeal. I'd also say it isn't worth its $50 pricetag, but felt it was worth it for the $15-25 range.I'd say if the game interests you, it is worth experiencing... Just maybe not at full price. It is different than your typical budgeted game in this day and age, and is sure to find a cult audience. In some aspects, it's a bit disappointing or under-cooked, but as a whole, this may be one of the best realized classic-styled ghost stories to appear in the gaming medium for years. Like the Fedora or not, Ronan is the perfect tour guide into a very different look at ghosts, Salem, and games with a budget.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
Short version: 86%Murdered mixes interactive storytelling with exploration mechanics to create a somewhat predictable modern ghost tale. The writing quality, especially the world-building, easily carries the game, despite its sometimes downright terrible (keyboard) controls.Long version:Murdered: Soul Suspect combines one of the most common basic premises of modern ghost tales—solve the case of your own murder—with a buddy cop system, where our titular freshly-murdered detective teams up with a young psychic girl to get to the bottom of a series of strange killings. And to maximise the possible clichés, this ghost story is set in Salem.In many ways, Murdered can be classified as an exploration game, as we spend most of it looking for things. It is divided to several levels (all tied to major Salem landmarks), where we search for clues or specific (otherworldly) objects. The clues are used in simple matchmaking minigames to draw conclusions and push the plot forward, whereas the collectibles eventually turn into a series of long backstories.Interestingly enough, these backstories supply the bulk of the content, as this is where we can learn the most about our protagonist, the game world, and the many tragic stories it hides. Since the central plot is painfully predictable, sometimes these stories are the biggest reason to continue playing.Although Murdered could have worked perfectly as an adventure-like game, apparently the developers were worried that the console generation’s attention span would run out without enemies to kill, so we have shoehorned action sequences against a bunch of wraith-like apparitions. To kill them, we need to play short stealth sections with mandatory quick-time events. These QTEs are downright impossible to do on mouse and keyboard, so, in the end, even with these tacked-on parts, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game, but only to gamepad owners.

												7.5/10 Very Good game , but id recommend buying it on sale.A mix of Alan Wake meets LA Noire and has a baby delivered by Bigby Wolf with the whole thing being recorded by Nicholas Cage on a 8mm film, and Jennifer Love Hewitt standing by to help all the ghosts watching cross over.PROS:- Good mystery story and atmosphere- Lots of collecting- Very interesting system and dynamic of game while playing as ghost- Dark undertone of story- Enjoyable graphics and pretty smooth gameplay imo ( had only 1 minor bug fixed by reloading )CONS:- very little and very simplistic combat (might as well remove it completely and add a few more sidequests or even some puzzles)- if you strictly rush main story without exploring or doing sidequests might be a bit short. I did 2 playthroughs first one i collected all except 5 items and it took me 12 hours, second one i rushed to get those few items and it took me 5h to get almost to last part of game ( Judgement house). So rushed probably 6h playthrough.- wish world was more open to explore and more interractive and immersive (ghosts you meet are pretty forgetable after you do quest)- this would work great as a mystery adventure with some rpg progression- not really scary , very little horror.  More of a murder mystery thriller if you ask me.CONCLUSION:Worth playing. Hope there is a sequel and i will buy it when it comes out.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												Ever thought about being a ghost?  Pass through walls, posses people, teleporting,  making the T.V. go wild, things like this make it fun to be one. Of course, being a ghost has to be somewhat dark and taken seriously. After all, being a ghost means you’re dead. Murdered Soul Suspect is a game where Ronan, a detective that follows a lead, dies but stays in this world as a ghost and the only thing that keeps him from finding peace is solving the case. The story is very noir like, despite the presence of modern objects, since the dark atmosphere and the mystery  are the things that are unavoidable in this game.  The plot is as it should be,  clear, logic and ended with enough closure to make you realize what a good story it is. In a world where ghosts have many questions, where are mediums that can see that and a killer that hunts those people down, you are the one that provides the answers.  There are ghosts that you can help find peace. There are collectibles that give you a lot of backstory on various topics and characters. There is one murderer that can’t be stopped still loose in this town. All of this is obvious throughout the game and that’s what will keep you hooked. 


Ghosts can live in this world 
A Screenshot of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™
By: F4rseeR




Gameplay wise, the game is easy. To put it simply, you’ll  take walks,  find clues, conclude investigations with the correct solution, execute demons by taking them from behind and collecting stuff if you feel like it. To put it as it is, things are more complex than that, but not much more.  In order to gain clues, you’ll need to look for them at the crime scene , you’ll need to interact with someone or something to find more, which sometimes mean possessing a person, influencing them to think about the topic you need or looking through their eyes.  The things that present a challenge in this game are the demons, that are very much alike with the dementors. They’ll consume your soul if you are exposed to them for long enough.  You can pass by them, or you can execute them by going behind them and using one of your ghostly abilities. Ronan can hide from them by possessing people or hiding in different entities. At the player disposal is also the ability to see the demon from afar, even through walls.Facing the demons are the stealthy section of the game, but they’re not frustrating enough to make the game challenging at all. For completitionists, there are a lot of collectibles to be found, which contain backstories of characters and places, or a separate story.  They aren’t hard to be found and there are more than one good guides, so you could say it’s easy to get all the achievements. The town of Salem is beautiful, varied but after you explore it all, it feels like a small place.  There is free roam until the last mission, but that is useful for those who want to get back to specific locations to get the rest of the collectibles.  Also, if you see an NPC that looks interesting to you, you can posses him and hear what he thinks. 


Too bad for them I'm the better spirit 
A Screenshot of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™
By: F4rseeR




Is the game a great one? No, it’s simply good. It lasts for about 10 hours, it has great concepts and executes them simply, which may be a fault for it, since many said about the game that it had great potential. Still, there’s no other game that can make you have fun for being a ghost like this one.  Passing through walls, possessing people, talking with other ghosts, potterghasting different object to perturb the living ones, it’s all very enjoyable. The theme is dark, some details are gritty, it’s a game where you solve a mystery which has a solution that isn’t obvious at all(the plot-twists turned out to be mind-blowing).


No matter where they're from, two can work together 
A Screenshot of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™
By: F4rseeR




All in all, Murdered Soul Suspect is a good game that delivers on what it describes itself to be and doesn’t take risks in being something more.

Posted: June 6, 2014
												I was fairly dissapointed with how this game turned out. The concept was interesting, and I love the genre; however, the excution of the game play mechanics was lacking in any real dept. All of the crime scenes were a fixed camera angle away from being a point and click adventure, and putting the clues together could be done by random guessing without penalty. The characters felt forced, and fell deeply into non-relatable stereotypes that were hard to really care about. I really wanted to like the story, but I kept finding myself just grinding through everything to see it end. I couldn't see me much functionally wrong with the game, and didn't encounter many bugs; however it just got down right boring. The stealth/combat whatever they were going for with the demons, ended up becoming an annoyance, and half the time I could just run by them without worry. The voice acting, music, and ambient atmosphere were excuted well, and they created the emotions the story was trying to encourage. Unfortunatly the writting its self was too forced, and anti-climatic at best. I completed the game in about 7 hours without collecting everything, but I did all the side cases I could find. It wasn't a completely regrettable expierence, but for the price you're better off waiting for a good sale as this is a play once and uninstall title. I hope this helps someone from being stuck with a $50 dissapointment like I am.

Posted: July 26, 2014
												I am here against all odds to recommend this game to everyone. You will like this game if you are like me and loved reading those detective novels. The Good Very Cinematic Approach, with a 1st person narration and 3rd person navigation.Quite an intriguing story.Even though the theme is supernatural it doesnt talk about religiousness or any other stupid stuff instead focuses on the characters that are in the game instead.The background score is great along with good voice actors.Very simple controls nothing too fancy considering the fact that this is a ported game from a console version.The BadThe Story is so condensed that the entire game takes place within a single night. In a sense it is a fast paced game but it doesnt feel like a fast paced game at all. The only other comparable game would be Fahrenheit aka The Indigo Prophecy.You are a ghost, there are a ton of fun stuff you could probably do as a ghost but this game doesnt allow you to fulfill your Hollowman dreams.The Story is very linear, there are no alternate endings, hence its very predictable considering it is a AAA priced game there should have been alternate endings.Limited exploration of the surroundings, you dont get to go everywhere you want. The only reason you get to explore is because you have to collect certain artifacts and items -again- the reward for which is negligible and has no direct relation to the game's storyline.In a way the game does try to teach 'children' about a moral about fulfilling your debts and being honest & things like that, but the developers forgotm kids dont get to spend 50 bucks. Teenagers and Grown up gamers do. You do get to snoop around a little to help a few other souls to 'move on' but it is nearly not enough.I am a DOG person why are there so many cats here and no DOGS in Salem ??The UglyThere is no denying the fact that the game has a very sloppy game engine. The quadruped animation quality of the cats are less than okay.I was stuck in a limbo / mid air within the first 5 minutes of the game.The lack of action. Despite what the trailer had me believing there is absolutely NO action game play here. The Cut Scene sequences are fun to watch but thats it.There was a million different ways how this game could have been made way better than what it is, the story, the interactivity, the side missions everything felt too little and too less.My rating 3.8/5

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Mudered: Soul Suspect left me wanting in almost every aspect of the game. I expected an engaging story focused 3rd person game with puzzles and minimal to no combat and in a way thats what you get here, just not well executed.Graphical Fidelty is mediocre as you would expect from a Console Port and i wouldnt mind if the mechanics and story were up to compensate for that. The Main mechanic of conducting an investigation is for them to designate an area where you look for a set number of clues to tell you what happened. This almost plays like a hidden object game and its really not interesting. At the end you are supposed to select some of the clues to conclude your investigatoin into a story and a little cutscene tells you what you gathered from that. Sometimes you can possess a witness where you can peek through his eyes to find a clue on a screen or notepad, influence his memory by selecting a clue you found so that he reveals more information about that or you can eavesdrop on a conversation. The Problem with all this is that you do it maybe 5 times in the game with some effect while the rest of the time, it doesnt do anything at all. Mindreading in Salem is really boring and i hope the real inhabitants have more going though their head than these NPCs.The Game has two types of collectibles which reveal some lore about your former life or a criminal story. The lore bits about your former life or you girlfriend reveal information one at a time which you can access by going into a horrible menu where you have to click on each piece individually to see what it says. And the Navigatoin of the Menu is horrible, the most basic pc-conversion where using your mouse is a pain, they put no effort into adjusting a system for pc which is badly designed from the start. Why dont you let me just click on this! You just dont want to navigate through this to get 2 sentences about the meaning of your tattoos, or how you met your deceased wife.The second tye which reveals a little story is even worse, because these are collectibles in a major areas which only reveal their story after you collected all of them. This means you can run around the levels for ages looking for that last piece which extends the game time in a very boring and artificial way. Only some true OCD guys will suffer through that. And they even have more ideas how to prolong their game time. Sometimes there are areas with demons which can end your undead life unless you sneak up behind them and press a button+mouse combination to ban them. So you jump from hiding point to hiding point to get behind them and banish all of them. This is neither challenging nor interesting, its only annoying because you want to get through this part which adds nothing to the game.All in all i am very disappointed and if i had payed full price for this i would be furious. The game doesnt know how to tell its story through its mechanics. the mechanics are uninspired and boring and there is a lot of filler to prolong a game wich doesnt have much to offer. I took 7h for the main story line and there was an infuriating bit at the end, where i had a lot of respawns right on top of these black spot which draw you into the abyss. So i got to spawn found myself  dying and reloading several times in a row before i could continue to the end.I am Sorry but A resounding: Dont Buy! from me

content:
Posted: January 23
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a third-person supernatural mystery-thriller where you play as Ronan O’Connor, a thief turned detective, who gets shot to death while trying to prevent a murder by the notorious Bell Killer, an enigmatic hooded man who kills his victims in different ways around the town of Salem, Massachusetts. Waking up, Ronan discovers he is a ghost stuck in some sort of a limbo, referred to as Dusk, but eventually figures out that the only way to free himself and meet his deceased wife is to stop the Bell Killer before committing further murders.The story in Murdered: Soul Suspect is all about Ronan’s journey of redemption. Each new finding leads Ronan to a new destination and at one point he even ends up partnering, out of necessity, with a medium by the name of Joy Foster, a punk-looking teenager, who can see and talk with ghosts. Joy is looking for her mother who is assumed to be followed by the Bell Killer. The chemistry between Ronan and Joy is legitimately good. As a murder mystery story with supernatural elements, it is fairly decent but I hardly think it rises above the average. It does not deviate too much from tropes, so it may feel very familiar to fans of this genre. While it may start off like an original story, by the end it is hard not feel like you might have experienced a similar story in games such as Blackwell (Rose and Joey), Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Father (witchcraft) and Cognition: An Erica Reed Thriller (Cain Killer). That bugged me a bit. There are enough genuine twists to keep you invested in its very short story (6-7 hours) though, even when the game tries too hard to fool you, but the ending is underwhelming.Now Murdered: Soul Suspect has a very strong presentation. Visually, it genuinely reminds me of Batman: Arkham Asylum/City. The story unfolds during the same night, so it is always night time in the game. Character models are generally well made, including their facial animations, although there is a noticeable difference in quality between the protagonists and civilians; the former being more detailed. In general, the performance is solid as well.The world, or the town of Salem, is a sinister semi-open-world similar to Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines where the streets are narrow and split between a few regions. NPCs are present on the streets of Salem, although most of them have fixed positions while others seem to follow the same walking path. Shockingly, at the first crime scene, two civilians have the same character model which, at the time, made me laugh. The more I played, the more I discovered the lack of variety in the NPCs roaming the streets which is rather disappointing considering a good effort was put into the presentation.The voice acting is also one of the strong points of the game and the voice actor of Ronan brilliantly gives the protagonist a Clint Eastwood vibe. Bluntly, Ronan O’Connor is one badass character without losing his credibility in the process. Furthermore, the soundtrack of Murdered: Soul Suspect suits most scenes and creates a fitting atmosphere that is quite chilling at times. There are even a handful of occasions which throws in a few questionable horror-oriented scores, as for the most part, the game is not much of a horror game. However, the soundtrack does tend to become very same-y over time.Where Murdered: Soul Suspect falters is in its game design and gameplay. Even within the first few minutes after you wake up as a ghost, I decided to venture outside the perimeter of the crime scene, just for the screen to fade to black and teleport me back to the crime scene. For me, this triggered a red-flag. Thankfully, this only happens at the first crime scene, as the game world opens up later on. Well, sort of. As a ghost, Ronan can walk through walls and objects, but not all of them. This is explained in the story, something about purgatory houses and whatnot. There are also many pre-rendered cutscenes (locked at 30fps) in this game which gives it more of an interactive movie feel than a traditional adventure game.Now, one of the things which makes the game appealing at first is how investigations work. At a crime scene, you look for clues to solve the puzzle. The more clues you find, there is a better chance of finding the right solution. More interestingly is Ronan’s ability in ghost form to possess people (or cats) and read their minds, or jolt their memories of a particular event, peek at what they are looking and influence them as part of your investigation. On paper, this sounds superb, but sadly the game misses so much potential by its lackluster execution. The problem here is that the aforementioned supernatural abilities are very restricted. You cannot always use the ability to peek whenever you desire. You cannot influence people whenever you want. No, you can only perform these actions when the game tells you. This is utterly stupid because it makes the game even more restrictive and linear than it already is. On the other hand, you can read any NPC’s mind at any time, but they barely give any useful information except when you are at an important plot point.Additionally, the investigation puzzles rarely give you an “A-ha!” moment because there is no challenge. When piecing the clues or connecting the dots, so to speak, you are not punished (fairly) for any mistakes you make in your deduction despite a rating system showing how well you performed. Later on in the story, Ronan gains two new abilities: Reveal and Teleportation. Both are self-explanatory, but they are criminally underused in the gameplay for trivial activities, with the latter being used mainly to get to a secret room with a collectible. Yes, throughout the game, there are 150 collectibles for the player to collect, at their leisure, which provide the backstory of the pivotal characters, the history of Salem and some ghost stories. Side missions are also present, albeit not too many. These involve helping out other ghosts stuck in Dusk and take about 5-10 minutes to complete. They are really easy to solve and optional. Sadly, most of them are not really that interesting as subplots and are not even connected to the main plot.The game has some stealth sections where Ronan has to either avoid or take down Demons once in a while at certain plot events. Contextually, these Demons are corrupted souls which stayed too long in Dusk and their only purpose is to consume the souls of other ghosts to regain humanity. Again, the problem here is down to the execution. There is no depth to the stealth, and frankly, I would barely call it stealth. Ronan can hide from them through soul fragments scattered around the area or by possessing a human, but all this is useless as the Demons can be taken down easily by sneaking behind them and performing a basic QTE. Not only that, but the Demons have an absurdly short line of sight. Even when you get detected, escaping is easy too. Worse, the Demons have a fixed path. There is also a stealth section involving smuggling Joy through a police department and an asylum, but again, the lack of depth in distracting the guards is laughable. In the end, the “stealth” works, but it is lazily implemented and these  sections become more of a nuisance. Thankfully they do not take too long.In conclusion, Murdered: Soul Suspect is a very difficult one to recommend mostly because it is neither utterly bad nor substantially good. It sits perfectly in the middle. It has the looks of an AAA game but the heart of a mediocre indie game. I strongly feel the game could have been better if it were a standard adventure point ‘n’ click game with a longer story, tighter mechanics, challenging puzzles and less emphasis on a cinematic experience. The story on its own, which is only decent at best, cannot carry the game with its current faults this time around. You will not be missing out much by skipping it, hence why I am not recommending it.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a third-person adventure game, in which you play the role of a ghost, who needs to find out about his mysterious murder.You're playing Ronan O'Connor, a detective, who gets murdered right at the beginning of the game. The Murderer itself gets away unidentified and you're staying in this world as a ghost, to find out what happend, why and who did it.The game itself is very story-driven. You're walking (or running) around the different hubs, interacting with items or persons, trying to find clues (and combining them) about your murder or the victims of the serial killer, which you were after at the beginning.There are also various collectibles to be found, which will keep you occupied (if you like things like this).Graphics are pretty neat and i liked the atmosphere of the game, though, even as you visit different scenes and buildings, the overall look doesn't change drastically. A bit more variety could have been better.The story kept me entertained quite well and had also some nice twists throughout the game.There is one part, which could be frustrating: from time to time demons appear on your path, which you'll either need to evade or destroy. THis only happens at certain points in the game (not often) and if you kill them, they'll be gone forever and won'T reappear.It's not *that* hard, but if you don't like things like this in an adventure game, then you might have a little hassle here.Apart from that, i can recommend this to all players, which like fairly easy, story-driven adventure games.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												If you like games such as L.A Noire and Sherlock Holmes this should be right up your alley. It is different from those games though, because this is you solving your own crime. That means your a ghost, wandering around the town looking for clues. I would say this is a very unique game, and that's rare these days.Gameplay wise it's simple, look around for clues, draw a conclusion and go to the next place. it's very interesting because you are a ghost and you can simply walk through walls. However you cant go through solid buildings, unless someone opens the door for you. You can also use abillities like poltergeist, mind control and even take over a cat. This game is extremely story heavy, and the story is really intresting. It kept me coming back until I was done. Even the simple sidequests really intrigued me and made me want to collect every little collectible I could find.About 1,5 hour of the game is cutscenes and the others are gameplay. It's not that long of a game, but I would actually say this was the perfect lenght. It didn't overstay its welcome and drag out for to long. The story was exciting all the way through, and you could never figure out who it was until the end. A lot of plot twists in this game, which reminded me of Heavy Rain. The story is great thanks to impressive cutscenes and good voice acting. Any downsides with this game? Only that the demons and the elements were quite repetitive, but that isn't that big of a complaint since the game didn't go on for that long, and I can clearly see that they put the work on cutscenes and story instead. I really enjoyed my time in this dark and gritty town. This is a game that everyone should play at some point in my honest opinion, it's that damn good. I really hope they will make a sequel or something along those lines.

Murdered: Soul Suspect 


Be free sweetheart 
A Screenshot of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™
By: 𝓝𝓪𝓪𝓻𝓲𝓼




At the moment of this review I have played for 13 hours. Didn't like it some time ago but now... oh yeah.Do I think this game is good and can I recommend it? YES, absolutely. I bought it on steam sale, but believe me, this game is worth at full price. A few words about this game? You have to be in mood to let the story trap you. Are you familiar with Occam's razor? If you are not it's ok, because in this game, that theory doesn't work.


Spectral light 
A Screenshot of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™
By: 𝓝𝓪𝓪𝓻𝓲𝓼




Graphics: If you have a mid/high graphic card you can force to downsampling to play 4k at 30fps. If not, you will play very smooth with everything high. Also, i recommend to use a sweetfx filter because like vanilla, the game is like be inside a soup. The air is grey and you are trap into it. I suppose that the purpose of it it's to remember you that you are dead but hey!! I can go through walls and I have 7 bullet holes on my chest, I know I'm dead! Some of the npcs are clones, you will find the same face sometimes and even when you posses them, some of them will think the same but Salem city is big and alive enough to seem a real city that is under the siege of a murder.The most interesting I found is that the game mixes the past and the present into the same place. You are a ghost and you can see the "memory" of the city, pieces of walls, canons, gallows, sunken boats... places where something (not necessarily bad) happened and are still here somehow, into the spiritual plane.Music: Tension, suspense, horror... I really don't remember the music itself but I can remember the feeling that it provoked ot me, so yeah.... good enough.


Feeling art 
A Screenshot of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™
By: 𝓝𝓪𝓪𝓻𝓲𝓼




Story: Murdered: Soul Suspect will transform you into a detective trying to resolve a case about murders which are happening into salem city. This is important because if you are not in mood to do that role, you won't like this game and it's a shame because it really worth. You will be Ronan, a police inspector with a dark past, who has been murdered during the investigation of the murders (this is not a spoiler) and here is the reason why Occam's razor can't be useful here, because you are a ghost investing the murders... what ghost can see...The story "is" the game. You have to follow the clues, going deeper into the case because like a ghost you have acces to where humans don't have and that's the best bet of this game and at the end is why it traps you until you finish the game.There are some secondary stories that are really good enough to try to resolve them.Gameplay: You can walk, run, posses npcs, and use some ghost powers to boldly go where no man has... well, to try to arrive to new locations and escape from demons. The way you can resolve the different cases you will find is easy and you can think that even boring but the real purpose of it, it's to make you think about the murders and step by step, think like Ronan. You will find yourself thinking on the case, the clues, the main suspect... and just by this the game would be good enough Negative point: You can't save or customize the controls. Demons are supposed to frighten you, but when you realize that they move inside a path, always the same patron, you just sit, wait and ambush them. Some repetitive npcs models, even their thoughts are the same Versión en Español Tenía mis dudas pero el doblaje es francamente bueno.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Bought this game on sale not too long ago, and I'm glad I bought it when it was cheap, as I feel the $6 tag was about right. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a crime drama about a murdered cop on the hunt for his killer. The story ended up being pretty good, a lot of twists and turns throughout, very well done and well written dialogue. If you're looking for a decent story that doesn't drag on, an interactive movie, this is a good purchase. However, if you're looking for more game elements? You won't really find it here. Gameplay is abysmally easy, the hardest parts coming in quicktime events, which are no more than two button combos. The puzzles are no more difficult than "Which one of these reminds you of a cheese sandwich?" *picks the picture of a cheese sandwich*. The setting is great, if albeit a little heavy handed (Wait... Salem... has witches?!), and the graphics are nice. The rest of it... just isn't really there. I completed the game (not 100%... like 75%, maybe) in about 10 hours, and do not feel the need to replay it or go back and hunt for the avalanche of clickies throughout. Unless this drops to about the same amount I paid, I would give it a pass, but $6 feels about right.

 One of the most surprisingly good games I’ve played in a long time. It manages to sell its bizarre premise and builds a solid, moving story out of it, and the plot-propelling investigations add immensely to the detective feel. Walking around as a ghost is clever and entertaining, and it even manages to inject variety into some of gaming’s most overused elements.  9/10

content:
Posted: April 16
												Murdered: Soul Suspect - an AAA 21th century quest title. Or adventure, if you like that definition more. Main mission of the whole game is to fugure out how to move to the next level, optionally helping some other people on the way.1. Gameplay. That's the game where you will not be shooting, or fighting. Except of dodging and expelling some hollow wraiths from time to time, by stalking them from behind and clicking a button to win. On the top of things, you'll be searching for pieces of evidence, and making some investigation going through and through some unpleasant secrets, revolving mostly around old dark history of the town you're settled in.Other than that, you can roam the levels in search of collectables, using your ghost powers to unlock all the achievements and background spooky stories which that game holding under the counter.2. Troubles. Game is buggy. Not messy or totally out of control, but I had to reload the starting sequence two times, unable to "follow the light", and later there was a museum bug (right after the running train part). Those two mentioned  bugs aren't really game breaking, but quite severe, the way I see things. Especially the first one: sure, it's just the start of the game, but, intro video is unskippable, duh!Other than those bugs (and some smaller), and the point that not everyone might like a point-n-click adventure with oversized "search for scrappy notes" part and "open-world roaming" like in the Batman games, where not all places are opened from the start... I am out with any other reasons why you may not like the game.3. Summary. Sure, the visuals aren't really top-notch, and the story is maybe too short for such a project... the actions gets repetative after a little while, and all that "hiding from wraiths" part is not too pleasant... but hey! - every, EVERY game has some weak spots, and someone will not be pleased with it.But, from my point of view, it's really a great game. A piece where you don't need to stab, kick or blast your way through is always a rarety. Ability to help some bystanders while doing you main quest, by putting some of you abilities in a good use, is surely a nice addition to the game's pro sides. Finally, a well-written detective story is always a welcome on my bookshelf. So, I'll mark Murdered: Soul Suspect with 8/10. Not perfect, but really good game which I'm glad I've played.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												This a fairly classic noir story -- with a supernatural twist. I've seen the reviews that put the game at around a 5-6 (mediocre) and on one hand I can see that. The graphics aren't anything amazing and for fifty bucks I'd like to have spent longer than 8 hours to finish the main story. On the other hand, what a fun (if somewhat predictable) story. I especially enjoyed the investigation elements; they're reminiscent of games like L.A. Noire or Condemned: Criminal Origins. Even more, the game is focused exclusively on the storytelling and there's really no combat or action -- it's all about the mystery and puzzles. What little combat there is in the game is mostly based on sneaking around and running away from enemies (you can only attack them from behind).Where the game really shines is in characterization and story development. The two main characters, Ronan and Joy, have a great odd couple vibe that had me laughing in spots. Most of the character development for everyone else (and even backstory for Joy and Ronan) happen through collectibles but provide really deep storytelling that is (occasionally) historically accurate and interesting. I'd recommend this to mystery or noir fans but suggest you wait for the price to come down since the game is so short. I finished all the main story, the "interactive" sidequests AND managed to collect about 75 percent of all the collectibles in my 8 hour play through.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Murdered: Soul Suspect Original Release: 2014 Genre Tags: Adventure; Mystery; Third-Person; Detective My Overall Grade: B+ Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 5-12 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Casual gamers REVIEWMurdered: Soul Suspect is a story-driven adventure game with a strong focus on collectibles and “detective” work, and very little action/combat. You play in 3rd-person adventure style, progressing the story and moving throughout the game world from one spot to the next.  You collect clues and make deductions in the case you are working on in the primary story arc.  The game is pretty linear, which is to be expected for something so focused on story telling; but there is some freedom of exploration.  Much of the backstory and lore can be learned about through the extensive amount of collectibles scattered throughout the levels.The graphics are pretty nice at max settings and the atmosphere of the game is fitting and done well.  The voice acting is among the best you will find in the realm of video games, which is important since the whole appeal of the game is the story.  It’s a pretty short game, perhaps medium-sized if you decide to get all the collectibles— but it is paced very well, and wraps up right around the time it starts to get stale.There is really only one mechanic to the game, which is to move around and pick up clues or artifacts... and maybe use a few bland abilities here and there.  The combat is rare and one-dimensional and never evolves into anything more.  So it feels a lot like a show/movie where you control the main character.  To keep you busy, you can explore the levels to search for collectibles as you play through the campaign.So in conclusion I would posit that I enjoyed my playthrough of this game.  It is pretty minimal in terms of gameplay mechanics; but if you are one who enjoys good story-driven games with atmosphere, and who enjoys collectibles in a 3rd-person adventure setting: then you will probably enjoy Murdered: Soul Suspect.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												I am judging this review based on its full price and therefore cannot recommend it. I would only recommend getting this game when there is a deep sale. The pro/con section will be at the bottom of this review .Murdered: Soul Suspect is a detective adventure game where you play as Ronan, an ex-con badass who became a cop to atone for his wrong doings. You get killed by a man in a hoodie and become a ghost. You learn that you need to find clues to figure out who killed you in order to complete your "unfinished business" and be at peace. This game had so much potential to be something great but fell short and left me with an unsatisfactory experience.GameplayThis is a detective game where you play as a ghost in the mortal world. Think about all the things you can do as a ghost, it's going to be awesome!.. Or at least that's what you are led to believe. You start off the game learning that can you can walk through walls, only to realise that there are "ghost walls" all over the town Salem that you can't walk through. These walls are just there to hinder you from exploring the town of Salem and become extremely annoying after a while. Next you learn that you could possess random people and read their minds, only for it to get boring and repetitive after 20 minutes. The people around the town were bland and shamelessly copy pasted and the only thing you get from reading their minds were always something along the lines of "Oh dear a murder, that’s terrible" or "I wish it wasn't so cold". It's the same thing over and over again and eventually you just won't bother with the possessions. Their scripted dialogue with each other is pretty interesting to listen to though.The core gameplay has you travel from place to place in order to investigate scenes and solve puzzles. You have to find a couple of clues and then come to a conclusion about what the killer was doing or where he was going to next, much like the crime scene investigations in L.A Noire . However the puzzles are so painfully simple and boring that it doesn't take you long to come to a conclusion. In the end it just becomes a sort of glorified find the object game with an extremely obvious "which one of these objects are related to the crime?" conclusion (seriously, a spoon , a fork, or a key that belonged to the killer? I wonder which of these are relevant). The combat system is an extremely basic stealth system where you have to hide from patrolling demons and then execute them when they weren't looking at you. However, like most of the game, demons pose little to no challenge and are just there to hinder you and fill time. The combat didn't evolve over the course of the game and after the 4th or 5th time I heard the demons arrive I just thought to myself "ugh not again".You also have several dialogue options to choose from during the story, but these have no effect on the story at all. There are also side quests where you go about helping other ghosts to finish their business and these quests are rather interesting.There are collectibles hidden all around the map for you to collect, these will allow you to learn about the town of Salem, Ronan's background as well as give some insight on the killer. Unfortunately there is no map function and also no way for you to check which collectible you already have and which ones you still need to find.  I enjoyed listening and reading the stories about the artifacts I collected and make exploring the town enjoyable, I just wished the damned ghost walls weren't so restrictive and annoying.GraphicsThe game is quite good looking and the town of Salem looks great. The ghost structures and mortal buildings complemented each other well to give this dark and gloomy feeling.The main characters looked unique and well designed. There is a 30fps when you have v-sync on, but you can turn off v-sync in game and use v-sync from an external program such as Nvidia's control panel and the game will run at 60fps.SoundThe music in this game was pretty good. It set the mood really well and occasionally the music would go eerily quiet to build tension. The combat music also tries its best to build excitement and tension but was unfortunately unable to complement or help the poor combat system.The voice acting in this game was superb and was one of the only reasons why I could finish this game. I enjoyed listening to the conversations between the main characters and especially liked listening to many of Ronan's monologues.Pros+ Town looks great when the "ghostly" and "mortal" buildings are mixed together to form a unique hybrid look+ Voice acting is superb+ Interesting lore and backstory about the town as well as the protagonist+ Good chemistry between the main characters+ Interesting storyline+ Side quests are a nice change of paceCons- Basic and boring combat system- Core puzzle solving is too simple and repetitive- Extremely linear game- Ghost walls are a hindrance- Somewhat clunky controls- Choices make no difference to the story's conclusion- No replay valueIn conclusion this game is an overly simplified detective game with a boring stealth combat system slapped on it. It fails to impress, and with a price tag of $30 I certainly cannot recommend it over other detective games such as L.A Noire
