content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												While I have said I wouldn't recomend it I do have some positive points as well as negative ones.I will admit the concept is quite a fun one, a dead cop investigating his own death however I feel this game suffers from Remember Me syndrome. A good, interesting concept with bags of potential that has a half arsed delivery. It also feels like a dumbed down L.A Noire, that maybe a bit harsh actualy but anyway it still holds your hand through the investigations that are implemented a lot like L.A Noire. The twist is ok and frankly I was quite a head of the investigation before that point anyway and the rest of the game was basicaly confirming my theories. The controls are also very odd. Exorcising demons, which I swear is never explained how the main character and only him can do it however I may have just missed that or didn't pay attention, involves holding the R then pressing either W,A,S,D and the left mouse button. Now I'm sorry but this is just too much, a 3 button QTE is just too much, it's a QTE not a think for a bit to make sure I have the right button because if you don't your going to have to run fast. These demons are quick and kill quick too, they also freak me out a lot but that might be just me. The mouse is also super sensitive and it took me a while to get used to it even on the lowest setting. The cat controls are ridiculous too and seems to be slightly less broken than Radscorpions, which is saying a lot as they are the most glitchy animals in a game, ever. Oh and the game is too short, and the escort parts are silly as the people your escorting won't move till a distraction happens to lead the person away....who is standing still at the time, not actively searching...so those being escorted are never in any real danger, so it's a tad pointless. On the whole, good concept, average delivery and worth £10 on sale, definatly not full price though.Check out my youtbe channel for lets plays and commentary every Monday and Fridayhttp://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2l1zwMcpJm_hJq4owO3nHg

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I REALLY wanted to like this.  The premise was unique (you're a detective and you need to find out who murdered you).  But this was just not enjoyable.The game is short.  By itself, this isn't a big deal, you don't need to put 40+ hours into a game to get your money's worth.  My playtime was 9 hours.  But I'm guessing 4 of those were spent fighting with the game's poor systems:1) No Map.  Seriously?  What is this 2004?  In a 3rd person exploration game this is unheard of & seems like it was omitted to add unnecessary time & difficulty.  Wandering about town, there is a series of intermediate waypoints that lead you to the next target, but those get broken & send you through areas that aren't available, so unless you're a navigational expert, you're stuck randomly wandering until you luck into the next target.2) Combat.  It's basically added as an afterthought to add time in between the "investigations" (which are generally well done, once you figure out the game's systems).  There's one monster type & it's pattern is easily identifiable.  But the controls are difficult & even if you do everything right you still might get caught & have to redo the area.  The game is using poor controls & frustration to again add extra difficulty & time, instead of giving the enemies useful AI.The graphics are fine, but suffer from overusing a "dark & hazy" theme.  Considering the story takes place entirely at night, this is probably expected.I was engaged enough with the setting & story enough to want to finish it, but definitely won't be replaying to get a 100% finish.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Criminal turned detective stumbles upon a killer and end up dead. Insted of going into the light, he becomes a ghost, resolved to reveal who murdered him. It's an adventure game, most similar to LA Noire. You go around, detect and inspect clues, listen onto the conversations, talk to other ghosts, walk through the walls, think, make hypothesis, solve mysteries, and reveal the story step by step. There's no much action, but there are stealth sequences, where you have to detect demons, and destroy them before they find you. A lot of optional content (side quests, world information, character info and all that) to be found. Nice graphics and sound, a bit weird controls but one can easily get used to them. I like it.

												To start off there is only 4 hours of gameplay here and no replay value. It is basically an interactive movie. It is a murder mystery. For me this game/movie was kind of boring... Not very fun for a video game. I feel sorry for those who paid full price. I guess I got my $12 worth out of this game since it's cheaper than going to the movies to kill 4 hours. This is a Crime, Drama, Murder, Mystery. I'd say I've been bored for 4 hours since I just wanted to finish the story. It wasn't worth it for myself. There was no challenge at all... Just go here investigate this and that help this person do this get here blah blah blah.... Just boring.Killing demons isn't even satisfying and it's also a very small part of the game to add a challenge... It's not challenging at all. Just get behind the demon hold R then you will have to hit W, A, S, or D with left or right click, it's completely random which is cool but i'd rather actually battle the demon with something more interactive. But yeah do that and the demon is dead YAYYYY!!! Or you can just skip killing demons and go to your next location... doesn't matter.This game is only worth $12 or less. For a single-player only game for $50 when it released and only 4 hours of gameplay if you don't care about finding every stupid hidden piece in the world. I just went where I needed to go and picked up what I could along the way. Most single-player 3rd person / 1st person games have around 8 hours average if not a little longer and also have replay value majority of the time.Bought it, played it, completed it, never playing it again, the end.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												This game starts oddball, but settles in quite quickly. I suppose you could call it an adventure title – it's kind of like a modern cop detective game, without the sort of action you'd assume to be stuck in as a timesink filler padding out a story. It is *much* more like a modern third person shooter without any of the shooting, just the investigative minigames, the scavenger hunt collectibles and the plot. Does this make sense? Designwise it simply does not feel like an adventure game.I do recommend it.Last note on the Steam version – getting it to run on my PC was an absolute, horrific chore. For some reason, the Steam integration .dlls kept the game from starting. It kept crashing right at the start, stating that it can't contact the Steam client. Well, eventually I got it to run by some dark magic steps that I'm not going to publicly enumerate, at the cost of losing most of the benefits Steam bestows.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I picked up Murdered: Soul Suspect because a good friend kept stressing how good it is (in spite of all the negative reviews), and I wasn't at all disappointed with the game. In fact, I enjoyed it a lot more than I ever thought I would! The game relies largely on its characters and the murder mystery that's central to said characters' lives. If you're looking for a fast-paced, highly action-driven game, it doesn't deliver on that front - but that's what made it such a great ride for me as a player.I wasn't sure what to expect of the game from the premise alone, but it does atmospheric horror really well, along with the splashes of detective fiction and noir, too. Investigating, gathering clues, questioning witnesses, and making deducions are all important to the game. It even has an historical angle that I first thought would be somewhat canned, but actually surprised me a bit by the end.Collecting is an important part of the game and, although it's "optional," a lot of the story content depends on how well you can scour a map for all of the items - some hidden and some not. Even with ~10 hours play time into my first "completed" game, I still didn't track everything down! So if you're a completionist who enjoys searching and interacting with maps, M:SS definitely appeals on that front.The other main challenge of the game is demon encounters, and they can be tricky to master at first, since some of the combinations are a little awkward. Still, by the last few maps it seems easier (as the difficulty doesn't really go up much during the course of the game) ... but it's definitely anxiety-inducing sometimes! All in all, the demon encounters kept the game from feeling extremely linear (i.e., like a visual novel).So if you're into mysteries and crime fiction, love spooky stuff, and enjoy a game that burns a little slowly, definitely give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												After hearing bad reviews about this game, I was a bit hesitant to even buy it. But the more I read into the reviews, the more I realized that this game was just never given a fair chance from the start. A lot of people came off as jaded as to what they wanted and expected with "Murdered: Soul Suspect". In truth, I feel as though they were wrong."Murdered: Soul Suspect" is what you expect out of a good ghost story, or even a Noir movie. You have many different characters that fit the roles they were supposed to play. The story keeps you guessing until the very end, and manages to keep you on the edge of your seat the whole time. While it is not like a sandbox game like many had hoped and desired, you still have plenty of places to explore and little nooks and crannies to find within the game's structure.This game is not for a player who wants a sandbox world, who wants to shoot up bad guys, or that has to really put some effort to unlock, discover, and solve the many puzzles within the game. This is the kind of game that is for those who enjoy the journey it takes you on. For those who loved games like "Gabriel Knight" or "7th Guest". Good horror stories that make you want to discover everything that happened and why.While the replay value may not be as good as some other games, it is the sort of game you will play, try to find all the artifacts in the first run through, and then put away when you are finished. You will then pick it back up after awhile, and play it once more for the amazing story it tells.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												This game is very similar to LA Noire but instead you are a ghost detective in the present day instead of an LAPD detective in the 40s. The gameplay mainly consists of walking around and examining objects in the environment to help solve cases. If that bores you, don't get this game because there is not even much of a combat system aside from sneak attacking demons once in a while. It is kind of open world in the sense that you are free to walk around town and collect objects to solve side cases, but the lack of any sort of map or minimap makes exploration a hassle. With all that being said, I enjoyed the story and atmosphere of the game, which is surprisingly a bit lighthearted for a game about ghosts. It took me about 7 hours to complete the game and I also took my time to grab most of the collectibles as well.Verdict: Definitely get this on a sale, it is short but sweet. 6/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												This is a really enjoyable game. The gameplay is mostly just finding stuff around the environment, with a few simple stealth combat sequences and puzzles to mix it up. The story is pretty good, although far too short. Voice acting is top-notch, although the game does suffer from 'Welcome to Corneria' syndrome at times.If you hate collectables, this is not the game for you, but unlike many other games, you actually get nice rewards for finding stuff here. The side stories are quite interesting.All in all, this game is clearly low-budget and unpolished, but there are still many endearing and fun features. If you're a fan of immersive environments and detailed lore, don't miss out on this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												Murdered is a game with an interesting idea and showed a lot of promise before it was released; a game where you play a deceased detective hunting down his murderer whilst solving crimes and using ghost powers, what's not to love? Well the problem is that the game is ultimately short and, frankly, boring - there is nothing to do outside of the main quest aside from FOUR side-quests and a bunch of collectables no one really cares about; the use of ghost walls, while a good concept, are only present to hide how small the environment is; and the biggest problem? This game is far too easy. It has a points system depending on how well you solve the crimes, but this doesn't actually have any impact whatsoever, and there is no penalty for making a wrong judgement, sure you lose a point but even after you lose them all you can keep on guessing. Oh and this game can be painfully short, if you're good at it you can complete in under 4 hours (or if you want to speedrun and miss the cutscenes - the story is the best part of the game, mind you - you can complete it in about 2). So yes, Murdered is an OK game, but it's one that will be played once and probably be forgotten about soon after playing it. However I do recommend playing it, but get when its on sale.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												To be honest I expected better with this game. Better story, better mechanics, better gameplay, better graphics.  The story is probably the best part. It wasn't too obvious and had a lot twists and turns to it. That being said it does have some glaring flaws.  Some of the gameplay is fun for a while but the problem I found is that you begin with almost all the powers you will have at the end. This leaves no room for a feeling of character progression and development. It has some buggy mechanics such as having to stand at the exact right spot to interact with certain things. The graphics seem very last gen. I also HATE the stupid demon killing thing. It's very repetitive and an all round pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to have to take them out. Negatives aside, I wouldn't say the game was terrible. If you enjoy story based games, in particular, ghost/horror/noir based games. You may enjoy those aspects enough to warrant you buying it. I would say, buy it if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
 So, Hear Me Out, I'm Going to Do Something A Bit Different Here I bought this game for next to nothing on Humble Bundle a while ago and played it awhile ago. Now I'm giving this a positive rating because I enjoyed it for what it was for how cheap I got it at. That said, I am going to give you a dual opinion here. You will hear the side of me who got it cheap and you will hear a side of me who bought as if it were 60 dollars. So, to be fair, I will ♥♥♥♥♥ for both sides. Let's begin.Legend1 - 60 dollar opinion2 - 2 dollar opinion (around the price I bought it for)(1)ARE YOU ♥♥♥♥ING KIDDING ME!!!! 60 dollars for less than a 5 hour experience? I forgot this was an interactive movie. This David Cage ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off where game developers think a good short story is enough to justify a 60 dollar purchase for a "Video Game" as in you play the ♥♥♥♥ing game. Sure, the story is decent but the game play is♥♥♥♥♥♥ No wonder so many people were♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off about this interactive story, it lacks meat, it has almost no game in it. Now you have to follow some teen girl around because shes the only one that will put up with your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t or rather is the only one who can since no one else can hear you since shes psychic that has to listen to whiny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s like your character who can't handle being dead so he has to find out which ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ killed him. Of course, I don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥since the main character is easily forgetable, hell there's interesting side characters I remember more than him that are in this game.(2)The game will start off with your character, Ronan, literally dying in the first 2 minutes after starting. The game had a good story and even though lack of game play was present here, at least for the price I got a worthwhile experience and an interesting concept of a story. While the game play does lack, it does have pretty entertaining parts to it at times. These times being the investigation parts where you, as the ghost, investigate crime scenes finding things that humans can't quite find. The game makes you pick 3 evidence that you found to match up a story but there's really no penalty here, the game will just move along and that's that.(1)Speaking of the "game play" there is "stealth" sections but they aren't stealth, its just waiting for someone to turn the ♥♥♥♥ around or setting off a printer so that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ can check it for eternity while you guide a teenage psychic around. You can also possess this teen or other humans so you can pass certain sections you can't get through by yourself. Yeah, this is the first Triple A game where it encourages you to go inside a teenage girl, ♥♥♥♥ing perverts. You also can possess animals as well, so now for 60 dollars I can go inside a teenage girl and a cat, was this concept straight out of Jared Fogle's computer history? You also can read their mind and hear what they're thinking if you're a nosy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. This game also presents you with a linear open world where you can't travel through certain walls, cause ♥♥♥♥ it, right? They came up with some sort of an excuse but I forget what it was.(2)The game play, or what is there rather, consists of stealth sections, while linear, are more like puzzles you have to solve. You guide the teenage psychic through a dangerous area, like, a Police Station or a Mental Hospital. You just distract somebody one certain way and you move her on. Sometimes they might switch it up but essentially its the same kind of pattern. There's also collectables...(1) Who gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the stupid collectables.(2) ....That I can agree with. So, they're not hard to find but with a game with little content in it, I doubt it'll reward you in anyway besides giving you behind the scenes videos to watch. The open world is hard to traverse at times since its got a lot of invisible and visible walls up to block you way. It can be a boring and confusing process but for being a slow game in the first place, it won't affect the flow too much unless you are on your way to a dangerous event taking place. You also have to use these ghostly hiding places where you can hide from demons when they are hunting you down. You can go about two ways of taking care of demons in most situations, one: You ambush all of them and send them back to hell or you take out who you have to and move on leaving the others alone.(1) The voice acting is meh, but I'm not here to listen to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, I want to play a ♥♥♥♥ing game. Why is that for 60 dollars that out of my 3-5 hours I have to sit here and listen to an hour total of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t? This game is like the Order 1886 before the the Order 1886. Sure, the atmosphere is creepy and the demons you have to hide from are scary, however, the story is decent, like I said. But there's still no game here. I don't get why this game got a 9/10 for 4 hours of story and almost no gameplay. The game play itself isn't even innovative, why is no one else♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥about this?(2)I thought the voice acting was pretty good and the scenes were shot well, although not perfectly. I did enjoy the story and the characters moving around were realistic looking, like they're actually just human beings, they have casual movement and the lip syncing isn't even that bad. Overall, it makes it more believable of a story.(1)Overall, for 60 dollars, its an over glorified movie and its game play is almost non-existent. Its a sad attempt at a game but a good attempt at an interactive movie. Of course, it should be this expensive, you greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s over at Square Enix need to stop ruining the game industry damn it. You ♥♥♥♥ing ruined Deus Ex Mankind Divided cause of your ♥♥♥♥ing greed you mother..(2)Unless you can get it for the price I got it at, which is dirt cheap, yeah, just look it up on YouTube or something if you don't wanna buy into it since its just a movie and not much more than that.

												Very enjoyable game with alot of twists keeping you guessing and wondering what's next. Playing as Ronan O'Connor  you piece together clues and evidence to find his killer . With just the right amount of skill for anyone to keep the story moving along.Great voice overs and dialogue that had me smiling and laughing at times.If you like to find hidden objects there are 247 total artifacts to find if that's something you'd be interested in .Having missed 3 artifacts I proceeded to the final chapter and couldn't go back. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of the best detective/interactive fiction games I ever played. The story is quite compelling and dark, since you play a cop who was murdered and has to find out about his killer. Taking place in the legendary small town of Salem, which you can freely traverse, you head from one crime scene to the next. There you have to solve single cases, all of which are interconnected and eventually will lead to reveal the big picture of the main mystery. You will find clues to other side cases everywhere and can interact with a lot of people, dead and alive. The presentation, utilizing the Unreal 3 engine, is very adequate to the story, creating very dark and gritty ambience. Everything is nicely modeled and really good animated and also the sound design is excellent and facilitates the gloomy atmosphere.The only critique that I have is that there is little to no replay value. Once the cases are solved, you will hardly touch this game again.All in all I had a great time playing this game and I do recommend you give it a try. My verdict: 9/10 points -  great game

Now you have to follow some teen girl around because shes the only one that will put up with your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t or rather is the only one who can since no one else can hear you since shes psychic that has to listen to whiny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s like your character who can't handle being dead so he has to find out which ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ killed him. Of course, I don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥since the main character is easily forgetable, hell there's interesting side characters I remember more than him that are in this game.(2)The game will start off with your character, Ronan, literally dying in the first 2 minutes after starting. The game had a good story and even though lack of game play was present here, at least for the price I got a worthwhile experience and an interesting concept of a story. While the game play does lack, it does have pretty entertaining parts to it at times. These times being the investigation parts where you, as the ghost, investigate crime scenes finding things that humans can't quite find. The game makes you pick 3 evidence that you found to match up a story but there's really no penalty here, the game will just move along and that's that.(1)Speaking of the "game play" there is "stealth" sections but they aren't stealth, its just waiting for someone to turn the ♥♥♥♥ around or setting off a printer so that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ can check it for eternity while you guide a teenage psychic around. You can also possess this teen or other humans so you can pass certain sections you can't get through by yourself. Yeah, this is the first Triple A game where it encourages you to go inside a teenage girl, ♥♥♥♥ing perverts. You also can possess animals as well, so now for 60 dollars I can go inside a teenage girl and a cat, was this concept straight out of Jared Fogle's computer history? You also can read their mind and hear what they're thinking if you're a nosy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. This game also presents you with a linear open world where you can't travel through certain walls, cause ♥♥♥♥ it, right? They came up with some sort of an excuse but I forget what it was.(2)The game play, or what is there rather, consists of stealth sections, while linear, are more like puzzles you have to solve. You guide the teenage psychic through a dangerous area, like, a Police Station or a Mental Hospital. You just distract somebody one certain way and you move her on. Sometimes they might switch it up but essentially its the same kind of pattern. There's also collectables...(1) Who gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the stupid collectables.(2) ....That I can agree with. So, they're not hard to find but with a game with little content in it, I doubt it'll reward you in anyway besides giving you behind the scenes videos to watch. The open world is hard to traverse at times since its got a lot of invisible and visible walls up to block you way. It can be a boring and confusing process but for being a slow game in the first place, it won't affect the flow too much unless you are on your way to a dangerous event taking place. You also have to use these ghostly hiding places where you can hide from demons when they are hunting you down. You can go about two ways of taking care of demons in most situations, one: You ambush all of them and send them back to hell or you take out who you have to and move on leaving the others alone.(1) The voice acting is meh, but I'm not here to listen to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, I want to play a ♥♥♥♥ing game. Why is that for 60 dollars that out of my 3-5 hours I have to sit here and listen to an hour total of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t? This game is like the Order 1886 before the the Order 1886. Sure, the atmosphere is creepy and the demons you have to hide from are scary, however, the story is decent, like I said. But there's still no game here. I don't get why this game got a 9/10 for 4 hours of story and almost no gameplay. The game play itself isn't even innovative, why is no one else♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥about this?(2)I thought the voice acting was pretty good and the scenes were shot well, although not perfectly. I did enjoy the story and the characters moving around were realistic looking, like they're actually just human beings, they have casual movement and the lip syncing isn't even that bad. Overall, it makes it more believable of a story.(1)Overall, for 60 dollars, its an over glorified movie and its game play is almost non-existent. Its a sad attempt at a game but a good attempt at an interactive movie. Of course, it should be this expensive, you greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s over at Square Enix need to stop ruining the game industry damn it. You ♥♥♥♥ing ruined Deus Ex Mankind Divided cause of your ♥♥♥♥ing greed you mother..(2)Unless you can get it for the price I got it at, which is dirt cheap, yeah, just look it up on YouTube or something if you don't wanna buy into it since its just a movie and not much more than that.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												this game is an absolute disappointmentbut before i start raging i must pause and give a thumbs-up to the interesting plot that this game has. and that's about it what can anyone enjoy the game. maybe some shallow gamers could also enjoy it for the graphics but don't get me even started on those.anyways, there is absolutely no gameplay. the whole "game" consits of boring pixel hunting, after which you are asked absolutely dumb "detective" questions, which often don't even make sense and would make even CSI-miami look like a decent detective movie (which it is not). basically, it has absolutely nothing to do with playing a detective.the hours of boredom spent by pixel hunting for "clues" and collectible artifacts are accompanied by an absolutely ridiculously primitive "stealth action", which consists of walking behind a wall with ghost infravision or whatever and just killing these demons with a press of a button. and the game does not even punish you for getting noticed because you just run away, hide and return later, and try to press the "KILL GHOST BUTTON" again. and if you are incompentend enough and manage to get killed somehow, i don't know, maybe a dog jumped in your face or something, then you respawn 1 milliseond and 1 millimeter before the enemy encounter, because the checkpoints and saves are almost literally made after your character makes a step. (honestly, i have not gotten killed a single time during the game, except for once when i wondered what would actually happen if i got killed on purpose)honestly, just reading these few paragraps written with my terrible english will probably be a time spent better than trying to enjoy the gameplay of this excuse of a modern "press x to win" game. but as i said earlier, the story is cool and the little ghost tales told for collecting items during the abrasive pixel hunting are interesting as well. i would much rather watch a 1 hour long B-movie made from this story than die in agony wandering through the streets of the boredom town to get to the story.this was a terrible experience, and screw the money but i want the time back. the time. give me back my time.PS. before you dismiss the review because i have 0.1 hours of the game played on the record, i played it with steam in the offline mode and it just didn't register my playtime

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Even though I am recommending this game, it is only a recommendation *IF* you can get it very cheaply (and I am sure you will be able to)You play the ghost of a cop who was killed and you have to solve your own murder. Good premise, and a pretty good story too, the problem is the gameplay. You are lead by the hand through the whole game, go from point A to point B and when you get there find a few things. It doesn't matter if you get anything wrong, there are NO penalties, just try again.The game is also VERY short, so to try and pad things out, the programmers have added a couple of "collect random objects" quests to make things last a little longer. You don't have to collect them and they add nothing to the story if you do (or don't) There are a couple of smaller "mysteries" to solve along the way, which are fun, but overall this game is just bland. Highly polished, but bland.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Save your money. I was pretty excited to play this game, but after completing the main story-line in under 9 hours I am severely disapointed. Difficulty: This game is incredibly easy. It's basically point-and-click. You can't make any mistakes, really. You walk between locations and look for clues, which are very obviously highlighted for you.  I thought I'd have to be solving puzzles, piecing together clues, but everything is spoon-fed to you. The main character must be the worst detective in history, because I was figuring things out way before he was. There's no real threat or doom in this game. I mean, you're already dead, so you can't exactly die. The only obstacle (if you can call it that) are the soul-sucking demons (Which look like Dementors from Harry Potter) which pop up and must be vanquished (Which is also very easy to do. Just sneak up behind them, click three buttons and POOF! Gone).Story: The story could be interesting if it wasn't painfully dummed down. There are no complex intertwining stories, no in-depth characters. Everyone is exceptionally bland and cliche. *Spoilers ahead* So you play a detective called Ronan in Salem who has just been murdered by the "Bell Killer". Ronan is exceptionally slow. It takes most of the game for him to figure out that this "Bell Killer" preys on "witches". (It's Salem. That was obvious.) He discovers who the murderer is with the help of a "Medium" who can see/communicate with the dead.  Graphics:Even the graphics themselves aren't that good. The characters mouths move at random, not really forming any real words. They move their arms and heads around as if they're puppets being pulled by strings. Even the cinematics are poor; clothes have jagged edges, and character's faces have no emotion.Glitches: There are glitches in this game which don't allow you to complete current objectives. Also, it's a checkpoint save game, so if you encounter a glitch you must reload from the last save-point (wherever thay may be). I also had a problem of cinematic scenes repeating themselves if I walked into a location where the objectives had already been completed. World:There is a very small area of game play. No map needed. You are in a tiny town and you are able to enter the museum, the church, the graveyard, the police station and the hospital (but only when the game calls for it). No free-roaming or exploring. Just walk to the next location (the arrows show you the way) and complete the objective. Then it's on to the next location.  Overall: This is a VERY boring, VERY easy game. Utterly dissapointing.  Rating:2/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												I just beat this game and I can safely say that I loved it.(I have tried to avoid spoilers at all costs, but I'd still be wary of them)I have actually been following the development of this game since it's first announcement, and when I saw the bad reviews I was kinda sad that a game like this would do so poorly.Luckily, the reviews didn't put me off enough to not play the game. I did play it and well, it's fantastic. The story is definitely the highlight of this game. Playing through it and see all the events and twists kept me immersed that I nearly forgot about real life. Was a long time ago I had an experience like that.The gameplay, while most reviewers said it was bad, I enjoyed walking around finding things and exploring. I also liked the "stealth" element with hiding around enemies. You don't actually fight, and if you get seen they hunt you down until you die. You have to get behind them and execute them through a QTE (which is pretty easy, but I messed it up a bit because I got stressed like crazy when those things were around)The game is open-ended and Salem acts like a sort-of hub for the game. Doesn't mean that it's not shockful of collectables Also, the game has loads of those. Around 200.All-in-all, I loved this game. It's not the perfect game, but the story is just amazing. The game is relatively short, but in my opinion the story makes up for it. I would recommend you to buy it, but if around 8-10 hours doesn't cut if for you, you should wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												I'd only recommend this game for its story only - in no way is this game worth the full price and it doesn't live up to what a game should be (some good gameplay elements but not used very well).This game is more fitting for a movie than a game since the whole "clue" thing is very much compulsory to proceed in the story line. The investigation aspect is forced on to you on each level and spoon feeds you on what you need to do, meaning that the harder-to-find clues aren't even necessary and have no impact in the game, making it a linear story. Side quests are almost non-existent despite it showing some potential with some of the ghosts you talk to - most of which, there is nothing to persuade them to move on from the living world. It has much potential but it dies down and you realize that everything you thought was cool, becomes repetitive and or unnecessary. Gameplay/Story aside, there are annoying technical issues with this game - only one save file is allowed and the autosave is terribly planned. If you're unlucky, like me, you'd have spent some time and lose all your progress with side quests (did two side quests and quit the game, only to find out that the game didn't save). The game's vsync is garbage, your video driver's vsync produces better results.To sum things up, the game aspects of this game are great but not used well to keep you entertained for long. The only things that could keep you entertained would be the story and that depends per user's preference. The autosave feature sucks, it only saves during main quest and when you enter/exit places. It doesn't save on the town map at all.[Possible spoiler regarding gameplay]The teleport and remove abilities are barely used in this game, making you wonder "whats the point of having this?". In the end, you only use the teleport ability for travel conveniences rather than to get past obstacles like how it was originally introduced to you. Remove ability is pretty much dead in the game, there's no point of having it. I'm quite ok with the monsters but other people may have issues with them. The demons need more variety. There are only 2 types of monsters that get in your way and it's those same 2 from beginning to end. Their availability in the game are very rare and illogical - you don't see them in the open map and only during story related quests. The investigation/clues - some answers are stupid and doesn't fit well in what you are observing, others are so obvious. As mentioned before, the important clues are in your face and you're forced to use them as your evidence. You won't be able to proceed unless you use those set pieces.The AI ... at first, you think it's cool but as you play on and interact with the non-quest related AI, it all becomes repetitive. They all say the same things and they don't react when you use poltergeist... they're there for decoration and nothing more.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I'm going to begin by voicing my displeasure at the fact that steam has only a two means of reviewing a game. The bright blue thumbs up or red thumbs down is the first thing people see and it is criminal that I'm forced to open my opinion with either a blatant recommendation or condemnation, as it is often never that simple. Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of those games that I feel very ambivalent towards. It gets a thumbs down though for reasons I'll gladly expound upon here but I'll start by saying that If you do want to buy this game, go ahead, but do it at a discount as there isn't enough of it to warrant its full price by a long shot. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural intrigue game where you play as Ronan O'Connor, gangland warrior turned detective and wandering samurai warrior, who is tracking a mysterious serial killer. Ronan is about apprehend the killer in the opening cutscene when the killer decides he's had enough of the law and reenacts the opening scene from Watchmen all over Ronan's face before shooting him seven times in the chest. So Ronan is dead, but you knew that already. Ronan now has to endeavor to do in one night what the entire police force couldn't do in years worth of time and solve the case of the Bell Killer. M:SS reminds me of two very specific games I actually liked, the first of which is Alan Wake. Like Alan Wake, this game is about supernatural dealings with a distinctly traditional American feel. Also like AW, the rules for the supernatural stuff in this game are very well defined.The supernatural lore being dealt with this time is ghosts, exploring all the traditional facets of what you might think ghosts are like, but before you go hog wild there is an exception to each of your abilities. You can pass through walls but not consecrated or ethereal walls, which mark the level boundaries. You can jumble electronics, but not to any meaningful degree. You can possess people but not control their actions. You can teleport, but not over demon holes so you still have to circumvent those on foot. Also like in Alan Wake, there isn't a whole lot to do in between plot points except hunt for collectibles. This leads me into the real issue I had with this game: its design.Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game of extra steps. I kept a running list of things the game took more than one step to complete without needing to: Often the game will end a cutscene just to have you press the interact button to continue the same cutscene. When questioning a suspect, you have to press a button for each option you want to explore but the interrogation doesn't end until all options are explored, so it might as well be one long cutscene. You can read the minds of people you possess but each person has exactly two things to say and you have to press the button twice to hear both things when they could just say them both at once. When piecing together the clues of an investigation, if you pick a wrong option you get booted from the screen, having to reenter the screen to continue. When grabbing collectibles, you have to reveal the object first before picking it up. The collectibles are half hidden but the game tells you where they are so there's no need for hiding them. Speaking of collectibles, there are a plethora of them, all of which have very little to no bearing on the actual game. Each area has a unique object that, once all are gathered, will unlock  a spooky campfire story unrelated to what you are doing. There are a series of over arching collectibles including diary pages from Ronan's dead wife (really the only means of character development), handy info blurbs copy-pasted from the Salem tourism comity website, and newspaper clippings reminding you how creepy and invincible the serial killer is.While Alan Wake also felt the need to boldly announce the appearance of an enemy so that there is no way for you to be caught off guard, at least it had engaging combat. Every once in a while the game breaks up the monotony by presenting you with enemies to sneak up behind and quick-time-event to death. Once or twice a level, there will be demons that half-heatedly wander around in an enclosed area. You have to hide in the hiding spot and wait for the monster to turn around so you can slowly walk up behind it and kill it. This ends up being tedious and non-threatening, unit you mess up. If you manage to not properly dispatch your spectral foe, the backlash is absurd. Demons will kill you within a 3-5 second window unless you can scurry back to a hiding spot. However, once detected, the demons can see you in hiding spots; forcing you to shift between them as fast and erratically as possible until they give up. This turns what little combat there is into a game of Red Light, Green Light. These sections make no sense to the lore of the game either as there is no reason given as to why Ronan seems to be the only ghost that can dispatch the demons. No introduction is given to the power nor is it explained that Ronan is the only one capable of it, leading me to wonder why the other ghosts all flee in terror when the demons show up.The second game I'm reminded of is L.A. Noire, because the investigation sections are reminiscent of the ones in that game. You have to walk around the crime scene and collect the clues, using them to piece together the motive of the criminal. There are six to fourteen clues per scene but only three of them at most are ever necessary to continue. It's no secret that detective work is not as flashy or intriguing as it is portrayed in popular culture, but no where is this more obvious than video games. L.A. Noire had a good mix of action and detective work, due (I think) to it's structure. All the clues were relevant because solving the case was the goal of the mission and everything unfolded naturally. Murdered, by contrast, has you investigating glaringly obvious crime scenes which, more often than not, inform you of something you already knew. For example, one crime scene later on in the game has you investigating a room full of people the Bell Killer murdered all at once. At the point of investigation, however, you have already been made aware of what the killer did afterword, so the reason for killing the room full of people is obvious. Then, once you investigate the room, Ronan stands there and tells the the reason the killer did it, even though you already knew. Really the investigating is just being a master of the obvious. It's also impossible to fail to find all of the clues, because the game tells you how many are present in the scene.Murdered, like many games these days, would have probably made a better book or movie. The game play really just consists of different kinds of walking around and looking at things. Despite being a game made by an established developer and publisher, this is something any indie dev could have made, if not made look quite as good. In the end, games are meant to be interactive; that is what the medium excels at. Yet more and more it seems like games are being made with interactivity at the bottom of their priority list. Once during the middle of a cutscene I caught my self replying to text messages. It was then I realized how bored I was with the game; how absolutely unengaged I felt. The story was really not all that bad but being set in Salem, you can bet with reliability that it will have to do with what Salem is famous for. I would rather them have just made a movie out of it and cut out the game play entirely. At least then it would have taken me only 120 minutes to get through.

(you get flashes of information when you find the clue, then you have to watch it all over again anyway once you 'solve' the crime)If you enjoy 'Tell me a story' mode games and can get past the controls it's alright. but get it on sale.

Posted: December 25, 2015
												The game has a good story, nice environments and believable characters with solid voice overs. Actually, it could have been one of those interactive movies if not these two things.First of all, it's completely linear. The main story and a few side quests. The only variable is whether you find all the collectibles (they are all related to the lore) or not. More likely, not - looking for every collectible is just too boring and doesn't provide much new information.Secondly, for some reason the creators tried to add more depth to gameplay and introduced demons that you need to hide from or kill stealthily. And it just doesn't work. Too easy for any Thief (Splinter Cell, Hitman, etc) player and too boring on top of that. Thankfully, those moments with demons are really short and sometimes you can simply run through them and then hide.Despide the flaws, I still recommend playing it. Basically, it's like watching a good movie. Perhaps you can even be surprised in the end!

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												A hidden gem or a rusty stone To some players, this game popped up from nowhere in the Square Enix's catelogue. However, some players has been following this game from E3 2013 and has been building up alot of anticipations and pre-release hype. Based on the original concepts, authentic setttings and unique mechanics, this game definitely delivers.In this epic detective meets criminal adventure heavily inspired by the likes of L.A. Noire and Alan Wake players takes the role of detective Ronan O'Connor who happens to find himself being killed by the mysterious 'bell killer'. He then not only find himself dead in the real world but simultaneous alive in another dimension like the movie 'ghost'. Determined to find out who the killer was, Ronan embarked on a endless investigation to solve the mysteries behind his death and discover the dark secret behind Salem's ancient history of witchcraft.By playing as a ghost, you gain awesome abilities such as no clipping through walls, possessing people, poltergeist electronic devices to attract attentions, and if these aren't enough you can possess a cat and go 'meow'.By poeessing common folks around the town, you are given the options mind read their thoughts. However, most of the things they say provide little to no useful information at all which makes it pointless at any point of the game. Some NPCs such as police officers will allow player to obtain useful clues regarding the cases often by means of eavesdropping, peeking through their eyes and influence their decision making.By possessing the cat, you gain access to platforming sections of the game which often will help you to get to a upper level.The detective elements of the game was not as good as L.A Noire, investigation can help you gather clues and the amount of clues needed for each case was given to players. Interrogation can only be done on other ghosts and it involves picking from limited options and are way too easy most of the time it is just common sense. With enough clues gathered, players can conclude the current investigation by chossing pieces of important information. Players are given 3 chances and even if you selcted the incorrect choices, the game will give you infinite tries leading to eventually picking out the correct information by trials and error.This idiotically defeats the purpose of giving 3 tries and has way too much hand holding throughout the story. Whereas, in L.A noire inability to solve crimes often can have consequences and investigation cannot be done again once it is concluded.The combat is however interesting as player gain ability to see demons through walls to allow advanced planning of strategies and make decisions to whether encounter or avoid. Most of the battle requires player to teleport between human remain souls to get behind the demons to perform execution called 'exorcism'. However, the game has only one enemy type and every encounter feels the same and after a while it gets repetitive.The environment is also quite boring with little open world elements, no interactive NPCs, and bland design choices that players often just walking around for collectibles, side cases or towards the next objective. Speaking of side quests and collectibles. It can be a real chore as the game has little replay value so you gasically back tracking for the sake of it. There are no incentives or rewards for doing it apart from some achievements for completing a side case or a set of collections.Characters have little personality development throughout the game, most of the time I find it hard to relate to most of them. If the story wasn't decent enough to make me continue playing I just cannot think of much selling point in this game.Techniquelly, there has been occassional frame rate drop issues and stuttering problems which is annoying but still playable. When booting up the game for the first time, the screen also flickers a few times but I won't rate a game based on these minor issues as it can be simply fixed with a update or two.Is this a good game?I think overall, yes it is a good game if you like story driven adventure that doesn't involve all out shooting and straightout combat. Its appeal really comes from a real life location and interesting depiction of Salem's ancient history and traditions with a unique play style, it can be really appreciative. If you can ignore the problems present and look at the good side of things plus the price they are asking for, I would say it is worth a try.Final verdictMurdered: soul suspect is far from perfect or a masterpiece if you compare it to similar games such as L.A noire and Alan Wake. But it borrows what is good from both titles and add its own twists which some think it is good and some simply may not like it.Finally, I think it is one of those game that should be played but just don't expect 100% perfection and a fully immersive world and rather expect a rough around the edges unque title to try in 2014.7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of the best detective/interactive fiction games I ever played. The story is quite compelling and dark, since you play a cop who was murdered and has to find out about his killer. Taking place in the legendary small town of Salem, which you can freely traverse, you head from one crime scene to the next. There you have to solve single cases, all of which are interconnected and eventually will lead to reveal the big picture of the main mystery. You will find clues to other side cases everywhere and can interact with a lot of people, dead and alive. The presentation, utilizing the Unreal 3 engine, is very adequate to the story, creating very dark and gritty ambience. Everything is nicely modeled and really good animated and also the sound design is excellent and facilitates the gloomy atmosphere.The only critique that I have is that there is little to no replay value. Once the cases are solved, you will hardly touch this game again.All in all I had a great time playing this game and I do recommend you give it a try. My verdict: 9/10 points -  great game

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I'm going to begin by voicing my displeasure at the fact that steam has only a two means of reviewing a game. The bright blue thumbs up or red thumbs down is the first thing people see and it is criminal that I'm forced to open my opinion with either a blatant recommendation or condemnation, as it is often never that simple. Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of those games that I feel very ambivalent towards. It gets a thumbs down though for reasons I'll gladly expound upon here but I'll start by saying that If you do want to buy this game, go ahead, but do it at a discount as there isn't enough of it to warrant its full price by a long shot. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural intrigue game where you play as Ronan O'Connor, gangland warrior turned detective and wandering samurai warrior, who is tracking a mysterious serial killer. Ronan is about apprehend the killer in the opening cutscene when the killer decides he's had enough of the law and reenacts the opening scene from Watchmen all over Ronan's face before shooting him seven times in the chest. So Ronan is dead, but you knew that already. Ronan now has to endeavor to do in one night what the entire police force couldn't do in years worth of time and solve the case of the Bell Killer. M:SS reminds me of two very specific games I actually liked, the first of which is Alan Wake. Like Alan Wake, this game is about supernatural dealings with a distinctly traditional American feel. Also like AW, the rules for the supernatural stuff in this game are very well defined.The supernatural lore being dealt with this time is ghosts, exploring all the traditional facets of what you might think ghosts are like, but before you go hog wild there is an exception to each of your abilities. You can pass through walls but not consecrated or ethereal walls, which mark the level boundaries. You can jumble electronics, but not to any meaningful degree. You can possess people but not control their actions. You can teleport, but not over demon holes so you still have to circumvent those on foot. Also like in Alan Wake, there isn't a whole lot to do in between plot points except hunt for collectibles. This leads me into the real issue I had with this game: its design.Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game of extra steps. I kept a running list of things the game took more than one step to complete without needing to: Often the game will end a cutscene just to have you press the interact button to continue the same cutscene. When questioning a suspect, you have to press a button for each option you want to explore but the interrogation doesn't end until all options are explored, so it might as well be one long cutscene. You can read the minds of people you possess but each person has exactly two things to say and you have to press the button twice to hear both things when they could just say them both at once. When piecing together the clues of an investigation, if you pick a wrong option you get booted from the screen, having to reenter the screen to continue. When grabbing collectibles, you have to reveal the object first before picking it up. The collectibles are half hidden but the game tells you where they are so there's no need for hiding them. Speaking of collectibles, there are a plethora of them, all of which have very little to no bearing on the actual game. Each area has a unique object that, once all are gathered, will unlock  a spooky campfire story unrelated to what you are doing. There are a series of over arching collectibles including diary pages from Ronan's dead wife (really the only means of character development), handy info blurbs copy-pasted from the Salem tourism comity website, and newspaper clippings reminding you how creepy and invincible the serial killer is.While Alan Wake also felt the need to boldly announce the appearance of an enemy so that there is no way for you to be caught off guard, at least it had engaging combat. Every once in a while the game breaks up the monotony by presenting you with enemies to sneak up behind and quick-time-event to death. Once or twice a level, there will be demons that half-heatedly wander around in an enclosed area. You have to hide in the hiding spot and wait for the monster to turn around so you can slowly walk up behind it and kill it. This ends up being tedious and non-threatening, unit you mess up. If you manage to not properly dispatch your spectral foe, the backlash is absurd. Demons will kill you within a 3-5 second window unless you can scurry back to a hiding spot. However, once detected, the demons can see you in hiding spots; forcing you to shift between them as fast and erratically as possible until they give up. This turns what little combat there is into a game of Red Light, Green Light. These sections make no sense to the lore of the game either as there is no reason given as to why Ronan seems to be the only ghost that can dispatch the demons. No introduction is given to the power nor is it explained that Ronan is the only one capable of it, leading me to wonder why the other ghosts all flee in terror when the demons show up.The second game I'm reminded of is L.A. Noire, because the investigation sections are reminiscent of the ones in that game. You have to walk around the crime scene and collect the clues, using them to piece together the motive of the criminal. There are six to fourteen clues per scene but only three of them at most are ever necessary to continue. It's no secret that detective work is not as flashy or intriguing as it is portrayed in popular culture, but no where is this more obvious than video games. L.A. Noire had a good mix of action and detective work, due (I think) to it's structure. All the clues were relevant because solving the case was the goal of the mission and everything unfolded naturally. Murdered, by contrast, has you investigating glaringly obvious crime scenes which, more often than not, inform you of something you already knew. For example, one crime scene later on in the game has you investigating a room full of people the Bell Killer murdered all at once. At the point of investigation, however, you have already been made aware of what the killer did afterword, so the reason for killing the room full of people is obvious. Then, once you investigate the room, Ronan stands there and tells the the reason the killer did it, even though you already knew. Really the investigating is just being a master of the obvious. It's also impossible to fail to find all of the clues, because the game tells you how many are present in the scene.Murdered, like many games these days, would have probably made a better book or movie. The game play really just consists of different kinds of walking around and looking at things. Despite being a game made by an established developer and publisher, this is something any indie dev could have made, if not made look quite as good. In the end, games are meant to be interactive; that is what the medium excels at. Yet more and more it seems like games are being made with interactivity at the bottom of their priority list. Once during the middle of a cutscene I caught my self replying to text messages. It was then I realized how bored I was with the game; how absolutely unengaged I felt. The story was really not all that bad but being set in Salem, you can bet with reliability that it will have to do with what Salem is famous for. I would rather them have just made a movie out of it and cut out the game play entirely. At least then it would have taken me only 120 minutes to get through.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												this game is an absolute disappointmentbut before i start raging i must pause and give a thumbs-up to the interesting plot that this game has. and that's about it what can anyone enjoy the game. maybe some shallow gamers could also enjoy it for the graphics but don't get me even started on those.anyways, there is absolutely no gameplay. the whole "game" consits of boring pixel hunting, after which you are asked absolutely dumb "detective" questions, which often don't even make sense and would make even CSI-miami look like a decent detective movie (which it is not). basically, it has absolutely nothing to do with playing a detective.the hours of boredom spent by pixel hunting for "clues" and collectible artifacts are accompanied by an absolutely ridiculously primitive "stealth action", which consists of walking behind a wall with ghost infravision or whatever and just killing these demons with a press of a button. and the game does not even punish you for getting noticed because you just run away, hide and return later, and try to press the "KILL GHOST BUTTON" again. and if you are incompentend enough and manage to get killed somehow, i don't know, maybe a dog jumped in your face or something, then you respawn 1 milliseond and 1 millimeter before the enemy encounter, because the checkpoints and saves are almost literally made after your character makes a step. (honestly, i have not gotten killed a single time during the game, except for once when i wondered what would actually happen if i got killed on purpose)honestly, just reading these few paragraps written with my terrible english will probably be a time spent better than trying to enjoy the gameplay of this excuse of a modern "press x to win" game. but as i said earlier, the story is cool and the little ghost tales told for collecting items during the abrasive pixel hunting are interesting as well. i would much rather watch a 1 hour long B-movie made from this story than die in agony wandering through the streets of the boredom town to get to the story.this was a terrible experience, and screw the money but i want the time back. the time. give me back my time.PS. before you dismiss the review because i have 0.1 hours of the game played on the record, i played it with steam in the offline mode and it just didn't register my playtime

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												I LOVED this game. But I'll confess to having a bit of a bias due to how firmly this game dug into a favorite subject of mine storywise - laying the dead to rest/bringing peace to the restless dead. The story is dark, intriguing, and I count it among those rare ones where I couldn't figure out where plot twist was going ahead of time.PROS:-Superb storytelling-Excellent quality voice acting-Graphically gorgeous and expressively animated-Tons of exploration-Tons of stuff to collect as a reward for exploring-Interesting story-related things unlocked by finishing collections-Controls overall translated well from controller to keyboard-Intriguing puzzle system.-Very good 'beacon' system to get you from goal to goal along the mainstoryline.Cons:-Barely-there combat system. It fit the feel of the game (I'm serious about this), but anybody looking for more than light stealth sections are going to be disappointed.-No map whatsoever. This can be particularly frustrating when trying to track down collectibles.Verdict: Very, very good, excellent game, just not for everybody.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												I was genuinely surprised by this game. I had my doubts when the hype around this game began to wane when it got closer to launch. Glad I was mistaken.The story starts with a bang and keeps you interested with a plethora of sidequests and lore. There's a lot to find in Salem, as there are over 200 pieces of different collectibles you can, uhm, collect. Bits of info about the town, witch trials and the characters themselves. All of them well written.Graphically the game looks good, but then again I'm really not that into graphics when I play. Voice acting is quite nice, though the budget seems to limit the amount of voice actors on NPC:s, as you tend to hear the same dialog often. But at least you don't hear Nolan North arguing with Nolan North (looking at you, Mafia 2).Story is great, in my opinion, and the ending was good. No cliffhangers or anything, everything is resolved.The gameplay is okay, although the "stealth combat" seems a bit out of place. It's only padding, really, they should have let that on the cutting room floor. The UI is very console-like, with rather odd button bindings. Nothing major, though. I played this with keyboard & mouse with no problems.All in all, it's a good game, definitely better than its metacritic score. Sure it's not a masterpiece by any means, but it sure has a spot on my underrated gems -list.

												It is not so often, when I get lost in a game like I did with Murdered: Soul Suspect. Everything about this game roars quality and adventure & mystery. You can solve tasks without having all of the clues discovered. You are even allowed to return previous locations to finish the side quests there, if you've skipped them through the Main Storyline. A lot of collectable item awaits you in the game, that unlocks so exciting extras such as other murderous stories has happened in Salem, even it's History. You can get more informations about Ronan, Jul.This game means something like Dishonored to me. Where an immersive story meets great graphics. And just not talking about Ronan. He is AWESOME.

Then I watched the first few minutes of gameplay, coupled with reviews, and (wrongly) came to the conclusion that is was a hidden object game/single-room puzzler wrapped in a 3rd person Unreal Engine. content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I need to point out a bias, and that's that I love games that dare to be different. I have no heavenly idea whether it's the optimism or the bias itself speaking, but I really like this game! I'm sure you know what the game is about, you're an ex-"bad boy" who wanted to change your life, so you became a cop. Now, during an investigation, you got shot by a mysterious man who seems anything BUT normal. You now need to solve this wicked mystery of who that man is, to get your redemption. Don't worry, you won't get to hold a gun, exactly, so it's not your "average COD-clone".My personal opinion of the beginning- and middle parts of the story is that they were good.  The ending was the most disappointing part of the game, however. Extremely cheap and weak way to end the game.. and even if it was "cheap and weak", it left you with a whole lot of questions afterwards. I won't spoil anything But story was overall quite good.The world in itself, that you walk around in, is fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic! It is soooo cozy to walk around in a very Italian-like village during the night! But there's a huge flaw.. hugeeee flaw. The voice of the main character is painfully bad. He tries to do something Batman-like and deepen his voice way too low that it ruins everything. I don't know how to demonstrate this exactly, but when I was playing and heard him talk, my stomach hurt.. that's how bad this situation is!Other characters are somewhat lovable, and their animations & voice acting are all well done. HOWEVER, despite this game being "open-world" the elements that show this are abscent. There are missions you can do when roaming around such as helping a ghost solving their deaths, but I've only found three or four. Pathetic! And the collectibles aren't even worth thinking about. It does get quite scary at times as well, however, for you horror-lovers. I definitely recommend this game, in the end, though!7,5/10

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect - Spoiler Free ReviewFirst off, I'd like to point out that I like both pulp noir and ghost stories both of which are heavy influences on the general feel of this game.  If you do not like either the cinematography stylings of pulp noir (in which case, you won't like the cut-scenes and may dislike the characters on occassion) or think ghost stories are dull, then this is not the game for you.  For those of you still with me and looking at potentially buying this game a bit of background is in order.  The studio that released M:SS closed down despite really ploughing everything into this game.  Part of it is odd in places, which I'll get to, but mostly they'd been struggling for a while due to releasing a couple of games which were bombs a while back.  Any future updates to the game will have to be community driven but that at least is one piece of good news - after multiple playthroughs I only came across one minor glitch, once, and it was a graphical one that I couldn't replicate.  The game runs really well so future patching should not be necessary.So, where to start?  How about the story.  It's pretty standard fair, almost straight out of a "Randall & Hopkirk: Deceased" episode.  You're a detective in Salem when a call is put in about a strange hooded man breaking into an apartment building.  As you are an emotional loose cannon after your wifes' death (it's actually nice to play a character who's irrational behaviour gets some explanation for once) you chase after him alone only to find that he's too strong for you, the eventual fight resulting in your death.  Your purpose is to stop the killer from beyond the grave so that your spirit can move on and be reunited with your wife.  This opening is actually really impressive as it's almost entirely done using the in-game engine and graphically looks superb, the sweeping camera shots and the slow-motion work really well giving a strong movie quality feel but rather than just have you as a passenger watching the opening the developer makes you take part in it, trying to first catch the killer and even trying to survive the attack.  The sound is excellent too and is nicely understated, something that carries throughout the whole game.After this you're left, dead, in Salem trying to figure out how you can stop this killer.  There's a tutorial which covers the controls and then you're given objectives to complete but you are left to wander through reasonably large parts of Salem without being stopped.  As you're dead you come across other spirits and left over memories of Salem in it's past, which just helps to make the world more interesting and full and the contrast in design is really well realised, especially when it ties in with the sidequests and main stories.  The more you progress the more of Salem opens up to you, allowing you to find out more about Salems past and revisit areas you have already explored.  The team have been as historically accurate as possible, considering that the game is a work of fiction, and you'll get to pick up on a real flavour of Salems darker past as you wander town.Character design suits the mood of the town too and there are characters in period dress in certain areas, although they are very few and far between, I'd have liked to have seen more of them.  They are reasonably realistic to look at - not ultra-real - which would feel out of place in a ghost story, but real anyway with very good motion capture and facial expressions especially on the main ones.  One that stood out to me is a point where a character manages to pretty much lie with just their face for a split second near the end, you'll know it when you see it, but the technology is well utilised without being overdone, it does not take you out of the story or gameplay very much if ever.As a ghost you get to travel through walls but presumably due to hardware limitations this pretty much is only really used within enclosed spaces, though this is explained within the game-worlds mythos itself well enough and it can be quite good fun.  These sections really can make you feel like a running, screaming spirit.  I felt less like a spirit and more like I was going to have a seizure due to swoosh noise everytime you select a conversation topic.  It's fine in short conversations but they can be long and a little grating if you want to find out everything.There's some disturbing bits in this game too.  Some pretty nasty deaths of young women, some ghosts have some surprisingly harrowing and well-acted lines, almost mini-stories, of their own if you come across them and there are collectables that unlock urban legends, a couple of which are genuinely quite creepy.  There are places with a lot of extra details added in which build up a wonderful sense of dread and oppression too, a lot of which can easily be missed and overlooked as it is just there for scene-setting.  Controls are pretty tight, the camera is good but can be a bit awkward when you are possessing something or trying to get through a wall slowly.  But there are two elephants in the room and these are what most reviewers scored the game so harshly on.1) Pointless Sort-of Forced Combat/Stealth Sections.You do combat, you either have to go for it whole-heartedly or just don't do it.  In for a penny, in for a pound!  M:SS feels like it's dipping it's fingers into the collection bowl and wondering if it can get away with giving a two Christmas old chocolate coin.  You get an enforced stealth section, taking you out of the more interesting portion of the game which feels jarring, so you can try to sneak past these demon-monsters which look like the Nozghul if they'd been drinking sheep-dip.  It hardly ever works so you have to try to stealth kill them, which is only a temporary fix.  2) Escort MissionThe escort is at least useful but these are really badly designed - it barely matters if you get spotted because the spotter sub-routine is so badly programmed.Both of these things feel tacked on and out of place.  I have a sneaking suspicion that they received orders from their publisher that if they wanted a Triple A advertising budget then it had to have those things in it because they feel completely at odds with the rest of the game.  And yes, I will be doing a video rant I am that annoyed about it.Mercifully, there's only a handful of those sections and apart from that and one point with a truly stupid portrayal of mental illness (completely different to an earlier scene with a ghost in a bath), the rest of the game is pretty much excellent.  If you can stick out those few parts you will find a good to look at, engaging murder mystery, with an excellent twist and interesting backdrop and characters.I recommend it, but have to dock it marks for 1) & 2)        Total Score:  7.5/10  Well above average and definitely worth a play if you want a murder mystery that's a little different or a slowly paced adventure game.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												While I do recommend the game overall, I have one major gripe with it: the demons. Having to fight them was, for me, a total distraction from the story. In short, they were supremely annoying. IMHO, the game would be much better without them.I have one other, less serious, gripe: the navigation system. At various times there is a pointer displayed that, supposedly, tells how far, and what direction,  it is to the intended destination. It's practically useless; truly annoying.On the positive side, the story is really good. The way the graphics are handled is also pretty clever. Some say it's similar to L.A. Noir. I've never played it so I can't compare. The movement mechanics for keyboard were good. It is a little slow at the beginning while trying to figure out what to do, and how to do it, but it picks up as you get into the story.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												This game is another example, approving that Square Enix releases good solid games, but not AAA level. I waited for it, and although it did not meet all my expectations, it left me satisfied.First of all it a game of a rare genre nowadays - Adventure. Get rid of the demons and demon hands - and this is a pure non-combat quest. The closest example which appeared in my mind is Indigo Prohecy. Sometimes it's really pleasant to drop off your swords, guns, explosives, tanks, etc. and just listen to a good (mystic in this case) story, or since we're talking about the game - become a part of the story.The plot doesn't bring something new (or maybe it's me getting older), but it's interesting and keeps you involved till the end of the game, with a small twist. Thankfully, game is pretty short and does not get you bored - 16 hours in my case, BUT, this is becasue of the greatest minus of the game - it's terrible, random, sadistic check points. I had to exit the game after several hours of playing, and when came back to it about 30 minutes were gone. I had to rush into several side quests again aaand....caught a bug with Ronan falling through textures, reloaded, and repeated those 30 minutes.As far as I understand this is first succesfull project from Airtight Games. If they had more budget, city would be bigger, there would be more side quests, more reasonablo thoughts in the citizens' minds and more interactive objects. So I wish developers all that for their next project so it can become a real AAA game. For now, it's 7,5/10 (not enough for 8, better than just 7)

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												This game starts oddball, but settles in quite quickly. I suppose you could call it an adventure title – it's kind of like a modern cop detective game, without the sort of action you'd assume to be stuck in as a timesink filler padding out a story. It is *much* more like a modern third person shooter without any of the shooting, just the investigative minigames, the scavenger hunt collectibles and the plot. Does this make sense? Designwise it simply does not feel like an adventure game.I do recommend it.Last note on the Steam version – getting it to run on my PC was an absolute, horrific chore. For some reason, the Steam integration .dlls kept the game from starting. It kept crashing right at the start, stating that it can't contact the Steam client. Well, eventually I got it to run by some dark magic steps that I'm not going to publicly enumerate, at the cost of losing most of the benefits Steam bestows.

												WARNING: This game is WASD keyboard configuration ONLY!!! You can select to use a controller but if you choose keyboard you are stuck with their WASD configuration; enough reason not to buy. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED.
