												Awsome game!It's something new and original, something you won't see often these days.I played for about 16 hours to complete it with all it's side quests and most of the collectibles, that reveal some nice story elements.Didn't find all of them yet, though.While the graphics are fantastic, the textures and animations of all non story relevant characters are pretty low.Their movement is kind of stiffm their textures low res and on that many of them even share the same textures.Since Salem, the town where everything will tak eplace in, is pretty small, you will have the feeling to run across the same five npcs the whole time.That said, it might even hurt the game concept if it was bigger.Everywhere in the open explorable town, are notes and similar collectibles hidden. Despite Salem's small proportions, those collectibles can be pretty tough to find, since you won't come across them if you aren't searching for them.Among notes and ghosts and humans  with trivial conversations, you happen to meet some ghosts with their own problems.If you find one, a side quest opens up and you can help them to get rid of their problems and move on.The system to help them is the same as in the main story line.The Main story line uses a puzzle system which repeats itself with every quest, but does never get old at the same time.Since you are a former detective, you will investigate each place, lokking for hints and combine them to find where to go next.Those hints are aquired and combined by many different actions to assure varied gameplay.The story itself is very atmospheric and intense with a good soundtrack alongside.The story characters have all an own personality which is intentionally used to drive the players sympathies.All of them are important in their own way and no one of them is forgotten quickly.Technically is some room for improvement.There are some minor bugs, graphically and not affecting but common.I came along one game breaking bug which forced me to reload an old checkpoint. Saving is done automatically and fair placed, though.Hitting some walls will let Ronan twitch around for a second while some other walls, intended to vanish at will, can't be targeted to do so. Luckily, there is always another way around.In the end I would give this game a 7 out of 10, strongly recommending it to experience something new.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect takes a fascinating part of American history and pairs it with a supernatural detective story.  The environment and plot is very creative and unique and kept me interested until the end.  The game is fairly short and doesn't overstay its welcome, yet still provides a lot of character and plot development as well as a few twists.  That being said, there are two minor downfalls to this game.  The first is the overuse of collectibles.  While the collectibles are easy enough to find and doesn't require too much 'post game time' to sit down and sniff them out, there are still a ton of them.  Over 170 in fact.  Each collectible gives some sort of backstory to the world or relevent major characters, but the sheer number of them will have you running to pick them up first before doing the actual story missions.  I feel this can really take the player out of the setting and mood Murdered: Soul Suspect tried to create, with its old, colonial, haunted theme.  If you are the type of player to skip right over collectibles and not be bothered, then this isn't a problem for you.  But if you are OCD, have to get them all, hear every backstory, learn every secret, then this will probably get on your nerves a bit.The other issue to this game is that some of the puzzles are unclear as to how you should go about solving them.  While this has only happened to me about maybe 15% of the puzzles in the game, it is still frustrating to look up the answer and say to yourself 'How does that make sense?'.  The game does give hints if you get the puzzle wrong, but sometimes the hints aren't that clear.  With some trial and error, you should be ok though.Overall, I enjoyed this game.  I picked it up when it was $4 and would have gladly paid $20 for it.  The setting and plot were really unique and I liked all of the ghost mechanics that were added into the game.  It is definitely a game to play when you are looking to get a good story with some amusing puzzles.  I rate this game a 9/10.

The options are unusual: you can possess, influence on smbd, read the mind and execute the demons. You walk through the game as a ghost, and the main objective is to solve your murder. Despite of this, you are also able to solve the other victim's murders while revealing the hidden items. After you found all the clues on a particular problem, the game proceeds with the next video part that tells you smth. more about your own. AND THAT'S ALL. Nothing more. It becomes boring, especially for those who do not like repetitive cycles. There is nothing scary in the game, it just makes you bored. My advice is: buy this game only if you like what I described above or if you are reach enough to spent around $60 to explore HQ video and the graphics and to satisfy your curiosity.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												While I enjoyed the game enough to actually finish it, the overall experience felt very unpolished.What I Liked:-Lovable Characters: I liked all the characters. The voice acting was really great, and I cared about Ronan and Joy; a lot of fun and interesting interactions between the two of them.-A completionist's dream: All sorts of stuff to collect, and fun little stories to unlock if you're into that sort of thing.-Interesting Storyline: The story was surprisingly original, outside of a few painfully predictable points. Original or not, it was interesting and kept my playing.What I Hated:-Sloppy Game Mechanics: Game mechanics were a mess. Especially the dialogue options. You enter a cutscene for each dialogue choice, and the break is very obvious. Once the cutscene ends, there's another obvious break, and you get to choose another dialogue option. It was strange and killed the immersion.-Investigations: Basically a hidden objects game. Walk around, find anything and everything it actually lets you examine until it says you've found all the clues. Then guess which one is relative to the current case. Easy and oh-so boring.-Felt Unfinished: A lot of the powers were pretty useless save for one or two very rare, very unique moments where the game practically screams at you: USE THIS POWER! Teleportation could've been really cool, but there's only a few spots it actually comes in handy, and even then it's super clunky and annoying. A lot of useless hiding spots you'll never use, no matter what, never ever. They're just there for the aesthetics, I guess? Just looked messy to me. And while the start of the game seems to promise a lot of interesting side investigations -- helping to put spirits to rest -- there are very few to actually be found as the game progresses, at least, that I could find.-Enemies: Demons. . .could've been scary, but instead they're just annoying. They walk (float?) a predetermined route. You do the exact same thing to kill them (quick time event). There's no real combat in the game, or even a sense of urgency. You just hide, quick-time kill an enemy when he turns his back on you, repeat.-Cats: O. . .M. . .G Fun at first, but then, seriously, WHY is the SAME black cat everywhere in Salem? You know what, I think that friggin cat might be the killer! Shows up in the most convenient places, always there when I need it. . .what's it playing at? Or maybe it's different cats, all brothers and sisters. . .with absolutely no way to tell them apart. . .? Maybe? And seriously, what is the point of pressing "Q" to "Meow"?I enjoyed the game, it was fun in its own ways. Mostly it was a story that was nice to experience. But MURDERED: Soul Suspect is NOT a $50 game. Maybe $20. So no, can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												A pretty good whodunit detective game. Most investigations can be beat by brute force, but that nets you overall less points. The games best selling point is it's creepy atmosphere and the offer of playing as a ghost and playing as a ghost is quite frankly a lot of fun. I dare you to not veer around trashcans and aim for doorways in the first few hours when you could infact just pass through the wall or something instead.You use abilities such as possession, mind reading, memory tracing and teleportation to accomplish your goals.The games weak parts is it's lenght, it's on the short side. And the enemies scattered around, quite frankly i feel that the game would have been better without enemies at all and just more detectiving. Every enemy encounter goes like this: You are startled by a loud scream, you hide nearby, wait for them to turn their back and then kill them with a QTE. It's just a hassle, not scary, not fun and they are in the way. Thankfully there aren't many enemies at all in the game.All in all i really recommend Murdered: Soul Suspect if you want to think a bit for yourself, fantasize about the beyond, are a bit of a history buff, are into creepy atmospheres or ghosts, just looking for a mystery or all of the above. A very pleasant surprise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Let me save you the time, and let you know that while this will be a review, it is going to read as more of a rant than anything else. Understand going in that I am not going to recommend any one play this game, at all. The reasons will be detailed below, but I am writing this as a way of venting my frustrations with the game, and treating the main purpose of this as a "buyers beware" because let me tell you, I am not going to let the store page lie to you. I will get to that in a second. That being said, Murdered Soul Suspect is the most dissapointing game of the year for me. Hands down. When it comes to expectations (what little I had asked from it in the first place) Not only did they fail miserably, they somehow managed to fail at even the BASIC expectations.  So what were my expectations? I just wanted a good mystery game. Interact with the environment/clues, piece stuff together. Learn about the mystery and basically just immerse myself as a detective. It didn't have to be a compelling narrative or anything, but for the story, I at LEAST wanted a likable main character.  I didn't EXPECT an L.A. Noire esque mystery game, and I would have even allowed a Deadly Premonition esque kind of mystery game. But this......WHAT IS THIS?Where do I even begin with this game. I hope if you are foolish enough to read my tirade you will at least have the respect for yourself to have a snack. Buckle in boys and girls, here comes the salt.  I want to address the store page bullet points real quick. To get this out of the way now. It's a good starting point as any. I won't address them all, just the ones I object to, and you, the future buyer, deserve to know the truth of. -"A twisting storyline supported by a great cast of characters constantly raises questions over the secrets that Salem hides."  This is cute. What great cast of characters? No. I am not being facetious, I mean what great cast of characters? Where are they? There are characters, sure, and I would have loved to learn more about them, but 75% of the cast occassionally drops in for that ol "THEY COULD BE THE KILLER" scooby doo schtick.  No in reality the game really only focuses on Ronan (main character) and Joy, his spirit medium. Every other character isn't any more developed than the last beyond fulfilling the cliche role they were intended to fulfill. There is no "constantly raising questions over the secrets that Salem hides." It's no secret. No, I want you as the reader, right now, to mentally say the first thing that comes to mind when you hear the word Salem. If you said "oh the Salem witch trials right?" then you my friend, are one smart turkey. Tadah. Oh, and there is only one main twist. I don't know where this twisting storyline business comes from. That implies it's constantly twisting.-" Move freely from one haunting location to the next and even if you have completed your investigation, return to previous scenes to follow new leads." Sounds compelling right? By move freely they mean you are essentially in a little invisible walled off box, and boy let me tell you there are a TON of invisible walls. Yes, you can return to previous scenes, but "to follow new leads?" What on EARTH are you TALKING ABOUT? The only time you return to a previous scene is if you forgot some disposable optional collectible you wanted to collect for 100% completion that doesn't do jack for you unless you are trying to get all the achievements. None of this "new lead" bullcrap. You don't change the outcome of anything. You are merely just taking a guided tour through this game.-"Seek-out hundreds of collectibles, side-quests and cases from Salem’s citizens past to learn facts about the town and its people, improve your detective ranking and help you piece together the truth about the killer." If there was ever a burning point I wanted to address, it's this one. This one, singular sentence on their page. It's complete false advertising. First off, while there are a COUPLE hundred (not hundreds) of collectibles, there are NOT hundreds of sidequests and cases from Salem's citizens. There are FOUR cases (not a typo) where you help out deceased citizens, and  EIGHT collectible sidequests that reveal a story of a previous murder not really tied to the main quest murders. The other collectibles that involve the main quest killer? They don't help you piece together ANYTHING about the killer other than he likes killing  and little blurbs from tabloids. How does that HELP anything? and honestly, with how poorly fleshed out and planned the characters were, you can more or less figure out who the killer is within the first 2-3 hours of gameplay.  The twist was nice, but again, you kind of expect it. The really sucky part about all this is they should have done more with the sidequests involving helping the citizens come to term with their death. But no, you get 4 quests, and the other spirits you run into, you get a two choice branch that changes nothing and it just falls flat. Or hey! hey! better yet! more of those collectible stories involving the side murders but you know, without the cheap copout collectible requirements! MAKE THOSE ACTUAL MISSIONS.  It would have been a farcry better than what we actually received.-"Survive powerful demonic spirits who devour souls in a belief that they can regain their own. Strategically use supernatural abilities to evade and outwit them before they tear away your soul forever." HAHAHHAHA, "strategically?"  STRATEGICALLY?! Are you kidding me?! What STRATEGY? Wh-what, you mean, exploiting the terrible AI of the 3 enemies at any given moment by hiding in plain sight, waiting for them to lose aggro, then mashing a QTE prompt? Or, or, using the various distraction options available (j/king you can only distract them with one thing, a crow) and then rinsing and repeat? Get out of here with that nonsense. Stop dressing up this lazy nonsense to sound fancy. Shame on you.Now that is out of the way, let's talk "gameplay." Well, you can basically consider this game a semi-rails game. Or, more or less, a guided tour game. You aren't actually playing the game. I mean, yes,you are controlling Ronan, and he is responding to your controls, but literally 60% of the gameplay is you collecting stuff. It's like a giant collectible scavenger hunt. When you aren't collecting things that have no rhyme or reason or impact to the game, the other 40% of the game is you "solving" crime scenes. But, YOU aren't solving SQUAT. The GAME has that covered. Look, there is no penalty for guessing wrong or deducing something wrong. All the clues are in the same room. There is no interacting with clues. Hell, the game will sometimes literally zoom in on the primary clue in a cutscene before you even start, rendering all your clue collecting pointless. AND, when you DO have all the clues collected, guess what reader? The game is like, "soooo what do you think happened" and you piece together 1-3 of the clues to "solve the scene." BUT AGAIN, there is no penalty for failing. It's as braindead as you can possibly get. My favorite moment occurs when the killer is looking at a picture, and the game asks me "Well, what do you think he is doing?" and 6+ words flood the screen and you gotta figure out what he is doing. He is clearly startled and up to no good, and literally half the options are the exact opposite of the mood being displayed. What is this, Dora the Explorer? Agh... this game, I haven't even scratched much of the surface, there is so much I want to talk about. So much...so much rage. But I have already spent too much time talking about the game. Look, I don't like it. I think it's highway robbery they would seriously ask for $50 of YOUR HARD EARNED MONEY for this crap. TL;DR: I  hate this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game cuts a lot of corners, and in a bad way. I will start off by saying that you shouldn't expect anything innovative in terms of gameplay and story because there is literally nothing to this game. Have you played Heavy Rain or Beyond Two Souls? Remember how there was some gameplay in that? Take that,  but remove more of the gameplay and make it a noclip simulator 2014 edition because all you'll  be doing is walking around and looking at things. Slight spoilers ahead.The detective bits? Bland, and obvious as the story is. Sure you won't figure out who the killer is but you will pick up what the deal is with the Killer and still have the protagonist and everyone else bumping their heads into the walls being clueless. Anyone could of picked up the patterns since it was so obvious but near the end of the game that you'll be eager for it to end. Unless you're easy to please. Oh there's a twist to the plot but it doesn't make any gatdam difference to the plot nor does it change anything at all for the later part.Now let's get to gameplay, aka wonder around a building trying to navigate and occassionally posessing people just to influence. There's no point in posessing other people that aren't vital to the "INVESTIGATE ZONE" since they all have two lines in mind read and that's it. Reused model heads on different bodies and that's it, find a creeper ghost in some kid's closet only to find five more of him with multiple jobs. Investigate zones are what I like to call areas that you'll be trying to search every nook and cranny to find enough clues to conclude the level, and that itself is also really annoying. Most of the clues are hard to see, and I understand how it is but if I have to look hard through one big room just to realize I need to examine some bloody cat prints for no reason that aren't even remotely related to the case then what's the point? This game is more hollow than how I felt when I beat it.As for the supposed combat? Horrible. There's nothing to it, and it's the most bland thing you'll ever experience. The demons that you face are always set on a path, they won't hunt you down unless they see you nor explore any rooms other than the patrol paths that they'll never stray from. Killing them is also a chore. Press direction + button = instant victory. That's all to it. They're just there to hinder you and nothing else. They'll arrive in the area you just left and have to backtrack to because they can. You can't get by them either so you have to fight them. You can hide and wait patiently. It just feels like they threw them in there just "because." They don't have any real point to them other than to add more than just walking around and "examine" things.There are side quests though, and that's just more INVESTIGATE ZONES for you to burn time away in to make the game last longer. Will you get anything for it? No. There are collectables, will you get anything for it? No. Only thing you will get is achievements, and  that's it. There are no rewards, there's no good feeling having to help ghosts and frustrate yourself in INVESTIGATE ZONES that are so damn open or have clues so hidden that you can't complete it. A good example is one quest where you have to find out if a guy killed his friends or not, and the objective is "Who saw the driver?" No one in that area, not even the Taxi cab driver who was probably called the other night. There's no point in any of these side quests, nor the collectibles to find out "Salems history" or backstory.If I want to read about Salem's obvious history that I learned in history class, I'll use gatdam google3/10Don't buy it unless it's on sale for like ten bucks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												TIme to find out you're not as invincible as you once thought. TL;DR - I give it 7/10. If you love being the detective and you love ghost stories, then definitely get this game. However, there are enough "cons" that make me suggest you wait until it's on sale. Longer review below. Despite it's short "running time", (took me 11 hours to complete), I feel in love with Soul Suspect. This game is not about combat or shooting things. It's about detective work, it's about figuring out how to sovle your murder and stop a serial killer even though you can't touch things in the physical world. On the whole, Soul Suspect feels like an experiment, an enjoyable one, but still an experiment. People complain about the "lack of combat", but in my opinion they should've cut out the whole system, it became repetitive and just downright annoying. The devs should've focused more on the story, which is what's at the heart of this game.Althought your character, Ronan, seems like your typical white dude, he has a refreshing personality, and he actually changes over the course of the game. Same goes for your "sidekick", Joy. The ending feels rushed, and more interactions with the characters you've met along the way or one more investigation could've tied the whole thing together. Even letting the character roam the town of Salem some more afterwards would've been a great opportunity for the devs to include some bonus missions. Overall, it's enjoyable, it's pretty creepy, and you just have to approach it like it's an interactive detective movie, not a "shoot em up".

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												The idea of this game is fantastic, and the story is interesting enough to make you think about it when you stop playing.Overall, the atmosphere helps the immerision, so it had everything to be one of those games you never forget.But...There are 3 things that were VERY annoying to me:1. "Combat": The demons that appear once in a while and can actually kill you, forcing you to restart from the last checkpoint were simply unecessary. It is not a challenge, hiding and waitng for the right time to kill them is just an annoyance. They're also not scary at all. They just kill the tension when they appear as you are exploring somewhere, finding clues, wondering what the hell is going on, or just admiring the nice graphics. They kill the atmosphere. If at least the encounters were better developed, with real stealth strategy, it could be cool. But no, it just makes you wonder if continuing playing is worth the trouble.2. Collections: It is nice to search for hidden items, that help you picture the background story of the characters, and understand the history of the city (which is very cool, made me think about visiting it someday). But there are just too many, some of them really hard to find (specially when the cursor has to be at a very specific position to collect it), and each one adds almost nothing to the story. The fragments are just too small, and that makes you lose interest in finding them after a while. Some of them are directly connected to the story, and can hint you at what is really going on (it is very easy to figure out the whole mystery if you pay attention), but after some time you just say "nevermind, let's continue with the story", and forget about them.3. "The most relevant Clue": This made me stop playing the game after the first minutes of gameplay. (But of course, after a while I gave it another shot and finished it). There are times during an investigation that you have to select the most relevant clue you found at that place to continue, or link an older clue to new developments. The concept is very nice, but it doesn't work. You can't think logically to find out which is the correct one. You have to wonder what the writers had in mind when they created that part. Sometimes it just doesn't make sense (and apparently you have infinite tries, so what's the point, anyway?) I'll just give an example: At the beggining, there is a part where you have to select which information in a cop's notes is the most important one. I selected the one that to me was obviously the most intriguing detail, and any cop in the world would immediately investigate that. But no, the "correct" answer was somthing obvious, with nothing really interesting about it. After some minutes, guess what happens? Yes, Ronan (the main character) decides to investigate that thing that the game wanted you to think was not relevant at all.Anyway, even with these flaws, I loved the game, and definitely recommend it to everyone who likes mysteries, and investigative games in general. It is worth it.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Lovechild of LA Noire and a horror suspense story of your choice.  Worth the money, all 12 hours of it - you don't get to run half an hour in one direction and then half an hour back to complete the quest (repeatedly) to bloat the gaming times. The game is insanely condensed into an amazing story you want to learn, combined with puzzles you will actually want to solve, combined with learning skills you will actually use, combined with enemies you will actually want to eliminate (or avoid, if that's your fancy).  Supernatural detective noire horror story - what can be better? Oh yeah, and the handsome tattooed chain-smoking detective in a fedora and shoulder holster, pity he is - well - dead. The replayability of the game is pretty low, once you know whodunnit, there is only getting back to get the collectibles you haven't found the first itme. Or watch the cutscenes and go all 'aha! how didn't i notice that before?!'. Or just trail behind the handsome tattooed chain-smoking detective in a fedora and shoulder holster (unfortunately dead) and admire the view :]No glitches, no crashes, no real need for the manual save system, though the lack of it might irritate some players. Overall extremely smooth gameplay with plot that is solid all over. I'd buy it on full price, it's that good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												While I enjoyed the game enough to actually finish it, the overall experience felt very unpolished.What I Liked:-Lovable Characters: I liked all the characters. The voice acting was really great, and I cared about Ronan and Joy; a lot of fun and interesting interactions between the two of them.-A completionist's dream: All sorts of stuff to collect, and fun little stories to unlock if you're into that sort of thing.-Interesting Storyline: The story was surprisingly original, outside of a few painfully predictable points. Original or not, it was interesting and kept my playing.What I Hated:-Sloppy Game Mechanics: Game mechanics were a mess. Especially the dialogue options. You enter a cutscene for each dialogue choice, and the break is very obvious. Once the cutscene ends, there's another obvious break, and you get to choose another dialogue option. It was strange and killed the immersion.-Investigations: Basically a hidden objects game. Walk around, find anything and everything it actually lets you examine until it says you've found all the clues. Then guess which one is relative to the current case. Easy and oh-so boring.-Felt Unfinished: A lot of the powers were pretty useless save for one or two very rare, very unique moments where the game practically screams at you: USE THIS POWER! Teleportation could've been really cool, but there's only a few spots it actually comes in handy, and even then it's super clunky and annoying. A lot of useless hiding spots you'll never use, no matter what, never ever. They're just there for the aesthetics, I guess? Just looked messy to me. And while the start of the game seems to promise a lot of interesting side investigations -- helping to put spirits to rest -- there are very few to actually be found as the game progresses, at least, that I could find.-Enemies: Demons. . .could've been scary, but instead they're just annoying. They walk (float?) a predetermined route. You do the exact same thing to kill them (quick time event). There's no real combat in the game, or even a sense of urgency. You just hide, quick-time kill an enemy when he turns his back on you, repeat.-Cats: O. . .M. . .G Fun at first, but then, seriously, WHY is the SAME black cat everywhere in Salem? You know what, I think that friggin cat might be the killer! Shows up in the most convenient places, always there when I need it. . .what's it playing at? Or maybe it's different cats, all brothers and sisters. . .with absolutely no way to tell them apart. . .? Maybe? And seriously, what is the point of pressing "Q" to "Meow"?I enjoyed the game, it was fun in its own ways. Mostly it was a story that was nice to experience. But MURDERED: Soul Suspect is NOT a $50 game. Maybe $20. So no, can't recommend it.

												This game is quite unusual in comparison to the others, and that's the main point of its success. The options are unusual: you can possess, influence on smbd, read the mind and execute the demons. You walk through the game as a ghost, and the main objective is to solve your murder. Despite of this, you are also able to solve the other victim's murders while revealing the hidden items. After you found all the clues on a particular problem, the game proceeds with the next video part that tells you smth. more about your own. AND THAT'S ALL. Nothing more. It becomes boring, especially for those who do not like repetitive cycles. There is nothing scary in the game, it just makes you bored. My advice is: buy this game only if you like what I described above or if you are reach enough to spent around $60 to explore HQ video and the graphics and to satisfy your curiosity.

												Understand beforehand that Murdered: Soul Suspect is a cinematic puzzle adventure game with all the trappings you expect from such. I felt it was reminiscent of Dreamfall and Indigo Prophecy. Its also not REALLY a detective game you just mouse around and collect clues then piece them together to complete the "puzzle" to further your investigation. Like an advenure game really. Overall I enjoyed it, the game is visually stunning, the sound and voice acting is top notch. What really blew me away was how detailed and expressive the characters faces were. The only problem is this is $50 for a puzzle adventure game! Since this is a Square title though you can expect the price to drop drastically and if it cost half as much and you like the genre I would say pick this game up for sure.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												A pretty good whodunit detective game. Most investigations can be beat by brute force, but that nets you overall less points. The games best selling point is it's creepy atmosphere and the offer of playing as a ghost and playing as a ghost is quite frankly a lot of fun. I dare you to not veer around trashcans and aim for doorways in the first few hours when you could infact just pass through the wall or something instead.You use abilities such as possession, mind reading, memory tracing and teleportation to accomplish your goals.The games weak parts is it's lenght, it's on the short side. And the enemies scattered around, quite frankly i feel that the game would have been better without enemies at all and just more detectiving. Every enemy encounter goes like this: You are startled by a loud scream, you hide nearby, wait for them to turn their back and then kill them with a QTE. It's just a hassle, not scary, not fun and they are in the way. Thankfully there aren't many enemies at all in the game.All in all i really recommend Murdered: Soul Suspect if you want to think a bit for yourself, fantasize about the beyond, are a bit of a history buff, are into creepy atmospheres or ghosts, just looking for a mystery or all of the above. A very pleasant surprise.

												A very great game if you like detective stories, supernatural themes, and a wicked twist. Really good gameplay for people who like story driven games, though not much in the action department. If you like to explore everything, you might beat the game in 10 hours and uncover the many mini-stories within the game. I.E. If they added some downloadable content, maybe telling of other cases and stories, it might be worth a full priced game of 50-60. Don't think on this having co-op or multiplayer, this is for the lone players.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Back hand clapping...I had to give up playing this today after the 30th time of trying to execute the same demon and forgetting that (unlike any other game) you have to hold the button down. For me this game is an endless cycle of: sneak up behind demon, press execute button, run away because "I" let them go (i.e. forgot to hold the button)...No option...Why for the love of god did they not include an auto hold on execute option in controls?! This awful command system is a game ruiner and all the hard work put into this game amounts to nothing because of it. It's very sad because I was enjoying the game. I have no problem sneaking up behind the demons but then in the heat of the moment I forget that it has a weirdly unique and bizarrely abnormal control system that has never been used in any other game. 3rd Party software needed?The only way I could play this was if I used a program like xpadder to make the button toggle or hold for a time, but having to use 3rd party software to overcome a badly thought out and poorly implemented control system is ridiculous (for a 3rd person game, not a flight sim).No patch?If they make a patch I for this I might play it but since having an unplayable game taking up lots of space on my hdd is a stupid idea,  I will be uninstalling it and wont know if there is a patch because I am not going to bother checking (in much the same way they didn't bother putting an alternative to their useless command system).

												A fantastic game that is more about puzzles and story than action elements. Fantastic characters, a solid story, and a couple surprises along the way make for a game that I would want to see a series of - even if it uses different characters every time, or different locales. For example, one set in New Orleans would be fantastic, considering its roots in the arcane.Nothing is ever perfect, though: there is the occasional graphical glitch that can make it hard to figure out what you've got to do next, and it really felt too short. This could have kept going without feeling like it was being padded - the end came up pretty fast, but at least it warns you so you can go back and collectible hunt. (And that's worth it, especially for the ghost stories.)If you want to get involved in a story, enjoy some solid voice acting, and have a little dash of creepy - you'll love this game.

												Murdered: Soul SuspectIn Murdered: Soul Suspect you play the role of a deceased police officer who is murdered by the mysterious serial killer The Bell Killer it's now up to you as a ghost and a couple of other characters to catch this murderer and bring him to justice so that you can finish your part in this life and be with your beloved wife.Pros-Interesting and great narrative-Amazing voice acting-Great graphics-Lots of collectibles-Different settingCons-Shallow Gameplay (fight off demons by sneaking behind and investigations)-Not enough NPC models so you can find 2 or 3 of the same kind in the same area-Not enough replayability once you know what happens there's no reason for a second playthrough-very short wish it was longer finished in one sittingIn the end Murdered: Soul Suspect is a fun detective ghost story with some great voice acting a strong narrative being the strongest points of the game, so if you want a game based on the gameplay then this is not for you but for those of you willing to purchase the game then this is very good however I would recommend you buy this on sale or from any other means I got this through the Square Enix Humble Bundle 2 which is great!Murdered: Soul Suspect7/10

												As a 6 hour experience for about 5 bucks, Murdered tells an ok story. As a game though it falls down in almost all departments. Boring and repetitive stealth sections make up the only actual gameplay part of the experience. The rest of it is simply walking around rooms to find clues and push the story forward, in an almost visual novel sort of experience. While a fan of these kinds of games myself, such as the Ace Attorney series, I dont think this is what Murdered was trying to do, and instead it fails at being a good action/mystery game or a good visual novel too.In conclusion I can't really recommend the title, as it does nothing particularly interesting with its unique premise, sadly turning a very intriguing concept into a run of the mill point and click adventure style murder mystery without a satisfying story to hold it up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural crime thriller about Ronan, a man with a criminal history who became a detective then found himself a victim of the bell killer when following a lead in the case. The game has a sense of uniqueness that has to be appreciated in just its premise. The character is full of quirks and remarks throughout the game as well as some of the other characters. This is all delivered rather nicely in it voice acting which is very solidly done. The controls are very simple and straightforward nothing to complicate things which lends itself well to the games puzzle-esque ways. Combat doest really exist out side of exorcising demons which is mostly optional bit is always pulled of by one of the movement (WASD) keys and right or left mouse button click so it feels a bit gimicky and like its trying to be pattern like but feels out of place in some way, at least for me. The plot and story are the absolute best  part in this game by far and with quite a few twists and turns that leave you scratching your head at who is behind it all then promptly smacking your ideas of the suspect. The only thing I feel they could have done better is making me feel more emotionally invested in some of the character which would have lent itself well in other aspects of the game in terms of impact. There are side things that can be done BUT due to auto save ONLY with no manual save control of your own if you want to colllect and/or solve all side things do so before reaching the end of the game otherwise that has to be done in a new game. Despite being a rather small and short game Murdered: Soul Suspect still deserves a try and it has its handful of problems but any I've run into felt very minor to the point it felt like might be me being picky so I say give this a go as it deserves a little more attention and love.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I would only recommend this shoddy excuse for a game during a sale. The game treats you like you are the world's biggest idiot the whole game. Look around a crime scene pick out the most important detail. If you get it wrong the first time it doesn't matter because there isn't an apparent penalty for being wrong other than a red flash and something along the lines of ''No. I need to find something that would actually help me figure this out. I'm a moron for thinking this could help." It literally feels like an indy game with the gameplay of a flash game but with the graphics of a good game... speaking of graphics... hope you dont have a♥♥♥♥♥♥computer like me, or else you are going to wait 2 minutes for every cinematic to load on the lowest quality setting... Do you know how many cinematics this game had? Alot. Literally the only two reasons I kept playing it to the end was because I spent 30 bucks on it like an idiot and because I kind of wanted to watch the story. It sucks that this writing staff made such a great story, but the people who decided on game mechanics were like... this game is going to be played by 5 year olds right? I mean Jesus Christ! It never gets any harder than the begining. And just when something different happens: I won't spoil what it is, you realize that its just a crappy last minute add in to the... movie... im just gonna call it a playable movie... thats what it is. So I guess if you like movies, murder mysteries, have a good computer, and don't mind being treated with the intellegence of a newborn lemur then this game is for you. Otherwise... please buy it on a sale and don't make the same mistake i did.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Worth a play if you can get it on sale. Soul Suspect is a detective adventure game. Calling it a horror game does a dis-service to actual horror games so I'll just say it has a dark atmosphere. The story is kinda mediocre, somewhat predictabe and relatively short (I finished it in 8 hours, while doing a pretty good amount of exploring). The controls are kinda sticky at times.  Some interacions should be based on proximity instead of the current system of it being based on where the camera is centered. There is very little character progression in regards to powers and the powers are a tad lame. 'Battles' in this game consist of sneaking up on enemies to trigger a QTE to defeat them. If you are spotted by them or fail the QTE, you're forced to run and hide until the enemy gives up at which point you can try again. There is only one enemy type in the entire game, save for the 'final boss.' The crime scene system (not sure what it's officially called) is interesting but will often penalize you for not being able to answer their vaguely asked question in the exact way they want you to. Not sure if this is a localization thing or someting else. Some of the clues are absurd to be called 'clues'  and I wa somestimes annoyed that I had to click on it to make the observation into a 'clue.' Also, as mentioned about the controls, because the camera has to be centered on the item for prompts to show up, I would often miss clues because a prompt didn't pop up -- this would just add unnecessary time as I'd be searching for that last clue and then realize that I hadn't properly centered the camera on the item for the prompt to come up.I got this during a recent sale for under $10 and I think that's a fair price for the game. It wasn't spectacular but was interesting enough to keep me occupied. Frankly, games like this should not be released at full console retail price when the quality of the product doesn't warrant so.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Remember The Darkness? This game plays a little bit like that, with the 'other world on top of this world' vibe... Except that Ronan is a WAY more likable and funny guy than Jackie, who - if Im going to be generous - had the personality of a piece of sopping wet cardboard. (Yes I've read the comics. I stand by my statement.)Gameplay can get a little clunky, but you arent asked to do action sequences more than a few times, so mostly it's just atmosphere. Said atmosphere can, at times, get a little repetative, but it did manage to maintain a pacing of steadily getting creepier and creepier. The tense string instruments make you want to turn around and slap the musicians for scaring you like a little girl. Play at night with the lights off for maximum effect, obviously.Power through the story if you get tired of the levels; they dont take long. The story itself had a few 'whodunit' twists and a few others you can see a mile out, but still. It's not terrible, and history nerds get a nice stroll through Salem that doesnt overwhelm people who dont give a rat's behind about what happened in 1800-and-who-cares.Conclusion: A nice timekiller that wont take up more than a day of dedicated play or a few days of off and on. WARNING: The menu in here IS glitchy as all heck, so stay out of it as often as you can.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												This game is more like "L.A. Noire" than anything else, and I really enjoyed it. Then again, I enjoy games with decent stories more than a lot of people seem to do, and the story for "Murdered: Soul Suspect" had enough twists and kept my intrigue enough to see it the whole way through without too many regrets. There was potential for it to be a "horror" game (which I hate), but fortunately any scares were more in the environment and feeling of the game than through outright scares.  Some people seem to put more value on time spent, so for those kind of people this game at $30 (as I write this) might not be of value. But if you enjoyed "L.A. Noire", this game is at least worth getting on a Steam sale.There are enough other reviews (should this one ever be read by anyone) that I'm going to spare yet another description of the story and get to what I think are the pluses and minuses of the game.Pluses:+ Non-linear with respect to being able to visit previous locations+ Intriguing story placed in Salem, MA and linked to the historic witch trials+ Dark, brooding atmosphere without necessarily crossing the line into "horror"+ Good acting and voice work+ No jump scares (for the most part)+ Roughly 8-10 hour play time doesn't require too much commitment+ No achievement mandating that all of the mysteries are solved PEFECTLY (unlike "L.A. Noire")+ Side quests while not required provided some well-written ghost stories+ Some interesting plot twistsMinuses:- Demons felt like they were added for pointless stealth/action gameplay- Too many collectibles for a game of this size- No way to track how many collectibles still remain in a particular location- End sequence stops somewhat abruptlyIf you can put up with the pointless demons, which don't show up very often anyway, and you can deal with not having to find *every* collectible, you'll probably find this game worthwhile, although the $30 price tag (as of writing) might be a bit too much for some people, based on the returns. This is definitely worth picking up on a Steam sale, though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												Firstly, the game has a decent story, cool intro and an interesting protagonist. It's like playing through a murder mystery with occasional collection quests and a nicely evolving understanding of your character. That said, the mystery could have been better fleshed out. The culprit was simply not on my radar until nearly the end, which made for a surprising, but unfulfilling twist ending.The game clearly suffers by being ported from console to PC. The controls are unintuitive and sometimes downright boggling for PC+Mouse, but I'm sure for a console controller they would make sense.The "combat" is utterly unnecessary and serves only to delay parts of the game for no benefit to the story or character development. There was also an unusual amount of walking back and forth for no real reason. It's not an Open World, you can only go from one scene to another, so why make the player walk through the same parts of town X times?The Clue-finding and Conclusion-Drawing mechanics were very railroaded and often left me wondering just how slow the protagonist must be, to take so long to figure it out. Being told you had found 6 of 8 clues in an area led to boring scavenger hunts, rather than trying to form conclusions based on what you'd already found, which could have lead to more interesting gameplay.It's tough to write a "no" review, but my internal rating of 5/10 just doesn't justify recommending this game.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												I guess this is that game: No matter how many negative reviews or hatespeech it received on forums, magazines and websites, I was rather captivated by it. And I still cannot quite put my finger on why... many reasons I think.  Even though I absolutely dispise pixel hunting (hi Arkham City!) I found myself drawn into the world of the protagonist through brilliant voice (and mocap) acting, solid graphics and a demanding story line with a twist at the end that blew my mind. While it is certainly true that the NPC's are the most boring to ever feature in a AAA title, the main characters feel suprisingly human in this stunning demonstration of how much oomph is still left in the Unreal Engine. Even on fairly modest PC setup, the game should look good. I know I clicked 'Yes' in the section that asks if this game should be recommended, but I can at least admit it will not be everyone's cup of tea. You NEVER actually touch a gun in this game, but to me that is part of the charm. It is definitely clear that the developers made an effort to do something different, even if they failed somewhat obviously to do so. If you are looking to take a brake from flinging tons of lead at enemies and you are willing to overlook a few glaring oversights of a development studio that obviously feared missing their release date, buy it. Or put it on your wishlist for that day you feel you need to take a break from mainstream gaming.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Murdered:Soul Suspect is a supernatural thriller kinda like Ghost Whisperer,Medium or Deadbeat.The game focuses on the story and the plot twist adds to a great ending.The characters are well done and you can discover their stories through notes.Also,the voice acting was good.You can possess a cat and even "meow"  which ,let's be honest, is everybody's dream.The background characters are interesting(from psycho butcher to jealous girlfriend) and you can even help some of the ghosts as a side mission.The dialogue was funny most of the time and straight to the point.Unfortunately,the controls seemed to be made especially for console so it didn't quite adjust to PC keyboard.Another con was the length of the game.I was expecting more gameplay.After you finish the game you can't go back and explore.Speaking of exploration,it was limited by walking from point A to B.You can only roam between those points and it felt like Salem was not really a city but a place with a few locations.In conclusion, meow out of 10.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Interesting story.  It is like reading a book.  A bit short as I finished it in one afternoon.  No surprise clues at the end, you can figure out the mystery as the story progresses (which is a good thing).  I had guessed a few of the plot aspects before they happened, but I don't find that a negative.  It happens.The game concentrated on the story (which I liked) rather than combat with some story thrown in.  This may not appeal to some.The game is short.There were bad parts.  It was clear that the end was thrown together.  Not that the story didn't complete.  That was fine, but there were four major broken game development commandments.  Two appear right at the end.1.  You cannot save the game.  Ever.  It is a port to PC from a console.  There are automatic progress points.  The good thing is they do seem to happen often.2.  Flash sequences.  Some people like them, I don't.3.  Repeated cutscene (happens at end) when you fail (which will happen).  You can skip it after it starts, but forcing one to even go into it is bad.4.  Sudden timed sequence.  There is exactly one (two parts of one timed sequence) and none of the rest of the game has one.  It is short (the timed sequence), too. I'd recommend the game if you like to play a short story.  This is not a combat centered game.  It is a mystery and in that aspect it was fun to figure out the mystery.  Get it on sale.  Not worth a normal 50-60 dollar price tag.I'd like to see more products like this rather than the overdone shooters and what not, so I realise my suggestion to get it on sale isn't going to encourage more such development.I'm going to give it a yes but read the caveats in this article.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed this game. I thought it was fun and the story was compelling enough to make me want to finish it. Speaking of the story, however, this main character is easily the dumbest person I have ever encountered in my life, let alone the fact that he's a detective. Ronan didn't die because he was hunting down a murderer, he died because the writers couldn't come up with a good enough excuse for supposedly-respectable police officers to allow this kind of stupidity to act freely in their police department. So they killed him off so that no cops would have to actually deal with how utterly moronic he is. I figured out the story about two and a half hours into the game, and i played a good 5 or 6 hours total to beat it. All along the way, Ronan kept going "Huh, I wonder what this means" when the meaning is so blatantly obvious that a 7-year-old could figure it out, given that this 7-year-old had the utmost basic knowledge on the historical significance of Salem. There was genuinely only one part of this story that surprised me, and even then, it wasn't that impactful because of how upset I was at Ronan for his 6  straight hours of nonstop idiocracy. What really emphasized his stupidity, and I personally find this thoroughly ironic, was when he finally ended up talking with Baxter. Ronan spent the entirety of the game talking about how stupid Baxter is, and when it came down to them actually working together, Ronan had gotten to literally the EXACT same place as Baxter in their search for the killer. Also, overall, Ronan's facial expressions were a huge disconnect. You could tell it was supposed to be a dramatic moment, and Ronan still looked like the infant that I think he really is. Except if that infant were 5'10", had a stubble, and wore a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fedora. Mechanics-wise, it was lacking, but not in such a way that made it hard. Just somewhat tedious. At one point where Ronan should be hauling♥♥♥♥♥across all of Salem, he's instead jogging briskly, taking detours because of how confusing the map is. The teleport mechanic comes in handy, I guess, but honestly it would be so much better if it were just a set distance that you could sorta spam to move faster, instead of having to hold left click, wait for it to charge, and let go, only to travel a repeatedly disappointing distance. Trying to get from the musem to the church was honestly one of the worst sequences for this. I wanted to care about trying to get to the church as fast as I possibly could, but all Ronan could care about was the brunch he was gonna go have with his dead wife after this was all over, resulting in me wanting to start running down my street so that one of us could feel like they were attempting to go quickly towards anything.tl;drstory was predictable, Ronan is a moron, and the controls are meh. 14/10 would Julia again.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												TL:DR - 12hr run time if you hunt for collectables. Average plot, decent but not groundbreaking and ultimately predictable. Decent mechanics and character abilities. Reasonably well written characters. All of this is hindered and spoiled by the frustrating need to kill demons when the kill sequence is buggy as hell and only serves to slow the game down and annoy you. Still worth playing, but be prepared to be thoroughly annoyed for about a quarter of the game.Overall it's got a decent plot, decent set design, interesting game mechanics. The Investigation side of things is pretty typical, doesn't stretch very far from the conventions of the genre but does involve a few quirks to give it it's own identity (e.g. you can uncover clues and information through possessing people and manipulating them into giving up information).The plot is, for the most part, pretty predictable. For example, *minor spoiler, no specific details*,  the story centres on the witch trails of salem, which becomes pretty obvious about halfway through when a flashback to one of the murders is shown. After that, it's pretty clear that the overarching motive is to do with killing witches. This wouldn't be nearly as obvious to the player if the game was set somewhere OTHER THAN SALEM, which is famous for KILLING WITCHES. As soon as strange symbols and similar things get mentioned, the connection is almost instinctive .The only real twists and turns occur right at the end and even then don't do much to flip the story on it's head, they just make the overall story a little more original. Around halfway through the story, a lot of people will figure out the second half of the plot pretty quickly and then will just have to play through the game and wait for confirmation of what is sadly quite obvious.All that aside, the biggest detractor from the game is the BLOODY DEMONS. A few sections of the game require you to get your stealth hat on and exorcise demons from behind by distracting them, triggering a quicktime event, and hoping that the stars and planets are correctly aligned when you press the buttons, because the system is buggy as hell. For starters, this style of gameplay is totally unecessary and poorly implemented. There's absolutely no flow to it and it just seems like something the developers put in to make the game last a little longer and make it more exciting/different (which it does the exact opposite of). For a dectective game, it really kills the immersion and slows the pace right down. It's incredibly frustrating when all you want to do is get on with the investigation.Basically, if you're drawn to this game and like detective games, go ahead and play it. It's pretty fun and pretty clever at times. Just don't expect to be blown away by the story, although it has some pretty good moments. And definately expect to get extremely fed up with BLOODY DEMONS.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Definately a breath of fresh air amongst the thousands of First and Third Person Shooters out there.The mystery is woven a little thick in places but it's definately enjoyable to unravel it piece by piece.The characters, what little there is of them, are competently written and voice acted and the music does it's best to amplify the creepy mood of it all.The game does suffer however from forced  "stealth" elements that do nothing but pad out the game's relatively short running time (FOUR HOURS).And at the end Murdered Soul Suspect is a point'n'click mystery game, without any pointing, without any clicking and a mystery that effectively solves itself - But that doesn't mean it's bad.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I was expecting either a run of the mill horror game or a glorified walking simulator. I couldn't have been more wrong. 1) Horror: I decided to play this right after Outlast because I was in that type of mood. Soul Suspect still managed to get my heart rate up and creep me out in a few spots. 2) Walking SImulator: I think the only one I ever played was Gone Home. It was a great story, it was kind of creepy but it was so human at the same time. Sure there are ghosts and demons and witches, but the story is about people. You really get to learn about the people by just walking around and clicking on things.3) Police Procedural: The only other ones that come to mind are the CSI games and LA Noir, none of which I've played. Althought the "puzzles" if you want to call them that were simple, they at least made it feel like I was involved in hashing out the next step.My only gripe is that some of the collectables were in places I'd have never looked had I not eventually given up and looked them up. I'm not a fan of these things though and they are totally optional so it doesn't really efffect the game unless you want it to.I've been playing video games since the early 80s and I've been using steam since the Orange Box was bundled with video cards. Two things I hardly ever do are complete a game 100% and write a review. I've now done both for this game.

Posted: August 27, 2015
												This game is short and not very challenging. 99% of the investigation puzzles I got right on the first try. The "combat" is slow and not particularly rewarding, and you only fight one enemy type throughout the entire game. A keen mind will recognize the primary villain immediately, but there are some creative twists that get thrown into the mix and spice up the story a bit. As a game, it's subpar, a step above a narrative journey. Not even the backstories were particularly interesting. However what I really liked about the game was its take on the spirit world, spirit powers, and the way spirits interact with the mortal world. It is a very unique theme and approach, and would have made a very exciting game if they had tried a little harder.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												I'm not gonna pretend that I wasn't blown away by this game. I was. The whole time I played it, I was just about ready to♥♥♥♥♥♥myself. The main character is fantastic. His life story is fantastic. And the story left me on the edge of my seat. The graphics were awesome, particularly the supernatural elements. The way past and present structures were mashed together was just beyong cool. The ending when all the pieces of this odd, disjointed plot come together left me face down on my bed for about an hour.Now all that being said...this game  could be REALLY annoying. The main challenge I had was figuring out how to sneak past enemies, and even that was rarely more than thirty seconds of looking around. There is little true "detective work", and a lot of "stare at the ground until you see a clue". And unfortunately, that's basicallt all the game consists of. Going to a new crime scene and staring at the floor until you get a cut scene. At least the floor was very pretty most of the time?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												*Spoilers discussed in review*I can't decide if the story of this game did or did not make up for things I disliked. I enjoyed the side stories and as someone who likes searching every nook and cranny of a world I enjoyed hunting for the extra pieces of evidence and items to find the stories. Sometimes it was frustrating having to be standing right next to something for it to have the option to interact with it but most of the time it was solid.....except once where my game glitched and I had to reload before it would let me interact with anything again. I was also a little annoyed that we couldn't revisit investigations. Again being someone who likes to be thorough, when I noticed I'd accidentally missed a clue out of an investigation you can imagine who annoying that stain on the record was when I realised I couldn't revisit it to find the clue I'd missed. Could not have some "Recall Investigation" feature been added? My main gripe about the game was the combat system against the enemies. Using a mouse and keyboard, I really disliked how they used the wasd keys and a left or right button click to dispence of enemies. If I was in a panic, I would have to wait around for ages to go through the malarky of it again hoping I don't miss-click or press the wrong key again. I didn't feel like it was a very rewarding system in that respect and just frustrated me more than anything. The enemies were just an annoyance rather than a "Alright! Lets deal with these evil demons!" Little disappointed with the ending. I feel like you found out only half of the story...the twist of who the killer was, I thought, was very interesting but they didn't go into it enough at the last minute. I felt through the whole game we didn't have a clue who the killer was and at the end they just went "Hey lets have this person". I don't even think I understand why the killer did it. I understand she was murdered for accusing witchcraft...but why had she accused them in the first place? What was her reason for that? The bell didn't really have much significance either. I just feel a bit underwhelmed. I also never appreciate a game which doesn't allow you to skip the credits!Overall, I am glad I played the game (even though it probably doesn't sound like it!) but it was a little....meh. I don't think I'll be playing it again in a hurry to find things I missed.

												Murdered: Soul Suspect shows a lot of promise, but falls painfully short of fulfilling it. In its gameplay close more to point and click adventure that to modern action games, relying mainly on case solving by finding needed items in the enviroment and finding out the proper links between them. Beside that its mostly going from A to B and collecting collectibles on the way. So in overall, even if it is not something revolutionary or even really great, it is still fun at some points and the atmosphere is really good. If you can get a hold of it at a discount, it's still worth a buck or two.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												I just played it from start to finish in one sitting.  The first time I tried it (when it first came out), I didn't really get into it.  After 10-15 minutes, long enough to get out of the first "scene," the game had me hooked.  I thought it was going to be a gimmick, but this game made playing as a ghost feel extremely unique and interesting, all the way through the end.  I worried, in the middle, that the plot was being too easy to figure out.  Revelations in the latter part of the game, however, just got more and more exciting - I had no idea what was coming.  The story was well written, enjoyable, immersive, and refreshingly different.I highly recommend this game.  I wish I hadn't waited so long to give it a full effort.  I now see why so many articles were written about it when it first came out, and I'm sad it isn't as well known as it deserves to be.  It isn't just another gimmick in a game.  It is deep and powerful, and I am so glad I played it.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												I loved this game. That is, *after* I disabled the awareness of the demons in the .ini file. I have to admit, had I been stuck with the demons, I would have returned the game. I like true adventure games - no dying and being attacked. I like stress-free escapism, thanks.I also had an issue with a bug in the interface whilst playing with my mouse and keyboard (PC). The interface, accessed by the tab key, kept locking up when viewing the investigation 'notes' and deductions. I had to switch to a game controller, which fixed the problem. After I discovered those fixes, I was able to play the game without any problems. I was intrigued by the mystery of who the killer was, the novelty of playing as a ghost trying to finish old business, and finally, having fun finding all the little items in the game. I played this over and over, just to re-experience the characters and the story. The story tends to be linear, action folks won't find anything remotely interesting, and old adventure gamers like me won't like the demons, but, in the end, the game was extremely enjoyable.

I didn't run into any technical problems, and looking back at the reviews, I think they're a lot harsher than the game deserved. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												I'm going to not recommend this game, primarily because it is just too short and has too many small issues with it; however, I do still think this is worth a play through.In Murdered: Soul Suspect, you play Ronin; a not-so-cleverly named man who is dead and searching for his killer. Through the game, you will help some random ghosts in what is I think some of the most interesting gameplay, and run around in crime scenes solving hide-and-seek puzzle games. The major flaw in this game comes with the very short play time and annoying time wasting monster encounters.Throughout the game you will have encounters with "daemons" who are your typical Metal Gear style pathed guards; they can only be killed from behind with a simple QTE and are more of a nusanse than actually being a challenge. By the end of the game, I went into the config and made it so they just didn't see me so I wouldn't have to fight them. It's not that fighting daemons is hard, it's just annoying and by the end of the game if you don't know where the escape rooms are you can just die if you screw up.The final encounter is lame and very confusing, I had to look up the solution. Again, like the daemons, this wasn't because it was hard, it was because the prompt wasn't clear on what I should do.The story has some decent writing in small parts. The noir monologue at the entrance to each game section is a neat touch. The two main characters are interesting, and there seems to be a decent about of background lore on Ronin (the PC). The collectables are interesting as they expand on the murder case and also include background about Salem (the town in which the game takes place). I have no idea if any of the lore is true, but it is nice they put it in. The hidden collectables are unique as they are just ghost/horror stories that have no connection to the main plot - its nice.Over all I think the game is worth a play through if you can pick it up for under $10. There is enough there to keep you entertained for an evening and if you like ghost stories than you should have a good time.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Overall a good game. I feel the story was concrete and actually pretty enjoyable, and the gameplay kinda blends a mix of detective activity and stealth. The ghost stories that you can unlock through the game by discovering their respective artifacts are also pretty good for adding some more flavour to the history of Salem, although it can be sometimes frustrating looking through every nook and cranny to find a hiding artifact. But hey, if you enjoy that sort of stuff, there's loads of it in this game. One slightly disappointing factor of the game is that there isn't really an option you can use to manually save the game; it works by checkpoints. So if you end your game in between checkpoints, you'll be forced to start again from the last autosave. However, the game seems to preserve anything you unlock or discover, regardless of the inconvenient autosaves.

												For some reason I thought this game was going to be pretty lame, and I was delighted to be proven wrong. This is basically Law and Order: Spectral Victims Unit. You are a ghost cop trying to solve not only your own murder, but several others as well as preventing further murders from taking place. A large portion of the game is just finding clues mixed in with the occasional stealth-kill arena when demons start showing up. Overall, I think if you're a fan of slower paced detective stories you'll find this game to be worth your time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Remember when Mirror's Edge came out and everyone got all excited that THIS was a new and exciting concept that, despite the clunky execution, really deserved to be remade? And then at E3 they announced it would be? Yeah... Well, don't ever say history never repeats.If you drag yourself, embittered and complaining, to the end of this game, and watch the credits roll-by (unskippable credits, too -- WHO still does that?!), it's informative, I think, about what's wrong with this game. The first name listed is the Story and Creative Director, which is fair enough, followed by aaaaaaaaaall the Square Enix producers, the Marketing directors, then their sales managers, analysts and coordinators, the interactive marketing senior manager, the traffic manager, the senior counsel, VP of HR, HR administrator, the network engineer, desktop support, senior manager officer administration, the senior accountant, the credit manager, and a whooooooole host of other Square Enix people before you finally get to the... Square Enix localisation managers, producers, teams, coordinators, brand design managers, production assistants, and then all of those for each office, the marketing in each country, the community managers, the localisation testers, functionality testers ... etc ...What's my point? There's about 300 names (unskippable, remember) before you get to a single programmer. And therein this game's primary problem.Early on in the game, in your rush to solve the first puzzle, you can seemingly run ahead of the game, find too many clues, and the game will effectively lock and you won't be able to progress. A check online will detail the precise order of clues to find to get past that section, but by that stage, you're pretty much over it. And this is sadly not an isolated incident. This game is riddled with problems: there are walkways you can't walk over the one-inch step on, others you cannot walk down, priests that walk through walls preventing your continuing the mission, cats walking up ramps that seem to freeze in a "I'm jumping down" pose, ...Yet, at the core of it, this is a really good game, and if there were more QA people and fewer marketing people involved, it could have been a really great game. In investigating your own murder, you play ethereal detective, run around possessing people to help solve your murder at the hands of a seemingly unstoppable serial killer. You get to hear peoples' thoughts, read their notes, look into their lives, or even influence their thinking.Expanded, some graded difficulty and substantially polished, this could be a real bombshell of new IP. But I am guessing SE didn't have the faith, cash or the willpower to purge the apparent stadium full of executives, producers, directors, managers and marketing people in favour of actual QA folk and programmers.tl;dr? Good idea, poor execution.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												*Spoilers discussed in review*I can't decide if the story of this game did or did not make up for things I disliked. I enjoyed the side stories and as someone who likes searching every nook and cranny of a world I enjoyed hunting for the extra pieces of evidence and items to find the stories. Sometimes it was frustrating having to be standing right next to something for it to have the option to interact with it but most of the time it was solid.....except once where my game glitched and I had to reload before it would let me interact with anything again. I was also a little annoyed that we couldn't revisit investigations. Again being someone who likes to be thorough, when I noticed I'd accidentally missed a clue out of an investigation you can imagine who annoying that stain on the record was when I realised I couldn't revisit it to find the clue I'd missed. Could not have some "Recall Investigation" feature been added? My main gripe about the game was the combat system against the enemies. Using a mouse and keyboard, I really disliked how they used the wasd keys and a left or right button click to dispence of enemies. If I was in a panic, I would have to wait around for ages to go through the malarky of it again hoping I don't miss-click or press the wrong key again. I didn't feel like it was a very rewarding system in that respect and just frustrated me more than anything. The enemies were just an annoyance rather than a "Alright! Lets deal with these evil demons!" Little disappointed with the ending. I feel like you found out only half of the story...the twist of who the killer was, I thought, was very interesting but they didn't go into it enough at the last minute. I felt through the whole game we didn't have a clue who the killer was and at the end they just went "Hey lets have this person". I don't even think I understand why the killer did it. I understand she was murdered for accusing witchcraft...but why had she accused them in the first place? What was her reason for that? The bell didn't really have much significance either. I just feel a bit underwhelmed. I also never appreciate a game which doesn't allow you to skip the credits!Overall, I am glad I played the game (even though it probably doesn't sound like it!) but it was a little....meh. I don't think I'll be playing it again in a hurry to find things I missed.
