content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												TL:DR - 12hr run time if you hunt for collectables. Average plot, decent but not groundbreaking and ultimately predictable. Decent mechanics and character abilities. Reasonably well written characters. All of this is hindered and spoiled by the frustrating need to kill demons when the kill sequence is buggy as hell and only serves to slow the game down and annoy you. Still worth playing, but be prepared to be thoroughly annoyed for about a quarter of the game.Overall it's got a decent plot, decent set design, interesting game mechanics. The Investigation side of things is pretty typical, doesn't stretch very far from the conventions of the genre but does involve a few quirks to give it it's own identity (e.g. you can uncover clues and information through possessing people and manipulating them into giving up information).The plot is, for the most part, pretty predictable. For example, *minor spoiler, no specific details*,  the story centres on the witch trails of salem, which becomes pretty obvious about halfway through when a flashback to one of the murders is shown. After that, it's pretty clear that the overarching motive is to do with killing witches. This wouldn't be nearly as obvious to the player if the game was set somewhere OTHER THAN SALEM, which is famous for KILLING WITCHES. As soon as strange symbols and similar things get mentioned, the connection is almost instinctive .The only real twists and turns occur right at the end and even then don't do much to flip the story on it's head, they just make the overall story a little more original. Around halfway through the story, a lot of people will figure out the second half of the plot pretty quickly and then will just have to play through the game and wait for confirmation of what is sadly quite obvious.All that aside, the biggest detractor from the game is the BLOODY DEMONS. A few sections of the game require you to get your stealth hat on and exorcise demons from behind by distracting them, triggering a quicktime event, and hoping that the stars and planets are correctly aligned when you press the buttons, because the system is buggy as hell. For starters, this style of gameplay is totally unecessary and poorly implemented. There's absolutely no flow to it and it just seems like something the developers put in to make the game last a little longer and make it more exciting/different (which it does the exact opposite of). For a dectective game, it really kills the immersion and slows the pace right down. It's incredibly frustrating when all you want to do is get on with the investigation.Basically, if you're drawn to this game and like detective games, go ahead and play it. It's pretty fun and pretty clever at times. Just don't expect to be blown away by the story, although it has some pretty good moments. And definately expect to get extremely fed up with BLOODY DEMONS.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17
												A well done murder / detective game, Murdered: Soul Suspect was an enjoyable game overall and is worth getting (on a sale) if you’re into this genre. The plot is straightforward. You play as Ronan, a criminal turned detective who is shot and killed by a mysterious man. Your quest is to figure out the truth behind your murder and why it happened. Gameplay is mostly good. First off, you play as the ghost of yourself. Therefore, you can walk through most walls and objects which is fun to do. This is carried through the story where characters that are alive cannot see or hear you. You won’t be shooting anyone or have any big action moments. This is story driven first with some puzzles, clue finding scenes and a few small “stealth” parts thrown in. The puzzles incorporate clues you just found or found in the past. You use them to answer questions the game asks you. “What would help Mary remember?” or “What is Joy doing?” for example. The answers are sometimes illogical but you can just guess again.Clue finding scenes are exactly what it sounds like. Find all the clues in a particular area in order to figure out what went on.Stealth sections are the weak point of the game. Luckily, there’s not many of them and it’s not too hard. There are demons that can float around certain areas or inside buildings. To kill them, you need to go up behind them and execute them with a quick time event. However, the controls for this were not predictable and I died several times because the controls wouldn’t respond how I anticipated. The environment, graphics and sound are all very good. There’s definitely a creepy atmosphere that surrounds the entire city. Although, I found that a lot of the characters looked the same and would mistake certain characters for others. I thought the voice acting was fantastic. A definite strong point here.Run the game in 60FPS+Turn off VSYNC in the game options+Enable/force VSYNC in the Nvidia Control Panel Note:Cinematics will still be 30FPS as they are pre-renderedOne of the biggest complaints I have with the game is the lack of a map. It became frustrating to try and navigate around Salem and forget how to get to certain areas you want to re-visit. The game gives you a navigation marker for your current objective, but that’s it. Throughout my playthrough I was never really familiar with the city. For a game with lots of collectibles, it would have been a great addition. I initially tried playing with a keyboard and mouse. It seemed to work fine but when entering the in-game diary, it wouldn’t register me trying to move around. I eventually just used an Xbox 360 controller and everything worked perfect.Pros+60FPS (see note above)+Good story+Great voice acting+Well done animations+Creepy environmentCons+No map+Stealth combat sections+No save feature, only checkpoints+Puzzles are too easy+Steam overlay doesn’t work+Keyboard/mouse controls brokenEven with a few faults, I thought Soul Suspect was a good game and enjoyed playing it. It’s a little short, with maybe 8-10 hours to complete. Even less if you don’t collect the various collectibles. So at the current price of $30, it’s a little steep. Grab this on sale.7/10 Good

content:
Posted: March 18
												Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed this game. I thought it was fun and the story was compelling enough to make me want to finish it. Speaking of the story, however, this main character is easily the dumbest person I have ever encountered in my life, let alone the fact that he's a detective. Ronan didn't die because he was hunting down a murderer, he died because the writers couldn't come up with a good enough excuse for supposedly-respectable police officers to allow this kind of stupidity to act freely in their police department. So they killed him off so that no cops would have to actually deal with how utterly moronic he is. I figured out the story about two and a half hours into the game, and i played a good 5 or 6 hours total to beat it. All along the way, Ronan kept going "Huh, I wonder what this means" when the meaning is so blatantly obvious that a 7-year-old could figure it out, given that this 7-year-old had the utmost basic knowledge on the historical significance of Salem. There was genuinely only one part of this story that surprised me, and even then, it wasn't that impactful because of how upset I was at Ronan for his 6  straight hours of nonstop idiocracy. What really emphasized his stupidity, and I personally find this thoroughly ironic, was when he finally ended up talking with Baxter. Ronan spent the entirety of the game talking about how stupid Baxter is, and when it came down to them actually working together, Ronan had gotten to literally the EXACT same place as Baxter in their search for the killer. Also, overall, Ronan's facial expressions were a huge disconnect. You could tell it was supposed to be a dramatic moment, and Ronan still looked like the infant that I think he really is. Except if that infant were 5'10", had a stubble, and wore a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fedora. Mechanics-wise, it was lacking, but not in such a way that made it hard. Just somewhat tedious. At one point where Ronan should be hauling♥♥♥♥♥across all of Salem, he's instead jogging briskly, taking detours because of how confusing the map is. The teleport mechanic comes in handy, I guess, but honestly it would be so much better if it were just a set distance that you could sorta spam to move faster, instead of having to hold left click, wait for it to charge, and let go, only to travel a repeatedly disappointing distance. Trying to get from the musem to the church was honestly one of the worst sequences for this. I wanted to care about trying to get to the church as fast as I possibly could, but all Ronan could care about was the brunch he was gonna go have with his dead wife after this was all over, resulting in me wanting to start running down my street so that one of us could feel like they were attempting to go quickly towards anything.tl;drstory was predictable, Ronan is a moron, and the controls are meh. 14/10 would Julia again.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is by no means a great game, neither is it a bad game. It is relatively short; the storyline takes about 11 or so hours. The gameplay is fairly simple; travel the overworld to the next objective, sneak/stealth past the baddies, then investigate a crime scene. There are a few puzzles here and there, but nothing that is too complicated. There are a few mechanics introduced throughout the game, but nothing too in-depth, which made the gameplay a bit bland. However, since the game is so short, the lack of new/interesting mechanics didn't really matter since even the basic actions I didn't end up using too many times. Overall, I wasn't blown away, but I didn't not enjoy the storyline. If the following is true: you want a quick game for the weekend, it's on sale, you don't want anything overcomplicated, and you've played through everything else in your library; then this would be a decent game. If you are looking for anything in-depth or with a in-depth storyline, steer clear of this one.

												The only thing holding your attention here will be the story, everything else is basic and an afterthought.While you do play as a detective, the "investigations" that you conduct mostly consist of running around a room looking for something that you can interact with until find the ones you need to complete the investigation. You are able to possess people and cats, but there is not much you can do when possessing people, mostly just reading their mind which becomes dull after a couple of tries. While possesing a cat you can also move around the world with it, however the movement is not at all fluid, jarring even, and it's just so that you can move from one point to another which for game reasons you could not do before. Besides the main story you also have some side cases to solve, which can be interesting and I wish there were more of them.In most ways the Murdered: Soul Suspect is generic and average at best. Thankfully though I certainly was interested in the story and it had some nice mysteries to keep you going. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I would label this as a must buy on sale game. The game itself is a rather interesting take on a detective game, where you are a murdered cop trying to solve his own murder at the hands of a serial killer, so that he can move on to the afterlife and be with his wife. Gameplay mainly consists of investigating crimescenes for clues, and then drawing conclusions based on what you find. There are also ghost abilities, like being able to possess people to read their thoughts, or make electronics turn on. There is also a minor element of combat, as there are demons that will attempt to consume you unless you sneak up on them and destroy them first.The story is engaging, the voice acting is solid, and the movement and game mechanics are well designed and fluid. The ending is solid and satisfying as well. Why only just on sale? It's a relatively quick play through, with no replay value. Once you have made it to the end, the story is complete and there is no reason to revisit it.

Got it at a discount price, not sure if I would really pay 30 bucks for it since it is not very long, but decide for yourself if it is worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect takes a fascinating part of American history and pairs it with a supernatural detective story.  The environment and plot is very creative and unique and kept me interested until the end.  The game is fairly short and doesn't overstay its welcome, yet still provides a lot of character and plot development as well as a few twists.  That being said, there are two minor downfalls to this game.  The first is the overuse of collectibles.  While the collectibles are easy enough to find and doesn't require too much 'post game time' to sit down and sniff them out, there are still a ton of them.  Over 170 in fact.  Each collectible gives some sort of backstory to the world or relevent major characters, but the sheer number of them will have you running to pick them up first before doing the actual story missions.  I feel this can really take the player out of the setting and mood Murdered: Soul Suspect tried to create, with its old, colonial, haunted theme.  If you are the type of player to skip right over collectibles and not be bothered, then this isn't a problem for you.  But if you are OCD, have to get them all, hear every backstory, learn every secret, then this will probably get on your nerves a bit.The other issue to this game is that some of the puzzles are unclear as to how you should go about solving them.  While this has only happened to me about maybe 15% of the puzzles in the game, it is still frustrating to look up the answer and say to yourself 'How does that make sense?'.  The game does give hints if you get the puzzle wrong, but sometimes the hints aren't that clear.  With some trial and error, you should be ok though.Overall, I enjoyed this game.  I picked it up when it was $4 and would have gladly paid $20 for it.  The setting and plot were really unique and I liked all of the ghost mechanics that were added into the game.  It is definitely a game to play when you are looking to get a good story with some amusing puzzles.  I rate this game a 9/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												 Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game I hadn't heard anything good about. Even prior to release, all the buzz was fairly negative. I can sort of see why. Soul Suspect is a strange cousin to a few genres. Its engine feels like it should be third person action adventure, but there is little action. The action (when it occurs) relies on limited stealth and is a bit rubbish. It operates mostly like a point and click, but investigative sections are few and far between. The main crux of the game is the deductive reasoning which is frankly utter tripe.Now none of this looks very good for Soul Suspect... You know what let's get this out of the way - the title is dreadful. Soul Suspect is a play on words that doesn't really make sense, except that you are a soul, having been murdered in the opening minutes of the game (spoiler!). But that's it. It would have been acceptable, but the "Murdered" title makes it unwieldy. Are we to expect a spate of games in the "Murdered" series? I would suggest "Murdered: Going Ghostal" about a murdered postman. I digress.On the surface, Soul Suspect is very much on the ropes here, so let's take it back to the beginning, where the game actually makes a very good first impression. Essentially, you play a policeman who is killed by a serial killer while investigating said serial killer and has to solve his own murder before he can move on to heaven. A neat, fun premise that isn't too demanding and immediately has you suspending your disbelief. What I found exceptional was the telling of your character's history in a well done cutscene showing his tattoos and reasons for getting each one. It really adds some layers to your character and I have to say that I liked the guy. There, I said it. He isn't too much of a wisecracking smartarse, he isn't all whiny and angsty about dying, and his voice actor does a cracking job. Great. I'd go as far as to say that all the characters are well written. You eventually befriend a teenage girl and even SHE is well portrayed, with the right amount of attitude to stay interesting without getting annoying.Now, sadly it starts to go downhill. Not quickly or dramatically, mind you - you just start to feel that many elements could have be far better implemented. The meat of the game is made up of investigating crime scenes, very similar to L.A. Noire, but without the depth. It can feel a little bit clumsy walking around the crime scene waiting for the "investigate" prompt to come up. It tells you how many clues you need to find, but finding some is needlessly difficult, requiring some odd maneuvering into the exact position. Using the clues themselves is even more frustrating.An example from early in the game is when you have to investigate a young woman who tells you she was murdered by an old couple and needs to know where her body is so she can move on. After investigating the old couple's apartment, you are given the question "What happened to the young woman's body?" and you have 6 clues to work with. Intuitively, you might select the ones that give physical evidence or point to what happened to her body, but you'd be wrong. The clues you have to select are actually 1) the girl is dead; 2) this person murdered her; 3) yes, this person definitely murdered her. It doesn't make any sense, because the clues you have to use don't really point to the question asked. This is a recurring problem throughout the game, but swings wildly between obtuse clues and such stark simplicity that you are constantly thrown. For example, later you are asked "What made that cracking noise?", a rope, branch or something cracking into a tree. Here it seems like the answer with "crack" in it is too obvious, but that is the actual answer!This all leads to a rather odd issue with the game in that there doesn't really seem to be a way to fail the investigations, you can just keep trying combinations of clues until you get it right. You get 3 shields next to a clue if you get it perfectly, dropping down to one as you fail. I don't really know how I feel about this. I like that it keeps the story moving, but it also makes the game feel trivial.What can slow the pace of the game are the fairly boring stealth sections. There are two types - one where you simply have to distract a living person with a possessed electrical appliance in order to let your companion slip past (I never failed any of these sections), and the second is when demons decide to show up. These sections are incredible dull and annoying simultaneously. You need to either slip by the demons' very short, predictable patrol paths or get behind them and kill them with mercifully simple QTE. There is some nonsense about using ghost crows to distract them and hiding in ghost residues if they spot you, but it all seems hastily cobbled together.When you're not taking part in the main parts of the game, you'll be collecting collectibles. Lots and lots of collectibles. There are journals, memories, ghost stories and ghost graffiti to collect and are also the subject of ambivalence. They are very easy to find which is sort of good as they add to the story, but are so easy to find that they seem a bit pointless. The only hard ones to find are the graffiti collectibles, but that's because they're invisible and there's the problem of you being in the right position to tell you that you can interact with them.So all in all, boring, pointless and needlessly obtuse. What a terrible game! Well, no, actually. It all sort of comes together. It gels very well. It initially feels weird moving around the levels and into crime scenes because you might feel like you should be sneaking, but you are completely invisible, so you walk around completely unimpeded. You can walk through walls, possess people to see what they're thinking and (in a great highlight) even possess a cat and run around meowing. The execution of the game might be lacking, but the intention is so clear that I found myself forgiving it most of its flaws.The story is a high point as well, I have to admit that it drew me in very and had me second guessing myself a few times. There are lots of clues around as to what is happening and if (like me) you pick up on them, you will find yourself slightly thrown as you try to piece it all together and re-evaluate your theories. I even found myself pleasantly surprised by the denouement - it wasn't overlong, over complex or a ridiculous boss fight. I was very impressed by the writing and performances in the game, they turned a mediocre game into a good one.I did get the game very cheap, I have to say, so I don't know how forgiving I would have been at £39.99. I paid around £4.50 for it and feel that that is very cheap, but I would have been happy to pay up to £11.99 for it, and that is praise indeed!

												A hugely underrated game in some circles, wherein I fear that some feel it does not stand up to the graphical quality of the PS3/PS4 games we have today. You have a choice: a stunning story, or pure eye candy. This game stands tall on the story aspect, featuring one of the best introductions I have ever seen in a video game. The setting is a powerful one indeed. All characters are relevant, and it is amazing to see a setting unfold and exposition be provided by so many supporting characters.There are the occasional obstacles requiring strategy guides (a solution to a problem would've been to have interactive objects glow orange or something like that) that can impede gameplay, but it isn't really a problem in the long run. Heck, you can possess (play as) a cat. That also makes the game an instant win in my book :D

Posted: May 22, 2015
												This "game" is one of the worst I've ever "played".  Even if free, it's not worth the time you'd spend.  Certain elements of the game make it clear that the game was rushed to publication, like the "mysteries" that you solve for random ghosts, which appear only in the first two areas and give you no reward whatsoever.  The game mechanics are shady and boring, like when you have to put together three clues and they tell you to put them in chronological order even though the clues have nothing to do with time.  Most of the time I could figure out what they wanted but by and large it was guesswork.  The game itself is only 3 or 4 hours of real gameplay with a great deal of padding in the form of hidden collectables, most of which also do not give you any reward except for the "scary stories" which feature excruciating voice acting and are a giant waste of time.I wish I had the kind of guts Square Enix has to publish this piece of garbage and demand 50 bucks for it.  Do not buy it, do not play it, and remember this the next time you want a Square Enix game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												You see I recommend it, but only to certain people.I will first of all admit that this game gameplay wise is absolutely dreadful to play. All of it is either you walking around a crime scene trying to find some obscure clue that isn't showing up when pass it or killing demons by mashing WASD or the mouse buttons at once. I found myself struggling to play the game simply for the repetitive and boring gameplay.But what is good is the immersion and story. That is what kept me going through this. If you treat this game as a game and not a story, it kinda falls flat on it's face in every way. But if you look at it for it's story and where it guides, it is pretty damn good. The ending was also great, something you have to experience yourself when connecting the dots. About half way through the game though the story starts to drag but at the end it picks back up in an extremely memorable way.So in terms of the actual game I would recommend purchase if you are into game stories and not gameplay. Something like the Walking Dead but not near as awesome.Performance wise the game is solid on playability most of the time. Most of the games that are helped made by AMD usually have decent ports with minimal problems, two good examples being Sleeping Dogs and Hitman: Absolution. There are problems though. This game in the options tends to not give you details, for instance the in the settings for anti-aliasing the options for FXAA are thing like FXAA(High) and FXAA(Medium), doesn't really give me an idea of what I am working with. The other issue is also with the mouse sensitivity settings, there are 3 options. There is no slider it is literally three options. I had to adjust my mouse DPI to make this game playable. But on high settings for everything at 1080p I would usually experience 120 fps + nicely. Although depending on the lighting my game has dropped to 30 for no reason (namely the church entrance).As a note I am playing with:2nd Gen AMD A10-5700 Accelerated APU (integrated graphics disabled)EVGA GTX 750 1GB DDR3 FTW ACX Cooling8 GB RAM

Murdered SS isn't a particulary bad game, it just falls short with a linear puzzle system, predicable story line and limited interactive combat or sense of real danger.  I'd say overall and decent interactive movie type title with an unsatisfying conclusion but it does deliver some fun moments along the way.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												This game is more like "L.A. Noire" than anything else, and I really enjoyed it. Then again, I enjoy games with decent stories more than a lot of people seem to do, and the story for "Murdered: Soul Suspect" had enough twists and kept my intrigue enough to see it the whole way through without too many regrets. There was potential for it to be a "horror" game (which I hate), but fortunately any scares were more in the environment and feeling of the game than through outright scares.  Some people seem to put more value on time spent, so for those kind of people this game at $30 (as I write this) might not be of value. But if you enjoyed "L.A. Noire", this game is at least worth getting on a Steam sale.There are enough other reviews (should this one ever be read by anyone) that I'm going to spare yet another description of the story and get to what I think are the pluses and minuses of the game.Pluses:+ Non-linear with respect to being able to visit previous locations+ Intriguing story placed in Salem, MA and linked to the historic witch trials+ Dark, brooding atmosphere without necessarily crossing the line into "horror"+ Good acting and voice work+ No jump scares (for the most part)+ Roughly 8-10 hour play time doesn't require too much commitment+ No achievement mandating that all of the mysteries are solved PEFECTLY (unlike "L.A. Noire")+ Side quests while not required provided some well-written ghost stories+ Some interesting plot twistsMinuses:- Demons felt like they were added for pointless stealth/action gameplay- Too many collectibles for a game of this size- No way to track how many collectibles still remain in a particular location- End sequence stops somewhat abruptlyIf you can put up with the pointless demons, which don't show up very often anyway, and you can deal with not having to find *every* collectible, you'll probably find this game worthwhile, although the $30 price tag (as of writing) might be a bit too much for some people, based on the returns. This is definitely worth picking up on a Steam sale, though.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												I guess this is that game: No matter how many negative reviews or hatespeech it received on forums, magazines and websites, I was rather captivated by it. And I still cannot quite put my finger on why... many reasons I think.  Even though I absolutely dispise pixel hunting (hi Arkham City!) I found myself drawn into the world of the protagonist through brilliant voice (and mocap) acting, solid graphics and a demanding story line with a twist at the end that blew my mind. While it is certainly true that the NPC's are the most boring to ever feature in a AAA title, the main characters feel suprisingly human in this stunning demonstration of how much oomph is still left in the Unreal Engine. Even on fairly modest PC setup, the game should look good. I know I clicked 'Yes' in the section that asks if this game should be recommended, but I can at least admit it will not be everyone's cup of tea. You NEVER actually touch a gun in this game, but to me that is part of the charm. It is definitely clear that the developers made an effort to do something different, even if they failed somewhat obviously to do so. If you are looking to take a brake from flinging tons of lead at enemies and you are willing to overlook a few glaring oversights of a development studio that obviously feared missing their release date, buy it. Or put it on your wishlist for that day you feel you need to take a break from mainstream gaming.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I can see how some people might recommend this game.  There is stuff to like about it, it's playable, but as a big studio title I'm going to take the harsher route and not recommend it.  Mostly because it's so underwhelming, gameplay and story wise.The game play is super casual.  Reduntantly casual.  Most of the game focuses around collecting clues, but you don't derive any meaning from them.   Once you've found the right clues you can opt to solve the case and the game will ask you a straight forward question like "what happened here", or "where did the killer go next" and you click on the clues that blatantly answer the question.  There's no deduction involve, just fill in the blank and then the character will summerize the obvious as though they were hit with some hard earned revelation.There is also the hunt/be hunted aspect of the game.  Every area has one or two sections where demons emerge and you either have to navigate through them, or destroy them without them attacking you.  It was kind of like the developer was trying to include some action in the game, but it was pretty pointless.  They didn't really get any more difficult as the game progressed and they had nothing to do with the story.  It made me wonder if the developers were playing with what kind of genre they wanted the game to be and ended up not developing or cutting out any of the possibilities. Heck, even the opening scene of us trying to get back into our body uses a gimicky game play element that we don't see again for the rest of the game. It obviously wasn't an interesting enough element to use again, why is it still in there?The story is also pretty mediocre.  I guess it's fine, it wasn't painful, it was just blah.  The superficial questions were answered, but there wasn't really any explaination as to why any of it was happening, nor was there any real character development for anyone.  The story did conclude, which is more satisfying than some games, but there wasn't really much reward for exploring so much game territory.  In fact, there were lots of smaller unrelated stories that presented themselves in the first half of the game that were probably more interesting and involving than the main plot.  I think they got tired of programming ghosts in the second half of the game or something because the NPCs that drove these side stories stopped asking for  help, and suddenly all the NPCs that had about 2 lines of original monologue each started sharing about 4 lines between all of them.All in all, I'm sure some people will like this game.  Maybe many will find it on the positive side of mundane, but personally I found it to be an overglorified, padded, hidden object game.  It could really use some editing, and it would be a nice bonus if they actually decided on an aspect of the game to develop into something interesting.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I was expecting either a run of the mill horror game or a glorified walking simulator. I couldn't have been more wrong. 1) Horror: I decided to play this right after Outlast because I was in that type of mood. Soul Suspect still managed to get my heart rate up and creep me out in a few spots. 2) Walking SImulator: I think the only one I ever played was Gone Home. It was a great story, it was kind of creepy but it was so human at the same time. Sure there are ghosts and demons and witches, but the story is about people. You really get to learn about the people by just walking around and clicking on things.3) Police Procedural: The only other ones that come to mind are the CSI games and LA Noir, none of which I've played. Althought the "puzzles" if you want to call them that were simple, they at least made it feel like I was involved in hashing out the next step.My only gripe is that some of the collectables were in places I'd have never looked had I not eventually given up and looked them up. I'm not a fan of these things though and they are totally optional so it doesn't really efffect the game unless you want it to.I've been playing video games since the early 80s and I've been using steam since the Orange Box was bundled with video cards. Two things I hardly ever do are complete a game 100% and write a review. I've now done both for this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												You play the ghost of a detective trying to solve his own murder. The game takes place in Salem, MA, modern day, but there are insights to the city's infamous past hidden all over Salem. As you explore looking for clues as to who murdered you and why, you find many other mysteries throughout the game.This game is very linear aside from finding objects throughout the city and buildings. It took me eight hours to beat the game and that includes the time I spent exploring. It is story driven and has very little action. The only action involves sneaking up on demons and attacking them, which does require some tactic. No shooting or combat, lots of hiding. Not much horror to it either. Nothing jumps out at you and the story itself isn't that creepy. Graphics are fairly decent and controls are smooth. I used a control instead of mouse and key board.I liked the story throughout this game and enjoyed hunting for clues. If you like story rich games and detective noir stories than perhaps this is the game for you. However I wouldn't recommend this if you're looking for an action/horror game. Also, I bought this on sale and thought it was a good deal, not sure I'd say the same buying it for $30. It's a good quick game with a decent story. 3/5 stars

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Soul Suspect is a good, unique game with an interesting story.First thing I'll say is that if you dont like being confined within a level boundary or anything like that then you probably wont like this game. Yes you play a ghost and can walk through many walls, but you cant walk through all of them, obviously you have to be kept in the game somehow, and I accepted that and enjoyed it.The game is humerous, has some funny dialogue and is a slow paced mystery game as you attempt to solve your murder as well as several other peoples in the game.You can take control of people in the investigation, gain information from them, then use all the clues you found to build a picture of what happened.You will investigate several crime scenes throughout the game, some are to do with the main story, and several are just extra investigations there for fun.There are plenty of collectables in the game to help form a backstory, you dont have to collect them but they are good as they give you a history on the main character and the town you are in. The town being Salem and is heavily centred around the Salem Witch Trials.There are several areas in the game in which you will do your main investivations, when completed you can always revisit them to look for things you didnt find before.There are nice details throughout the game like random ghosts that are just there in the background and vanish as you get close to them, other ghosts that you can help to move on, and even ghostly buildings, such as original structures that no longer exist in the real world but you cannot pass through them as they are real to you.If you want to play something a bit different, with a unique story, humour and lots of collectables for you to find then give Murdered: Soul Suspect a go.I may not play this game again as the fun is in the mystery and trying to work out what has happened, but its still good to play a first time.7/10Oh yeah, ignore the Metacritic score. They don't know what they are talking about.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
Score: 7/10Similar GamesSherlock Holmes: Crimes and Punishments,The Vanishing of Ethan CarterSummaryYou play as a cop with a family history in gang violence. While tracking down the Bell Killer you wind up being killed by him. Now you must master your new ghost powers to solve the mystery of who the Bell Killer is.PositiveThe game has an interesting story and presents it very well. All the different ghost mechanics work quite nicely and really give the game some uniqueness. The atmospheric graphic imagery and sound do a great job at being creepy while staying true to both the spirit world and the living world.NegativeKILL DEMONS!! How about no... I mean combat is done in a pure stealth approach by hiding and taking them down, but overall it ends up feeling like a giant gimmick to make the game double the length. The sheer amount of waiting you have to do is just annoying during these sequences. I don't mind the demon floor traps, but the actual demons looking for you I removed with an ini edit. Here's how to make yourself invisible to them so you can just ignore fighting demons.Go to......\Murdered Soul Suspect\FateGame\Config Open...DefaultAIPerceptionData.ini Change...StimTypes=(TypeName=Player,BaseTypeName=Ghost,Result_Awareness=High)To...StimTypes=(TypeName=Player,BaseTypeName=Ghost,Result_Awareness=Unaware)ConclusionI tried to spoil as little as possible during this review. The great atmosphere and piecing of clues together while doing using your ghostly abilities is pretty fun. It can occasionally feel under developed and shallow so you may find yourself thinking about how amazing this game could have been. I doubt it will get another similar game sequel, but I think another game that used these mechanics and improved on them would be a real treat.ValueI'd suggest not paying more then about $10 for this game. The story is great, but not all that long if you use the ini tweak and ignore combat along with ignoring the collectables.

Posted: April 11, 2015
												I'm not really sure why I liked Murdered: Soul Suspect, maybe it was because the investigation parts are just the right amount of challenging without relying on your ability to lip read the faces of the uncanny valley... I'm trying to avoid looking at you L.A Noire... Or perhaps it was the side quests, engaging side quests, where I actually felt like I was doing some good, that I was changing the game world for the better. Whatever it was I did enjoy Murdered: Shoal Suspect. I enjoyed it a lot and (silly name aside) I found myself gripped in a supernatural thriller, which had some level of adventure gameness to it, the controls were solid, the graphics reasonable, and the story (while a little predictable in places) did keep me glued to the screen wanting to find out what happened next, the ability to contribute to that story through the aforementioned side quests, and investigation moments probably helped keep me in during the boring bits.I did find the combat a little clunky, but the moments are so few and far between that it never became more than a minor annoyance, and immersion was spoiled somewhat by the sheer denseness of the player character, watching him piece together the motives of the antagonist was less Sherlock Holmes, and more Scooby-Doo.However maybe you really get off on being smarter than the character... Maybe that is the real reason I like Murdered: Soul Singer. Whatever your motivation for thinking about getting this game, I advise you to.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Just finished this game and I must say it worth its money. My rating: 9,5/10First of all, the Level Design is well layed out with a prety huge map to explore, not to mention that this game is based on exploration. There are many different paths you can take to reach a certain area, the indoor level design is gorgeous, many effects such as lens flares, particles/smoke, cool looking spectral city placed across the map with props all over it and the contrast between colors is tremendous. The more you explore, the more real information about the 1660 time you'll find and secondary cases you need to solve in order to obtain achivements and some creepy stories that are fun to hear or read. Secondly, speaking of textures now, the developers used a really wide range of textures, and the result? The boredom of seeing the same thing over and over again is excluded. Not only did they succeed in creating a sinister environment, but with the accompany of a Various library of sounds , they created a replica of a horror movie inwhich you choose the protagonist's moves. Thirdly, the animations, I must admit, could have been done a lot better. Such automatic, much less cool.Another aspect of the game I want to talk about is the combat system and the enemies. Besides the Killer Bell (the main enemy), are the demons. Yes, it appears that ghosts can be swallowed in by them...who would have thought? To kill one you need to follow this simple step: Go behind it and press the buttons that appears on your screen. Voila you just killed a badass looking demon. There are some demon's spawns on the floor which will make you cast a certain combination of keys the moment you step on it. If you fail, some demonic hands will drag you down (in hell maybe).Encountering a demon will only happen in a specific area full of teleportals. Although I used the Teleportals to travell across the map faster I also used them to hide from demons. They can't sense you in a teleportal.Possesing is a protagonist's ability to read people minds but you can't move with their bodies. Moreover, you can even posses a cat.Nevertheless the story is by far one of my favourites. I bought this game mainly for its level design and for the Dark, sinister and twisted story which caught my attention. You need to take decisions based on what you know so far, based on the recent findings and your logical interpretation.  I won't spoil the story don't worry, you really need to figure it out  yourself. The main character has a easily recognisable visual design and you must admit he's a badass looking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ from the game's poster.All summed up, due to its story, level design including the textures,lighting,particles and lens flares, with a cold heart character I highly recommend this game.

												Murdered: Soul Suspect is an immersive third person adventure that puts you in the role of Ronan, a kind of swaggerish badassitude detective who needs to solve his own murder to finally move on.You solve investigation puzzles, help other ghosts in need and collect different stuff on your way to discovering who killed you and why. The riddles are not difficult, there are even some stealthy scenarios involving demons etc. but the main focus here is the intense story in a very dark and mysterious little town with a heinous past.The game reminded me of some games of the Telltale-Series, only you can move around more freely and dynamically.If you love intense storytelling and stuff involving police work and serial killers, thats the one!

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I love the concept of this game (a ghost cop trying to solve his own murder by a serial killer), but unfortunately the game is clumsy and shallow. In the end, I couldn't wait for this one to be over.Pros:+ Good concept+ Good graphicsCons:- Clumsy controls- Shallow, one-dimensional characters and unrealistic dialogue- The game's attempt at stealth/combat seems like an afterthought. It is annoying, distracting, and doesn't add anything to the game.- The game's attempt at puzzles that require you to use deductive reasoning are not well done. The main character is so slow at putting things together, it's hard to understand what he considers interesting.- The game appears to be a sloppily done console port. Counter-intuitive key mapping, puzzles that appear to use controller vibration, etc.- Text is very hard to read (bad font choice)- Getting around from location to location is tedious. (No mini-map, blocked paths, etc.)

												Ein detektiv Spiel, dessen Gameplay mechaniken so sehr auf das simpelste runtergebrochen ist, dass auch Blinder es fertig bringen könnte, das Spiel mit einer Hand durchzuspielen und mit anderen in seiner Hose zu landen. Wer also still-Life erwartet, wird vom Spiel enttäuscht sein.Das worin es gut ist, ist die Geschichte, die das Spiel erzählt. Eine spannende Detektiv, Geister Geschichte, die dazu noch Salam und Inqusitionen  in den Topf schmeißt. Und wenn es nicht genug sein sollte, so kann man viele Collectables sammeln, um spannende Horror Kurzgeschichte freizuschalten. Alle passend zu dem Gebiet, in dem sie freigeschaltet wurden.Und auch wenn das Gameplay rudimentär sein mag, so finde ich es immer noch befridigend, wenn man die Beweise zusammen gekramt hat, und es mit der Geschichte weitergeht.Fazit: Eine Schande, dass dieses Spiel als schlecht angesehen wird. Denn ich nehme viel lieber ein "schlechtes" Spiel im Spiele vom Murdered: Soul Suspect, mit seiner einzigartigen Geschichte, den spannenden Kurzgeschichten und einem Gameplay, dass nicht aus schießen, springen, schießen, repeat besteht, bevor ich es überhaupt wage, einen Blick auf den Rest der Square Enix, Sega. Capcom, Sony und co. Spiele-Bibliothek zu werfen, und euch zeige, wie schlechte Spiele wirklich aussehen. Hab ich recht, Final fantasy 13 und jedes Sony exklusiv Titel seit Uncharted, die verzweifelt versuchen Filme zu sein? Yeah, ♥♥♥♥ you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Worth a play if you can get it on sale. Soul Suspect is a detective adventure game. Calling it a horror game does a dis-service to actual horror games so I'll just say it has a dark atmosphere. The story is kinda mediocre, somewhat predictabe and relatively short (I finished it in 8 hours, while doing a pretty good amount of exploring). The controls are kinda sticky at times.  Some interacions should be based on proximity instead of the current system of it being based on where the camera is centered. There is very little character progression in regards to powers and the powers are a tad lame. 'Battles' in this game consist of sneaking up on enemies to trigger a QTE to defeat them. If you are spotted by them or fail the QTE, you're forced to run and hide until the enemy gives up at which point you can try again. There is only one enemy type in the entire game, save for the 'final boss.' The crime scene system (not sure what it's officially called) is interesting but will often penalize you for not being able to answer their vaguely asked question in the exact way they want you to. Not sure if this is a localization thing or someting else. Some of the clues are absurd to be called 'clues'  and I wa somestimes annoyed that I had to click on it to make the observation into a 'clue.' Also, as mentioned about the controls, because the camera has to be centered on the item for prompts to show up, I would often miss clues because a prompt didn't pop up -- this would just add unnecessary time as I'd be searching for that last clue and then realize that I hadn't properly centered the camera on the item for the prompt to come up.I got this during a recent sale for under $10 and I think that's a fair price for the game. It wasn't spectacular but was interesting enough to keep me occupied. Frankly, games like this should not be released at full console retail price when the quality of the product doesn't warrant so.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Soul Suspect is a good, unique game with an interesting story.First thing I'll say is that if you dont like being confined within a level boundary or anything like that then you probably wont like this game. Yes you play a ghost and can walk through many walls, but you cant walk through all of them, obviously you have to be kept in the game somehow, and I accepted that and enjoyed it.The game is humerous, has some funny dialogue and is a slow paced mystery game as you attempt to solve your murder as well as several other peoples in the game.You can take control of people in the investigation, gain information from them, then use all the clues you found to build a picture of what happened.You will investigate several crime scenes throughout the game, some are to do with the main story, and several are just extra investigations there for fun.There are plenty of collectables in the game to help form a backstory, you dont have to collect them but they are good as they give you a history on the main character and the town you are in. The town being Salem and is heavily centred around the Salem Witch Trials.There are several areas in the game in which you will do your main investivations, when completed you can always revisit them to look for things you didnt find before.There are nice details throughout the game like random ghosts that are just there in the background and vanish as you get close to them, other ghosts that you can help to move on, and even ghostly buildings, such as original structures that no longer exist in the real world but you cannot pass through them as they are real to you.If you want to play something a bit different, with a unique story, humour and lots of collectables for you to find then give Murdered: Soul Suspect a go.I may not play this game again as the fun is in the mystery and trying to work out what has happened, but its still good to play a first time.7/10Oh yeah, ignore the Metacritic score. They don't know what they are talking about.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Remember The Darkness? This game plays a little bit like that, with the 'other world on top of this world' vibe... Except that Ronan is a WAY more likable and funny guy than Jackie, who - if Im going to be generous - had the personality of a piece of sopping wet cardboard. (Yes I've read the comics. I stand by my statement.)Gameplay can get a little clunky, but you arent asked to do action sequences more than a few times, so mostly it's just atmosphere. Said atmosphere can, at times, get a little repetative, but it did manage to maintain a pacing of steadily getting creepier and creepier. The tense string instruments make you want to turn around and slap the musicians for scaring you like a little girl. Play at night with the lights off for maximum effect, obviously.Power through the story if you get tired of the levels; they dont take long. The story itself had a few 'whodunit' twists and a few others you can see a mile out, but still. It's not terrible, and history nerds get a nice stroll through Salem that doesnt overwhelm people who dont give a rat's behind about what happened in 1800-and-who-cares.Conclusion: A nice timekiller that wont take up more than a day of dedicated play or a few days of off and on. WARNING: The menu in here IS glitchy as all heck, so stay out of it as often as you can.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												It's a wonderful exploration and collection type game with a spooky (but not scarey) vibe to it, with detailed environments and lots of goodies to hunt down.There's only two issues that make it only worth buying when it's on sale and not at full price.The first is that it's fairly short.The second is the performance problems.  The frame rate is all over the place, so it feels like it's always stuttering.   This is one game where it might have been better if they limited the frame rate and tuned the game to that frame rate.   Only the demon hunts require any sort of timing and hand eye co-ordination, but you don't need 60 frames per second for that.There is a final thing that comes up and it depends a lot on what kind of gamer you are.   The game's mini-games aren't very challenging, and the solutions don't always make sense.  On the upside, aside from score keeping, the game doesn't really punish you for a wrong move.   If you screw up a demon hunt, you just respawn -- the demons you already took out don't respawn.   When you make a wrong choice in your investigation, you just lose a badge point (these aren't even important except for score keeping).   Even with no badge points left, you can keep picking until you get it right and continue the game.   There's very little frustration to this game.Worth buying, but don't pay more than $20 for it.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												This game had potential of becoming a good detective game but it felt squandered.Ultimately the game could've of been more fleshed out while the mechanics work well they ended being used to simply. Where instead it should've been asking the user harder questions depending on the investigation instead of asking simple question such as what happened here. It also felt short and unfinished with a lot of ghosts starting to explain there problems which could allow them to move on but then telling the user not bother. I also think there should've been more then one murder case to look through then just your own and the bell serial killer murders.The story was kind of predictable to the point you can guess the red hearing as soon as he/she shows up. The ending had a twist you don't see cause the character basically showing only twice and in one scene didn't even interact with the player. The two leads had really poor chemistry that they both just came off as whinging most the time during there dialogue.The combat and stealth was poorly executed and unnecessary to the point where it shouldn't off existed in the first place making this game a pure detective game. Guiding joy around ultimately ended up being find the thing to poltergeist to allow joy to move on to the next point.Overall this game had potential of being a good detective game but was squandered with unnecessary combat, simply investigations, short game and uninteresting characters.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												The type of game that makes me wish for a recommendation of "Only on sale"One of the few games out there that lets you play as a ghost doing actual ghost like things, the game is marred by several issues that really prevent it from working enough for me to give it a pass at normal prices.It's a puzzle game first and foremost that felt it had to add in some action in the form of stealth segments where you must avoid getting caught by demons, which usually boils down to accidentally getting spotted and having to waste time teleporting around safe spots waiting for them to resume patrolling so you can try again at doing a QTE to get them out of an area so you can go back to exploring.And then there's the puzzles, that boil down to trying to find every object in a given area and putting 2 or 3 of them together to solve a small mystery, sometimes operating off of logic and other times suffering from the Phoenix Wright problem where you're ahead of the game's characters but are forced to answer extremely handholding questions in order to advance (such as "there was a murder" as one of an early mystery's "most relevant" clues when you are asked to investigate a murder).However, that's not what really hurts this game. Instead, it's the simple lack of content. There isn't enough dialogue recorded for a game that features a mind-reading mechanic. There are very few side quests and after you complete them all the hub world you are forced to travel through seems very boring. Collectables are decent but don't seem to ever really be enough considering the amount of ground you cover between them. The main plot ends way too early for something that came out above $20. And those demons mentioned above? They are thrown in purely to prevent you from breezing through levels in 10 minutes.As you'll probably get through most of the content you care about in the first run, the game really lacks a lot of replay value, so your first run through is going to be about as long as you spend with the game. I went through with the "I'm going to try to collect as much as I can, but more than an hour without any result and I'm moving on" mentality, and I clocked about 8 hours (which includes a bit of idling time spent away from the computer).It's kind of sad, because the game isn't devoid of value, just not enough to justify purchasing it normally.Its writing, especially concerning some of the ghost stories you come across, is engaging, even if it's not the best you'll ever experience. Meanwhile, it completely nails the "I'm playing as a ghost detective" thing it was going for, even going so far as to have the first thing you do be trying to get back into your still barely alive body by trying to slip into it. If you liked Ghost Trick or Geist and wanted more games like that, this scratches that itch nicely.This game is worth playing for those who have a weakness for a somewhat noir detective game or one where you play as a ghost, but because you'll probably only need to play it once, get it on sale.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Throughout my playthrough of Murdered: Soul Suspect, I could never truly figure out if this was just a game that took the modern game developer's philosophy of all-inclusiveness to an extreme or if they honestly just think gamers are all dumb as posts. That's the biggest problem with this game. I'm generally a fan of story-based games and can appreciate when they make games decently easy to complete so that you can follow the story at a good pace. Even for me, Murdered: Soul Suspect was so ridiculously easy that I just couldn't bring myself to care.You follow the story of Ronan, a cop working on a serial killer case in the city of Salem. As the game starts, Ronan meets his grisly end but comes back as a ghost. He quickly finds out that in order to move on to the afterlife with his beloved, he must solve the case of the Bell Killer and thus, his own murder. It's not an uninteresting premise but curiousity quickly becomes tedium as you work to make Ronan catch up with what you probably figured out just from reading those three sentences. Supernatural occurances in Salem equals witchcraft. In fact, reaching this level of obviousness and not overthinking things is probably the most difficult part of the game.While the game occasionally gives you action sequences involving sneaking around demons a la Metal Gear Solid, the primary bulk of the gameplay is exploring and using detective work to piece together the mystery of the Bell Killer. The kinds of puzzles you have to solve are similar to this: a body lies in front of you with a gunshot through the head. What weapon killed him: a gun, a knife or a rope? See what I mean about overthinking things? This isn't a trick question and the game is full of stupidity like this. One frequent puzzle that is honestly in the game is where you have to influence people to think about a certain topic so you can read their thoughts. You have to pick from a variety of subjects to get them to think about the Bell Killer. To do this, you pick the thought that is directly talking about the Bell Killer. There is no extra thought to this and the puzzle repeats FREQUENTLY throughout the game.The other gameplay elements aren't much better. The stealth sequences are absurdly easy and simply require you to move behind the demons who follow the exact same path without variation in rooms where there are, at most, four of them. There is also a collect-a-thon throughout the game where you pick up elements of backstory about a variety of topics like Ronan's life, Salem's history and other topics. There are over 200 of these collectables scattered throughout the relatively small game world and while it's fun to find these at first, it quickly becomes boring like the rest of the game due to very little reward for collecting them all.Due to the ease of completing the game and the stupidity of pretty much every character, the storyline is hardly fulfilling either. Some may enjoy making their way to the conclusion but you will likely guess what's going on after only a few hours of play time. Still, despite the bad gameplay, the controls felt great to me, using a 360 gamepad, and the camera worked surprisingly well, considering how much time is spent walking through walls. The sound is also decent with voiceovers ranging from passable to pretty decent. If you are looking for a mindless game to play through in a day or two, Murdered: Soul Suspect may be what you're looking for but if you're looking for something with even the slightest hint of meat to it, pass on this one. It will only disappoint.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												A story-rich experience, with a high dramatic intensity. Those are all the words needed to describe this game, and all that you might want from it. Being an average-budget, not AAA-wannabe game, I wasn't expecting too much, and I got exactly that. You can see from the setting, the story and the mechanics that this game' size isn't so big, neither it pretends to be. But you can also understand from the very beginning that the developers did the best with everything they had, even on the technical side (yes, even if it is locked at 30 FPS and may look like a console-to-pc porting, when maxed it looks very good). The soundtrack is good, the ambient sounds are good, even the lighting is pretty damn good and they all do their part in creating a creepy enough atmosphere in which the player has to wisely move. Buy this game for a few bucks and spend some good late afternoons with it, you won't be disappointed.

Expect it to be campy, don't expect it to be terribly long, and you should have a lot of fun (and maybe wet yourself once or twice).

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of the games I missed out on when it was released, in fact, I hadn't even heard about it until I got it in a bundle pack on sale.  Turns out, I loved this game.It takes place in a pretty nice noir setting.  The graphics are alright, but nothing amazing and certainly not groundbreaking for 2014.  The game suffers from a few issues, one of which being the copy-pasted NPC models and voice-acting, and another being the choices you make have virtually no effect on the outcome of the story.  The game features little to no replay value, due to its linearity as well.That said, the story of the game was very well done, and the events that take place are really well thought out and the gameplay mechanics are very well done, so the game is still worth it, I think.  The main character, Ronan, isn't exactly a very complex character, but his inner demons and his relationship with his wife Joy, really give him some depth.  There is pretty great character development in this story, and the whole thing has a very distinct movie-like feel to it.    The evidence finding and general detective mechanics are pretty fun and the atmosphere they managed to create with the ghosts and seeing Salems past through the eyes of Ronan makes for some really cool effects and storytelling.One of the highlights of the game is the phenomenal voice acting and character lip-syncing to the voices, which often goes pretty underrated.  However a downside of the title is that there is a 30 FPS lock on the game, but I honestly wasn't able to notice, very similar to the way L.A. Noire has a 30 FPS lock as well.I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys paranormal/ghost stories as well as noir/detective games with dark-ish atmospheres.  It is certainly worth the time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17
												A well done murder / detective game, Murdered: Soul Suspect was an enjoyable game overall and is worth getting (on a sale) if you’re into this genre. The plot is straightforward. You play as Ronan, a criminal turned detective who is shot and killed by a mysterious man. Your quest is to figure out the truth behind your murder and why it happened. Gameplay is mostly good. First off, you play as the ghost of yourself. Therefore, you can walk through most walls and objects which is fun to do. This is carried through the story where characters that are alive cannot see or hear you. You won’t be shooting anyone or have any big action moments. This is story driven first with some puzzles, clue finding scenes and a few small “stealth” parts thrown in. The puzzles incorporate clues you just found or found in the past. You use them to answer questions the game asks you. “What would help Mary remember?” or “What is Joy doing?” for example. The answers are sometimes illogical but you can just guess again.Clue finding scenes are exactly what it sounds like. Find all the clues in a particular area in order to figure out what went on.Stealth sections are the weak point of the game. Luckily, there’s not many of them and it’s not too hard. There are demons that can float around certain areas or inside buildings. To kill them, you need to go up behind them and execute them with a quick time event. However, the controls for this were not predictable and I died several times because the controls wouldn’t respond how I anticipated. The environment, graphics and sound are all very good. There’s definitely a creepy atmosphere that surrounds the entire city. Although, I found that a lot of the characters looked the same and would mistake certain characters for others. I thought the voice acting was fantastic. A definite strong point here.Run the game in 60FPS+Turn off VSYNC in the game options+Enable/force VSYNC in the Nvidia Control Panel Note:Cinematics will still be 30FPS as they are pre-renderedOne of the biggest complaints I have with the game is the lack of a map. It became frustrating to try and navigate around Salem and forget how to get to certain areas you want to re-visit. The game gives you a navigation marker for your current objective, but that’s it. Throughout my playthrough I was never really familiar with the city. For a game with lots of collectibles, it would have been a great addition. I initially tried playing with a keyboard and mouse. It seemed to work fine but when entering the in-game diary, it wouldn’t register me trying to move around. I eventually just used an Xbox 360 controller and everything worked perfect.Pros+60FPS (see note above)+Good story+Great voice acting+Well done animations+Creepy environmentCons+No map+Stealth combat sections+No save feature, only checkpoints+Puzzles are too easy+Steam overlay doesn’t work+Keyboard/mouse controls brokenEven with a few faults, I thought Soul Suspect was a good game and enjoyed playing it. It’s a little short, with maybe 8-10 hours to complete. Even less if you don’t collect the various collectibles. So at the current price of $30, it’s a little steep. Grab this on sale.7/10 Good

												Murdered: Soul Suspect, is very underated as a game. I put off playing this game for quite some time due to the negative publicity. My loss, because this is well above average in many regards.The negatives are its total lack of replayability and pointless combat system. But forget about all that and don't even bother with the collectibles, the majotity of them are pointless and offer nothing in relation to world or charcter building. The npcs found everywhere are likewise pointless, dont waste your time with them.However the reason I love this game is the story, the main story is gripping and the main characters are likewise compelling. This is not an fps or an rpg, its a very good interactive story. If like me you appreciate a well told story in a great setting and don't mind it being linear with no sidequests and the rest of the fluff then this is a winner. If you spacebar through conversations and skip cutscenes then avoid this like the plague.Love Arch

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect takes a fascinating part of American history and pairs it with a supernatural detective story.  The environment and plot is very creative and unique and kept me interested until the end.  The game is fairly short and doesn't overstay its welcome, yet still provides a lot of character and plot development as well as a few twists.  That being said, there are two minor downfalls to this game.  The first is the overuse of collectibles.  While the collectibles are easy enough to find and doesn't require too much 'post game time' to sit down and sniff them out, there are still a ton of them.  Over 170 in fact.  Each collectible gives some sort of backstory to the world or relevent major characters, but the sheer number of them will have you running to pick them up first before doing the actual story missions.  I feel this can really take the player out of the setting and mood Murdered: Soul Suspect tried to create, with its old, colonial, haunted theme.  If you are the type of player to skip right over collectibles and not be bothered, then this isn't a problem for you.  But if you are OCD, have to get them all, hear every backstory, learn every secret, then this will probably get on your nerves a bit.The other issue to this game is that some of the puzzles are unclear as to how you should go about solving them.  While this has only happened to me about maybe 15% of the puzzles in the game, it is still frustrating to look up the answer and say to yourself 'How does that make sense?'.  The game does give hints if you get the puzzle wrong, but sometimes the hints aren't that clear.  With some trial and error, you should be ok though.Overall, I enjoyed this game.  I picked it up when it was $4 and would have gladly paid $20 for it.  The setting and plot were really unique and I liked all of the ghost mechanics that were added into the game.  It is definitely a game to play when you are looking to get a good story with some amusing puzzles.  I rate this game a 9/10.

												The only reason this game remains interesting is that there aren't that many detective titles around. However, beyond novelty it has little to offer. The investigation mechanics have potential but are way to limited to be engaging. There is little thinking required. It usually comes down to clicking on all clickable things in the area and than choosing the relevant information. It is a straightforward process, as long as you don't overthing things. Your character (and everyone else for that matter) and quite dumb and you will often connect dots way quicker than game wants you to. The final reveal surprises only because of how silly it is.Also the is something of a stealth combat mechanics, probably due to devs or producers not being confident in their product. It sucks but doesn't take too much time.

												The game is about a cop who dies but cannot moves on until figures out who his murderer is. While ghost aspect surely adds a twist to the game, this is basically an adventure game with a lot of walking and listening. There is also some sort of a fighting sequence but it loses it's charm after a while and you start wishing it never existed in the first place. Story, voice acting and characters are quite cool, also the game is arguably bug-free. However, the game is short (I usually hang around a lot in games but even I finished it in 9 hours).Conclusion:FACTS:~ The game has a lot of talking and solving puzzles in it. If you want pew pew bang bang kinda game this isn't for you~ Relatively shortPROS:+ Great voice acting+ Great story+ Great atmosphere and characters+ You can actually use ghost powers (possesion, passing through solid objects etc)+ Nicely placed collectables (so they actually makes sense)+ Not a lot of bugsCONS:- The fights get boring fast and you feel like they're a burden- Investigations are kinda easy

												This is one of those games which gets murdered by so called highly educated gaming reviewers but they are stuck in AAA world. Now the game is not perfect, especially with nvidia surround which requires to install flawless widescreen but once that is taking care of, you are on for a very interesting and different game. It is not an action game but a more relax investigation game. You do have to fight some demons but honestly, I could have done without it as it does not bring anything. So, gameplay wise, very basic, a bit cluncky (probably related to the nvidia surround), but all the investigations, the historical aspect of salem, all the legends, this game has a lot to offer if you can appreciate the style. I would highly recommend it and also take the time to do all the investigations, this is where a lot of the gametime is. One thing, the first investigation is a bit slow but please, go past it and you will see why people enjoyed it.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												A brilliant tale of modern murder with a foothold in the Salem witch trials. As someone who loves typical "Who did it!?" type games, I found it great that it didn't hold your hand all the way through. The voice acting was top quality and believable, the humanization of the characters through actions and interactions were very smooth. My only qualm with the game is that when Ronan has to make his way hastily somewhere you'd expect for him to jog/run/sprint out of the cutscene, instead he just takes a leisurely swagger while puffing on his cigarette. It doesn't give you that sense of urgency that the storyline is trying to portray. I'm glad I didn't buy it at full price (50% off) because it was quite a short story/game, but for the $15 I did pay it was worth it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I would label this as a must buy on sale game. The game itself is a rather interesting take on a detective game, where you are a murdered cop trying to solve his own murder at the hands of a serial killer, so that he can move on to the afterlife and be with his wife. Gameplay mainly consists of investigating crimescenes for clues, and then drawing conclusions based on what you find. There are also ghost abilities, like being able to possess people to read their thoughts, or make electronics turn on. There is also a minor element of combat, as there are demons that will attempt to consume you unless you sneak up on them and destroy them first.The story is engaging, the voice acting is solid, and the movement and game mechanics are well designed and fluid. The ending is solid and satisfying as well. Why only just on sale? It's a relatively quick play through, with no replay value. Once you have made it to the end, the story is complete and there is no reason to revisit it.

												I got this pretty cheap and I still couldn't really get myself to complete it. The incentive to persue the main objective just wasn't there, on top of that the game is repetitive, clunky and lacks entertaining gameplay. It's a psuedo-detective game, though it holds your hand and never lets you "fail", which essentially means if you get an answer wrong you just try again, and again, and again until you are correct. I got a bit excited when the enemies were introduced to the game, the so-called "demons", but they are very easy to kill and the excitement quickly turned into annoyance, as the game would often toss a "kill the demons" sections at you, which aren't scary or hard, but just annoying (like filler to extend the game if you will).I stopped playing the game after the "asylum" part because it got boring. I'm just glad I didn't buy this at full price.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												I was a bit skeptical about this game after the reviews I saw but after 5 hours of playing it is a solid game. There is barely any action, it's more of a L.A Noire without the gun fights or similar to a sherlock holmes game. The story really sucked me in though, the basic premise is a mysterious killer has murdered you and now you have to find a way to solve the case. I love detective games like this where you have to find clues and piece together the story.The gameplay is good, theres nothing to really say, its fairly basic. The game does have some puzzle solving but its mostly about the story and solving this case. There are other smaller cases in the game that you can solve along the way optionally.I have run into a few bugs here and there where I've had to reload my last checkpoint because something didn't load in properly or the game was stuck. It has only happened twice in my 5 hours of play so they are few and far inbetween.Bottom line, if your a fan of mystery and puzzle solving, you'll love this game. Do not expect an action, think sherlock holmes.  But there is a very good story that will suck you in.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Albeit a rather short game (I completed it in a mere six-seven hours) I enjoyed this game. Is it flawless? By no means. The enemies are very easy to defeat once you get the hang of avoiding detection, and the final boss is a bit of a let-down. In spite of this, the idea of a detective solving his own murder while trying to deduce the identity of the Bell Killer is very interesting. I enjoyed doing the detective work and finding the connection between the various clues, and interacting with Bell Killer victims as well as other ghosts I encountered during the gameplay. Discovering clues to other unrelated murders was also very enjoyable and added a bit to my gametime just for searching for these clues. The connection to the Salem Witch Trials (a mark in history I always found fascinating) was also right up my alley.All in all, I give this game a slightly-above-average score of 7/10, and recommend it for gamers who don't mind an interesting, although short, game.
