number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												Following in the footsteps of Quantic Dream, the developer of Fahrenheit, Heavy Rain, and Beyond Two Souls, Airtight Games have developed a AAA Adventure title - a genre that usually doesn't mix with the sheeple of the current generation. Unlike high octane experiences with tons of explosions and buildings collapsing, adventure games have one goal: to tell a story.And boy, does Murdered: Soul Suspect tell a story. You play as Ronan, a wise-cracking police detective hot on the tail of Salem, Massachusetts' latest serial murderer: the Bell Killer. Just as you're about to apprehend the suspect on the top floor of a dilapidated apartment building the tables are turned and Ronan and his "I'm a toolbag" fedora fly out of the window, falling to the ground and becoming the newest victim of both fashion and the Bell Killer. But instead of carting off to the afterlife, Ronan's soul remains tethered to this world by his unresolved business with the Bell Killer. Now, Ronan must use his new ghostly abilities to solve his own murder.The game immediately starts by holding your hand. Telling you exactly which buttons to press and which linear corridor to travel down. Fortunately, it doesn't stay that way for long. The game quickly opens up into an open world exploration game, and you can hunt down clues all across Salem pertaining to your own death, the other victims of the Bell Killer, the Killer himself, and your family members you left behind. As a detective, you must piece together the clues at your own scene of murder and any future murder scenes to discover who the Bell Killer truly is. Sadly, the clues are very easy to discover. Glowing with a supernatural light from across the street, it's never particularly challenging to figure out exactly what happened, and the Phoenix Wright style of click on X-clue to solve Y-mystery is overused, cliche, and simple-minded. You're never actually punished for getting it wrong, nor does the game continue on assuming you're right until you find yourself alone with the wrong person like in Kara no Shoujo. The game just lets you click randomly until the mystery is solved. While I understand that this is one of the only AAA detective titles and Square-Enix took a massive risk in publishing a game that would be almost universally hated by the current braindead population, it still feels a bit too casual for my tastes.It turns out much of Salem's deceased population are also tied to this world, and they make up much of the side-quests. Discover what ties them to this world so they can move on. But not everyone can be saved. You can speak with every ghost, and possess every living human and read their thoughts - a novel idea in theory - but the dense population of both living and dead combined with the watered down sayings makes the world feel bland, as you randomly go through all the recycled phrases in hopes of some refreshing monologue in their head.Thankfully, the open world is anything but bland. The rustic yet modernized city alone is fantastic to walk through, but as a ghost you can see ghostly imprints of past structures. The burning remains of buildings long since erased from the timeline, wrecked cars and ghostly pileups, horse carts overturned, ghostly trains doomed to repeat their final travels, civil war era field hospitals and mass graves from immigrants with the bubonic plague, even puritan era torture devices used in the witch hunts that Salem is so popular for. The developers did their research before making this world, and it feels fantastic and believable.The open world aspect plays out a lot like a Metroid or Castlevania game, or most recently the Batman Arkham games. A wide variety of open world yet enclosed cells linked together. Unlock new ghostly powers and travel back to old places to uncover new clues and sidequests. Walk through walls, teleport across gaps, or possess people and animals to reach inaccessable areas. There are even obligatory stealth sections, where souls, trapped on this plane of existence, never moving on due to their unfinished business, have transformed into soul eating husks of their former selves, and you must sneak past them with the aid of your casual gamer wallhacks allowing you to see the enemy through walls so you can plan your stealth route. Once again, it never dips into "difficult" territory, and the closest thing you get to action is a couple of quick time events. I suppose they implemented this mechanic to try to entice some CODers into trying a new genre, but it ends up feeling tacked on. There are few stealth instances in the game, thankfully, but it's so poorly implemented it ends up hindering the experience.Now to talk about the elephant in the room. As anyone should expect from innovative ideas and a new intellectual property, especially in such a niche genre, this game was almost universally panned by critics. I don't often take the time to formally recommend games, unless I feel like injustice was served and the game isn't getting the recognization it deserves. While this game is as casual and simple as a detective game could possibly be, it's got other things going for it. The ending is fanastic, and the shocking revelation that every detective story needs comes unexpected and fast. It's worth playing to the end to see how nicely all the themes get wrapped up. And like I said, the game world is awe-inspiring both in scope and in detail. There may not be shooting mechanics, and the title isn't proceeded by 10: Modern Warfare Reloaded, so naturally the braindead pus spewing mass that is IGN won't like it, and neither will the Michael Bay fanboys that so devotedly follow it because they can't have an intelligent thought of their own volition. But this game provides a lot of ingenuity and new, refreshing ideas, proving that regardless of execution, Airtight games has what it takes to reach new heights in the future. Square Enix sees it. And I see it. I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This is an interesting murder mystery adventure game.  While it has some "action" components, it's closer to being a point and click adventure game.  Playing as the ghost of a detective, you have to search through various areas of town for clues about your killer.  I liked the depth of the story and it had enough twists to keep you on your toes.With that being said, I do have a couple of gripes about the game.  Firstly, the enemies.  The "demons" (which I would have personally called wraiths given how they're designed, but whatever) feel like they were tacked into the game as an afterthought by some exec in a suit that decided the game needed some action to make it fun.  This in fact does not equal fun.  I literally groaned and rolled my eyes every time I heard the sound of them being zoned into an area.  They're not hard to kill or anything, you just use some stealth type gameplay to sneak up behind them and do what amounts to a 1 step quicktime event to kill them off.  Even when you fail, they still won't necessarily kill you since you can run and hide until they go back on their short patrol route.  I never died from them at any point.  Once you kill all of them off in that particular area, they never respawn (thankfully).  I found their presence interrupted the flow of the game and was just a major annoyance.  I feel like the game would have flowed a whole lot better if they'd removed them completely and just left it as a straight mystery game.My second problem, the clue system.  This one is a bit bigger since it's the main focus of the game.  Searching for clues works sketchy at times.  If you get too close to one of the clues or have it not quite lined up on your view, you won't get prompted to press they button to get it.  This happened a whole lot more than I would have liked.  Given how the majority of the clues don't glow or give any indication that it's what you need to be looking at, it can lead to a lot of frustrated wandinger back and forth in the same area trying to figure out what you missed.  Also, once you have your clues gathered, you often have to patch 2-3 of those clues together into an "answer" for the current question you're trying to answer.  While the majority of them make sense, there were a few I ended up spamming through all of the clues to try to get the correct combination.Play time for me was around 8 hours total.  This included me collecting 90-95% of all collectibles, reading every clue that I got, watching the ghost stories for the 100% collections I had, and listening to nearly all of the spoken text each random person has to say when you possess them.  If I'd wanted to reach 100% collectibles without a walkthrough, I could have probably added on a few more hours for wandering back and forth for an eternity trying to find the ones I missed.Overall, this is a decent adventure game that's worth a look.To sum the rest of this up:+ Stylish looks+ Good voice acting and sounds+ Solid story that makes you want to keep playing- Clue system is iffy at times- Combat/enemies are annoying and probably shouldn't have been put in at all

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I got the game on sale and I think it was okay, but the full price is ridiculous. I like the game but it's not worth the full price and you should go through more reviews or gameplays even if it's on some 50 % off.I'd say most of the game is okay. And that's exactly the word. It's not great but it's not bad either. The general feeling when you finish the game will probably be something like... yeah, I had fun but it could (and should) have been much more fun.The story is fine but not breathtaking. It uses a lot of clichés but what really makes it dull is that there are too few characters. It's a detective story and you have like two possible suspects, not much mystery there. The detective part is... ehm. You collect clues and then you are supposed to draw some conclusion. Unfortunatelly, all you need to do is to click on the most obvious stuff you can and it's usualy the right answer. Sometimes, you even "discover" something you (as a player) must have thought before you started investigating because it's so flippin obvious.The stealth and fights with demons are really easy once you get a hang of it. Not much to say about it, the stealth parts could have been great but they ended up just dull. The demons are really creepy though, they look a bit as if they were dancing... but they wanna eat you... creepy.There are many collectibles. Some of them add to the story, which is great. Each area of the game has a ghost story which plays only if you find all related collectibles. These are great. Unfortunatelly, many collectibles just give you an achievement and that's is annoying. I also ended up with one or two collectibles missing in some catogories which brings me to...The saving system. It works fine, there are autosaves and even if you die, you dont lose much progress. But there is no way to make a hard save and once you reach a certain point in the game, you cannot enter most areas. So if you dont have all collectibles by the endgame, you will not get them unless you play again. And even then you'd have to go through almost the whole game because areas of the game open as you progress in the story. The few puzzles you encounter are really easy. You have some great mechanics (possessing people and cats, messing with electronics to make people move and get you through areas you cannot cross) but the creators really didnt use all the potential. I know puzzles weren't the point of the game but they could have add a lot of fun to the gameplay.I generally enjoyed the game, it's has a lot of genuine creepiness in it and it's mostly fun. But it gets repetitive even of it's a rather short game (I think I have like 12 hours with almost all collectibles, I think people do it faster) and you will be left with the feeling you expected more from it.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I would definitely recommend this game. BUT - My boyfriend and I bought it to play when it was 25% off. I would recommend waiting until it comes up as a daily deal for that or less. I DO however, love the "who dun it?" aspect of it, and they definitely captured that well. All in all, they build up throughout the entire game until you feel certain you know "who dun it" but there's a nice little twist to the game in the end. If you're smart, you'll pretty much pick up on exactly what's going on about the first hour or two while you're playing, but it still keeps you interested. It took me 14-ish hours to finish because I went slowly and looked for all the collectibles - of which there are a TON (and I still missed some!) The neat thing is that each area you find yourself in has its own collectibles and once you get them all it tells a story for that area. There are a few miniature side cases that let you aid other spirits in moving on. These are interesting too. This was definitely a game worth playing, and has some replayability to it due to all the collectibles and maybe if you want to finish it with 100%, but otherwise it's more of a 'play through thoroughly once and enjoy' type of game. The only aspect that I found tedious was the 'demons' you had to fight. As I've seen a few other reviews state, the demons became more of a nuisance than anything. They were put in most likely as to have SOME form of combat, (as there isn't any otherwise) so I understand the point, but they get tiring after a while. That definitely didn't stop me from playing however. I give the game a 80/100 due to the demons and the fact that it's not really replayable. Definitely scary at some points and definitely atmospheric. I LOVE horror stories so it was right on the money. I definitely enjoyed the historical aspects of the game too. Great background.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												Wanted this game since I saw it on Steam but got a bit cautious when I saw that many people were giving it bad reviews.Now that it's on sale I bought it and finished the game. My Opinion: Definitely worth buying. At least on sale.Also you might want to consider useing a Gamepad / XBOX 360 Controller for playing.So Murdered[..] is a Story Driven game, making gameply rather linear. There are some side quests but nothing that yould keep you from your main quest for too long. Everything has a voice over and the lips of the animated characters are (to some degree) synced with that is said.In terms of being a ghost detective you have a rather minimalistic set of ghost powers like walking through walls (some inner building walls), posessing people in order to read their very repeteative and simple minds and sometimes triggering some memories.The thing that strikes one the most is that if you are inside someone and you try triggering a response you don't get a voice-acted "Why the **** am I thinking that?" respone but simply a text message saying "not the right clue" - which is rather boring. The "Combat System" is basically describeable with "keep-out-of-sight" and "hope-the-system-triggers-the-backStab-and-I-can-banish-that-demon" - not that there would be a lot of that but still, it gets annoying because you have to "backstab" those demons and if you have played any other game with such a feature (eg. Vampire TMB) you might know that triggering a backstab on a moving target has its difficulties.The main part of the game is the detective part, which means searching for clues and puzzing them together. The thing here is also that if you try to puzzle clues together that are of minor or no importance you get just a message stating that that clue was not the right one. And you may eliminate all your not right clues untill only those not not right remain.Still it was fun to play (for the most part) and I really liked the story.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Lots of ambition, poor implementation.  What initially drew me in was the premise of the game:  A murder mystery ghost story who-done-it.  Instead, you find yourself trapped in a luke warm, predictable storyline with little flair.  The investigation system, the setting and the like?  They are good ideas poorly implemented.  There's only ever one soulution for each investigation, you know exactly how many clues they are, and it's very easy to figure out what happened in each situation before you conclude each investigation.  Solving a case means finding all the clues and then selecting the "correct" ones to move on.  The only difficulty in each investigation comes from trying to figure out which clues the developers wished you to reference in each investigation (the objectives aren't always clear).  After a few investigations, you pick up how the devs intended things to go, and it's basically a no-brainer from there.There's much more that I could go on about:  enemy encounters that can't decide if they are confrontational or stealth based, the very limited "open" world, and more.  Instead, let's take a look at what might have been.  The most depressing fact about the game is that you can easily see how this could have been a much better, very different game if they simply refined the experience.  Imagine:  a realized world with multiple fully fleshed out characters and places to explore.  Imagine:  being able to guess incorrectly on an investigation and wasting precious time following a false lead while there's a killer on the loose.  Imagine:  characters changing (killed, alienated and the like) based on your decisions.  Imagine:  multiple endings based on the decisions you've made.  Imagine:  meaningful sidequests that, while optional, might also give you access to different powers, resources and people.All of that just serves to make the whole experience more depressing.  If I could think this up not even halfway through the game, how could have the developers missed an opportunity like this?  Lack of budget/time/inspriation/testing?  Such a wasted opportunity!

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I was pretty excited about this game when I saw trailers and gameplay about it, but when it was released I didn't have the money to buy it and the reviews I saw for it was saying that it wasn't the most compelling game released. But I recently got it when it was on sale and I have to say I really enjoyed it. This game is different and I think thats what I really liked about it, I mean how often in a game can you go ahead and walk through walls and possess cats? The town of salem is a perfect place to set a supernatural story like this one, its so awesome going through the town to find out about the town's infamous past. If you really wanted to you could spend your time going around and collecting the enormous amount of collectibles which include information about the town and charcters. As for the detective part of the game its ok, it isn't the hardest as the game is pretty lenient, if you guess the wrong answer it gives you two other tries at getting the right answer. Other than the detective work you will also find yourself hiding and taking out demons with stealth which breaks up the gameplay a bit. The story and the investigation of your death is actually damn interesting as it has you guessing who could be your potential murderer. If you were considering getting this game I would recommend it, although I would suggest that you don't expect a action packed game, this game requires less violence and your brain. I personally wouldn't buy this game at full price though, its a bit on the shorter side as it took me 7 hours to complete, I still have collectibles to get but I know some people choose not to collect them. But if you're interested by ghosts, witches and solving murders then this is your game...

												This "game" is one of the worst I've ever "played".  Even if free, it's not worth the time you'd spend.  Certain elements of the game make it clear that the game was rushed to publication, like the "mysteries" that you solve for random ghosts, which appear only in the first two areas and give you no reward whatsoever.  The game mechanics are shady and boring, like when you have to put together three clues and they tell you to put them in chronological order even though the clues have nothing to do with time.  Most of the time I could figure out what they wanted but by and large it was guesswork.  The game itself is only 3 or 4 hours of real gameplay with a great deal of padding in the form of hidden collectables, most of which also do not give you any reward except for the "scary stories" which feature excruciating voice acting and are a giant waste of time.I wish I had the kind of guts Square Enix has to publish this piece of garbage and demand 50 bucks for it.  Do not buy it, do not play it, and remember this the next time you want a Square Enix game.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												This is a dificult review. The basic idea is great. The graphics are ok. The mainstory is good. All up for a recommendation of this game. But there are some bits that are downright wrong or just killing your fun.The plus sides:The main story is really good. No masterpiece but good and with some twits here and there.You can posses and run around with a cat which is greatThe world in a mixture of ghosty past and present is nicely done and great to explore.The downsides:Some side missions are what feels like "Ideas that been tossed aside and then used anyway..."The rather short main story is massively expanded by collectiong hidden objects. more than half the time you will belooking for hidden collectibles.Some puzzles are... I am not sure if they are meant as a joke? You want to pick up a key that you been looking for. Then you see a fork a knife and a key and hear the sound of a fallen key and have to click the object that makes that sound... what??!?Then there are those Deamons who are silly hard and just feel like yet another obstacle to expand the time you need to get through this game.All in all this is a great idea put into a very short game and then filled with nonsense stuff to expand it.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												If you go into this game expecting a sweeping epic or a play time creeping towards triple figures then you're going to have a bad time.What this game does have is a short but engaging story (I finished it in 6 hours), a world with plenty of nooks, crannies and collectables to keep the treasure hunters among you happy and characters that managed to make me either care about them or dislike them as the developer intended.As far as replay value goes, I doubt I'll be loading it up for another playthrough right away but I can see this becoming the sort of game that I'll fire up several months down the line when I don't fancy playing any of the shiney new games I've splashed out on at the time. I picked this up on a 50% flash sale, and that price feels about right for what I got. I think I'd feel let down if I'd paid full price.So, to reduce all that to a number, I'd give it a solid 7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Interesting story.  It is like reading a book.  A bit short as I finished it in one afternoon.  No surprise clues at the end, you can figure out the mystery as the story progresses (which is a good thing).  I had guessed a few of the plot aspects before they happened, but I don't find that a negative.  It happens.The game concentrated on the story (which I liked) rather than combat with some story thrown in.  This may not appeal to some.The game is short.There were bad parts.  It was clear that the end was thrown together.  Not that the story didn't complete.  That was fine, but there were four major broken game development commandments.  Two appear right at the end.1.  You cannot save the game.  Ever.  It is a port to PC from a console.  There are automatic progress points.  The good thing is they do seem to happen often.2.  Flash sequences.  Some people like them, I don't.3.  Repeated cutscene (happens at end) when you fail (which will happen).  You can skip it after it starts, but forcing one to even go into it is bad.4.  Sudden timed sequence.  There is exactly one (two parts of one timed sequence) and none of the rest of the game has one.  It is short (the timed sequence), too. I'd recommend the game if you like to play a short story.  This is not a combat centered game.  It is a mystery and in that aspect it was fun to figure out the mystery.  Get it on sale.  Not worth a normal 50-60 dollar price tag.I'd like to see more products like this rather than the overdone shooters and what not, so I realise my suggestion to get it on sale isn't going to encourage more such development.I'm going to give it a yes but read the caveats in this article.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is probably best described as a story driven puzzle game. You don't shoot anything and the only time you feel like you are in danger is when you have to face demons that you can destroy by walking up behind them and perform a takedown action.The story revolves around a cop, name Ronan, who dies on duty chasing a serial killer and he can't ascend to the next plane of existence until his business on the mortal realm is resolved, so you have to hunt down the serial killer by solving crime scenes to determine what to do next.Overall I enjoyed the game and story, although once you finish you probably won't touch the game again unless you are trying to obtain 100% of the trophies. My recommendation is to buy the game when it is cheap, maybe around the $20 range or less.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
'Kid' - Ronan, Murdered: Soul suspect

I like this game, it's not my typical game, but still I like it. It's a combination of a good point-and-click game and say 'The Walking Dead'. Most of the time you need to find the right place and choose the right dialouge, but then there are times you need to take action towards people and demons-FAST. You could always sneak past them aswell (but what's the fun in that;) )

There are alot of side-missions you can do (Achivements, achivements, achivements!), but they are not needed.

At times the music and surroundings makes the game way creepy and scary. The graphics are Amazing and they've really nailed the voices. 

Is it difficult? Not really..you learn the controls pretty quick. I reccomend this, give it a try and let me know what you think and ask me if you have any questions.

Oh, and by the way... 'meow' (if you've played the game you now what I'm meowing about ;) )

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Absolutely loved the game. I hate horror but saw the trailer and had to play. Got the xbox version for the holidays and found the controls a bit difficult so I bought the PC version and could not put it down. Was excited but kind of disappointed when it was over.Really wish there was a way to play it over and get either a different end or extra content, or better yet I wish there was a sequel following Joy, a different ghost, or a prequel following Ronan when he was alive.Pros:-Great story with a twist and great score, really put me on edge and I don't like horror so A+ for making me like that-Loved the quality and range of the voice acting-Third person with fully mobile camera so it doesn't set off my vertigo-Well animated emotion-Enjoyable cutscenes (took me 12 hours to finish it, loved every minute and I was sad when it ended)-Really freaky demons that you can either play as is or modify the config file to play around (I couldn't handle the demons so that's what I did. They still freaked me out and I had to execute them but they weren't as huge of a hurdle with the modification)Cons:-No map (my xbox360 version had a code for a map included but it had expired so no map)-Very little if any replay value because the story is linear and additional material doesn't affect the story (aka no extra cutscenes). Once the game is over it runs through the credits and boots you out to the menu. If you try to continue from the menu once the game is done then it sends you back to the final checkpoint where you can't leave to explore the town for missing items-It felt so short, I was a bit taken aback when I realized that I was at the final scene-It didn't affect me but I found it funny that some of the character modeling overlapped (like his badge or hand would enter his thigh during some cutscenes)9.5/10 for me on this game

It reminded me a lot of like Batman: Arkham Asylum but without any melee fighting (for the record I hated batman for that so I was okay with this change), and with more things to track down (which, I'm okay with, I like stat progression and holy moly so many achievements, but it was rather bewildering at first because it just slams you with tons of new things all at once).If you ever played those Scooby Doo platformers on consoles between 2000-2005 then you'll probably like this enough that it's worth $15, like one of those used games you buy at Gamespot/EB-Games and you enjoy it for a time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is an interactive movie, with only mildly interesting story and generally mediocre gameplay. The supposedly interesting mechanics, like walking through walls or possessing people are either confusing, or only useful in specified places. The combat (or stealth with QTE takedowns to be precise) turns stale after only the second encounter. The meat of the game, the investigations, are also lackluster. They limit player interaction to mostly looking at stuff Kim Jong-un style, give no failure state and so become devoid of any meaning or satisfaction.And then there's the truckload of collectibles - checking every corner and wall for them quickly becomes rather irritating than satisfactory and draws attention away from the storyline. For me, as a stupid completionist they doubled the gametime of around 4 to 5 hours while also making it almost insufferable.Overall, I can't think of a person to recommend it to. Maybe if you would just ignore the collectibles? Even then, worth a couple bucks, tops.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect review.Comrades, this is not a game, certainly not a detective one. The puzzles are not really puzzles and there are no options of getting it wrong. The game is quite short, only has few side quests, and three types of enemies (demons, train and controls).The thing is that as a detective game Murdered: Soul Suspect fails, it fades away into the shadows if compared to Sherlock Holmes and L.A. Noire.The game play is very basic, pretty much point and click on clues and then select the most relevant one. As such on a gameplay and mental levels the game is not challenging or stimulating at all.The story is simple and the plot can be guessed, but it is not a cliché one.I can't recommend this as a game, however I will recommend this as an interactive story if available to purchase below $7Overall score 5/10For more reviews joinhttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/ogrreview/

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												A dark ghost-detective adventure story about ghost detective searching for truth about his murder so he can leave this kind of limbo.Game is good, this game doesn't fit all, so i understand a lot negative reviews in games related media.Pros:- slowly evolving dark detective story- nice unusual gaming mechanisms (as ghost you can possess people, you can attract them via "poltergeist" ability, you can walk through walls)- classic adventure mechanism - find clues yourself (which often means to watch everywhere and see if it is possible clue or not) and think about them (at every investigation you have to pick one to three from collected best fiting clues which are leading on)- dark atmospheric locations of Salem city- nice soundtrack- skippable EVERY cutscene and video (there is a lot flashbacks or memories videos etc.)- not bad rendered characters- you can even possess a cat! :)- daemons - in late gameplay i hated them (only real enemy during gameplay), but they can be scary, which is good, at the end i loved locations with daemons- almost no bugs or glitches (encountered only one during whole gameplay, some kind of stucked movement, character started walk to the left forever, but leave and enter location helped /i played it on keyboard and mouse so it was no stucked controller or so)Cons:- i can imagine much wider possibilities with such nice game mechanics, it looks like someone tied dev's hands- there are a few side investigations, but i could imagine a bit larger world with this setting and with some kind of open-world possibilitiesNice story, if you're into adventures, detectives, ghosts and mystery, go for it (8€ was worth it). It easily could be "detective simulator" packed into ghost-story. Lot of people complaining about every investigation has "same gameplay" - you go find clues and pick the right ones to solve investigation (or to get another additional clue) - well, as detective main character i find it natural you are visiting crime scenes douing your own investigation.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												For what it is worth, this game is not bad. In fact, it has a decient story to it.It is clearly unpolished in many ways, from the fact that Ronan always enters an area the same way, even if the story should indicate a sense of urgency to the fact that many of the ghosts you come across are merely 2D, and fade to prevent you from being able to tell easily. At one point you are wandering through a quarantined area and you can talk to a ghost of someone who had caught TB. For the time of the event you should expect her to be dressed in early 1900s style clothing, but she is wearing something clearly modern.i really want to like this game, but it is unsatisfying.Pros would be that the game does have a decient story, the main characters are developed enough to be believable, even if at times they do act very out of character in attempt to push the story forward.Cons, the gameplay gets seriously repetative. Every area is exactly the same things. Collect this, investigate this, guide this person, find a way around this, rinse, wash, repeat. Areas involving the demons are simply annoying. The puzzles are overly simplistic and many of the clues are difficult to find. Do not be surprised if you find yourself looking over the same room half a dozen times because they made things exceptionally obscure.For what it has, i am glad the game is short. Anything more than 7.5 hours and it would have become far to repetative and annoying to bother with. That and this game has little replay value.Why am i still recommending this game? Because if you can get it on sale for something under 10 dollars, i think the story alone is worth it. Anything more, and it would be best to pass this up for something a bit better.i feel bad for anyone who payed even 25$ for this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Murdered Soul Suspect has quickly jumped to my list of most underrated games of 2014.  A solid mystery yarn with great atmosphere and a gripping story, it's a sure bet for any gamers looking for more story-driven fare.Like similar titles (Beyond Two Souls, LA Noire, The Walking Dead), MSS operates on the philosophy that story trumps action.  The gameplay consists almost entirely of investigating scenes to piece together the central mystery, with some stealth elements wedged in for good measure.Everything is fairly well-done gameplay-wise, though the investigations can become a little repetitive later on into the game.The story is the focus here, though.  The plot (which I won't spoil here), is like Patrick Swayze's "GHOST" had a baby with LA Noire.  Overall, enough to keep you going through the game.Not that it needs to keep you going for long.  I finished the game in just over 5 hours.  I don't, however, feel cheated.  If purchased at sale price, it's a great game that's worth your time and money.  I'm going to be revisiting it eventually because replaying would be so quick.So if you're looking that's light on action and heavy on story, check this one out!  I really enjoyed it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												less a videogame, and more an interactive movie on rails. frequently your only input will be to choose the order in which you ask someone a set of predetermined questions as you investigate a series of murders. combat with demons - the only enemies in the game, outside of cutscenes - feel more like a worthless speedbump than an entertaining mechanic. however, if you can force yourself through the tedious, mediocre gameplay, you'll find a fantastic whodunit that will keep you guessing right up until the end.  the overall concept, voice acting and art direction are absolutely superb, but unfortunately, poor execution, clunky controls, and repetitive, thoughtless "scene investigations" will probably bore and frustrate most players into quitting before they get all the way through what is otherwise a great story. it's worth a buy on the merits of the story alone, but expect some tough slogging through the mud to get all the way to the end. buy it on sale, ignore the terrible gameplay and stick it out to the end to watch a neat psychological thriller / whodunit crossover, and then uninstall it forever.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Murdered Soul Suspect is a 3rd Person Ghost Walking Simulator. You are a cop, who has been murdered in the intro and must now try to solve your own murder (and several others). As you can barely interact with real worlds objects, you mainly walk around and look at things. From time to time you have to answer questions about the things you looked at, these questions are normally either embarrassing easy or the answers do not make much sense.There are some nice "ghost mechanics" included, mainly walking through walls, but they do not carry the game for its full (or half or quarter) length.So, what else can carry a game with stale gameplay?Visuals? They are nice, but no unique sales point.Music? There are mostly mysterious sound effect.That leaves us with: Story. And the build-up is great. Your dead cop character has a checkered past and is full of hurt, you have your run of the mill serial killer to follow, your teenage side kick complains a lot etc. The first third of the story is good, then not a lot happens, then a few foreseeable plot twists and it ends with ... a deus ex machina. In a nutshell:+ really good concept, no open end- gameplay is mainly walking around looking for stuff- story starts out good, then becomes less so and leaves you unsatisfied

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
 Too Long Won't Read Verdict Bargain Bin - Buy this game at a discount price. The story is solid, but not mindblowing. I enjoyed the ride and the atmosphere was great. The gameplay mechanics are nothing to write home about and the "action" sequences are annoying obsticles. The game runs for about 5-6 hours which can be extended by hunting all the little collectibles and enjoying the snippets of content that brings. Overall it was an enjoyable experience. The 'Tails I played this game from start to finish in two separate nights. The game immediately pulled me into it's atmosphere of supernatural mystery and maintained it's low hanging horror throughout. I'm glad it did not try to be a horror game; it was smartly realized to keep that element very passive which just supported the backbone of the game's overall flavor. This particluar "flavor" is set in Salem, Massachusetts and plays heavily off of the historical witch trials. You get to experience this through the character known as Ronan who dies in the first sequence of the game.  Ghost Detective...ooOOoOOOOOOooo . In order to avoid spoilers I won't say anymore about the story than that.Gameplay-wise this game relies on an investigation mode where you have to search specific areas for clues to piece together a shard of the story. Sometimes finding all the clues in a given area is really easy, othertimes they aren't all so obvious, but that's okay, beacuase you don't need to necessarily find all the clues to complete the investigation. Good design. There is a strange component to this core mechanic in the form of what seems to resemble a score system. It was never made really clear, but basically, whenever you have to put the final pieces of an investigation together a menu is brought up in which you usually have to choose three clues that explain that particular scene. At the bottom of this menu are three police badge shaped icons and whenever you make a mistake in choosing clues one of them goes away. However in my experience the badges will never drop below one and create no pressing incentive to just randomly click on all the clues until you get the right answer. Bad execution.The final main mechanic you will run into are these "stealth-action" sequences. You will occasionally run into areas that have demons blocking your progression. You must sneak behind them and perform a short series of QTEs to destroy them. I played this game with mouse and keyboard, and my expereince with these QTEs was frustrating to say the least. You start by holding R, then have to follow up with a combination press of W, A, S, or D + left or right mouse button. It is a little akward and to be frank they are QTEs which I already despise. I did run into some areas where these demons could be ignored and you can progress by just being sneaky, but not many. And when the demons see you, you have to go run into hiding spaces and then teleport between them when they search the hiding spaces. This entire mechanic is a bit akward and I don't feel it added to the game in a positive way. Bad design.The game doesn't have a whole lot more to offer mechanically, but it should be expected seeing as this is a very narritive focused game. So as I said above, I reccomend this game only at a discount.EDIT: Oh I forgot to mention. The final sequence to the game is irritating. You have a limited amount of time to figure out what to do and if you fail it takes you back two whole cinematics. Luckily cinematics can be skipped, but it was frustrating.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												I finally finished this game today and I'm finding it incredibly difficult to decide how to score/review it, since my thoughts about it are so mixed. I chose to give it a positive overall score because I don't feel it's a *bad* game per se, and it certainly does have an audience. I did enjoy the game, even while at the same time I had so many issues with it.Since I first heard about this game, I couldn't wait for it to come out. The premise sounded fantastic. Salem is very close to my heart IRL, and I'm inclined to adore any game that explores occult/supernatural themes in a unique way. And this game certainly did that. However, it just doesn't have the polish that it deserved, and I feel as though it doesn't give itself license to be what it is. In stark contrast to this is another game that came out this year with very similar themes and gameplay, which I found to be executed far more effectively. That game is the Vanishing of Ethan Carter, and it was made by a much smaller studio no less! Of course, these games did not invent detective games, however they explore mechanics that I haven't seen much of before. While I won't spend this whole review comparing the two games, I will say this: if you enjoyed the detective mechanic and occult themes here, do yourself a favor and look up the Vanishing of Ethan Carter as well.With that said, I did enjoy Murdered: Soul Suspect. Wandering around the streets of Salem as a ghost, deciphering clues and uncovering hidden remnants of the past is a fun and unique experience. The game looks great and plays smoothly, and the difficulty level is appropriate for the casual player, nothing quite too challenging. I also enjoyed the story, which wove together some pieces of Salem's darker past with modern times, as well as stories from in between. Exploring a Salem full of ghostly objects and remnants was an interesting idea, even if many of those objects were clearly just placed at random to place limits on the world. I didn't really feel like this is what an "in-between death realm" would look like - random boats and carts all over the place, the occasional demon grabbing for you and other dead people standing around that disappear when you get close. These effects start to feel more like decoration than a living world, which is a shame. This is Salem after all, there was such potential here. Some of the locations outside of the town proper were much more interesting, such as the cemetery. While you can roam around Salem (mostly) freely, at the end of the day, it's a very small place with a finite number of activities. And while walking through walls and objects never gets old, using your other ghostly abilities such as "possessing" living people does. 90% of the time, all you can do is read their thoughts, and most people have only 1 or 2 thoughts, neither of them interesting. After doing this a few times with different people, you'll hear the same thoughts over and over, and this feature will lose all of its appeal. Only very rarely do people's thoughts contribute to gameplay or add any interest to the story, mostly it's just a bore. A few times, the possession mechanic was used to inhabit and move through other characters, including a cat, which was very interesting. I would have loved more of this, it would have provided a bit more variety in gameplay and made the ability feel a bit more tangible. I'm also left wondering why the devs developed the ability to inhabit and move through a secondary character, but this was only used for a combined total of 30 seconds throughout the game. Much more potential for stealth here. Instead, all we can do is "poltergeist" objects like fax and soda machines while the other character runs around, and it's almost impossible to mess up.Which brings me to the other stealth mechanic, the demons. I did not like the demons at all. Very tedious and unnecessary piece of gameplay. This is what I meant when I said the game should embrace what it is, a detective game. Instead, it tried to add some action into the mix, with a half-hearted attempt at stealth mechanics. I love a good stealth game, in fact it's one of my favorite genres, but this was painful. The demons just wander around set courses, and you have to either slip by them or attack them with what is essentially a quick-time event. The only thing that makes this remotely challenging is that you have to press (if playing with keyboard and mouse) a random WASD key and either left or right mouse button at the same time. It just ends up feeling like a cheap attempt at adding challenge to a very boring mechanic. Essentially, the only weapon you have in this game is how fast you can press those keys. The demons don't change throughout the course of the game, and you don't develop any new abilities for dealing with them. They merely serve as padding to prevent you from getting from one area to the next too quickly. The "action" culminates in a very disappointing "boss battle" which strangely attempted to weaponize the game's detective mechanics. It all just felt very strange and unnecessary. Again, in contrast, VEC allowed itself to be a detective/exploration game without injecting unnecessary action, and as a result achieved a much more cohesive experience overall. Perhaps if M:SS had developed the stealth/action parts a bit more, it could have integrated that gameplay more effectively. But as it is, I felt the game would have been better off without it.M:SS does have a few other redemptive qualities that I want to mention. There are stories in the game that you uncover by finding objects and letters, and these, along with the main storyline, are what kept me playing. It is definitely fun, at least for me, to explore the various scenes and settings in the game and uncover the secrets of what happened here. Perhaps that is what this game does best - it allows you to unravel the story through experience rather than just telling you what happened. Many of the locations are great and kept me wanting to explore every last nook and cranny to make sure I didn't miss anything. Not all of the stories are interesting though. Most of the notes you'll find are sad journal entries written by the main character's wife. Both her and the main character himself are beyond boring and cliché. All of her journal entries are about how Ronan is such a bad boy, but she's irresistibly drawn to him nonetheless. She's afraid of him, but she loves him. If you've read one, you've read them all. It became disappointing to pick up a note and see her sad face on it. Ronan, however, is even worse. I just found him incredibly uninteresting and unlikeable. Keep on ghost-chain-smoking your ghost-cigarettes, Ronan. Most of the other characters and stories in the game were much more interesting, so at least there's that.Another gripe - where are all the witches? We're in Salem, and there are basically zero witches. Huge missed opportunity there. To this day, Salem has a thriving Witchcraft community, and it's an essential thread in the tapestry of the town for obvious reasons. While the story references the witches of old, I was left wanting more than that from this part of Salem. And further, for a ghost story full of demons set in a town famed for Witchcraft, there is no horror to this game at all. The only thing scary in this game is whether you'll continue to fail at QTEs and have to do them over and over again.Alright, I feel this review is just devolving into me listing off complaints about what I wanted this game to be, which isn't quite fair. There is much more I could say about why this is overall a decent game, but I would say that if this game piques your interest, if you want to try something different and aren't scared off by the mixed scores, then I'd say go for it. Get it when it's on sale and go in with low expectations, and you'll probably enjoy it. 6/10

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I would definitely recommend this game. BUT - My boyfriend and I bought it to play when it was 25% off. I would recommend waiting until it comes up as a daily deal for that or less. I DO however, love the "who dun it?" aspect of it, and they definitely captured that well. All in all, they build up throughout the entire game until you feel certain you know "who dun it" but there's a nice little twist to the game in the end. If you're smart, you'll pretty much pick up on exactly what's going on about the first hour or two while you're playing, but it still keeps you interested. It took me 14-ish hours to finish because I went slowly and looked for all the collectibles - of which there are a TON (and I still missed some!) The neat thing is that each area you find yourself in has its own collectibles and once you get them all it tells a story for that area. There are a few miniature side cases that let you aid other spirits in moving on. These are interesting too. This was definitely a game worth playing, and has some replayability to it due to all the collectibles and maybe if you want to finish it with 100%, but otherwise it's more of a 'play through thoroughly once and enjoy' type of game. The only aspect that I found tedious was the 'demons' you had to fight. As I've seen a few other reviews state, the demons became more of a nuisance than anything. They were put in most likely as to have SOME form of combat, (as there isn't any otherwise) so I understand the point, but they get tiring after a while. That definitely didn't stop me from playing however. I give the game a 80/100 due to the demons and the fact that it's not really replayable. Definitely scary at some points and definitely atmospheric. I LOVE horror stories so it was right on the money. I definitely enjoyed the historical aspects of the game too. Great background.

Not my type of game, but if you like the games listed at the top, you may enjoy it.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I'm not really sure why I liked Murdered: Soul Suspect, maybe it was because the investigation parts are just the right amount of challenging without relying on your ability to lip read the faces of the uncanny valley... I'm trying to avoid looking at you L.A Noire... Or perhaps it was the side quests, engaging side quests, where I actually felt like I was doing some good, that I was changing the game world for the better. Whatever it was I did enjoy Murdered: Shoal Suspect. I enjoyed it a lot and (silly name aside) I found myself gripped in a supernatural thriller, which had some level of adventure gameness to it, the controls were solid, the graphics reasonable, and the story (while a little predictable in places) did keep me glued to the screen wanting to find out what happened next, the ability to contribute to that story through the aforementioned side quests, and investigation moments probably helped keep me in during the boring bits.I did find the combat a little clunky, but the moments are so few and far between that it never became more than a minor annoyance, and immersion was spoiled somewhat by the sheer denseness of the player character, watching him piece together the motives of the antagonist was less Sherlock Holmes, and more Scooby-Doo.However maybe you really get off on being smarter than the character... Maybe that is the real reason I like Murdered: Soul Singer. Whatever your motivation for thinking about getting this game, I advise you to.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												I got this game from buying a new video card, and had heard good things about it before that. When I finally got to play it, the first thing that struck me was how much it felt like a console game. The world is very limited, and it feels like one is railroaded from crime scene to crime scene.Gameplay is limited to finding clues at each crime scene and then selecting the most relevant to "solve" the scene, with some side cases sprinkled in for flavour in between. Occasionally demons arrive and must be dealt with (or evaded), but this is very tedious and not fun (or challenging) at all.Adding insult to injury is the fact, that Interaction with the environment is extremely limited, and dialogue choices are non-existant. The game also isn't entirely free of bugs, which sometimes make it necessary to load an older saved game.What saves Soul Suspect from being a complete disappointment is the setting, in which the protagonist perceives both the mortal and the spirit realm. This does grow old after a while though, and there is absolutely nothing that could possibly add a level of suspension (while there is the occasional strained-strings-with-something-unspeakable-about-to-pop-out-of-nowhere-background music rest assured, nothing will actually happen).If I hadn't gotten this game for free I would most certainly feel that any amount of money spent would have been a complete waste. As far as crime games go they mostly revolve about finding and combining clues, and it is also the core mechanic of Soul Suspect. The execution, however, is so uninspiring (and sometimes insultingly simple), that I simply could not recommend this to anyone.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												A refreshing mystery game, light on action with some straight-forward navigational puzzles, and a solid narrative as far  as video games are concerned. There's some above average voice acting present here, with atmospheric and sometimes spooky visuals. The content and subject matter of Murdered: Soul Suspect is what makes it a breath of fresh air in a sea of violent action games.  How do people cope with their own deaths? You'll learn a lot about that subject if you take the time to talk to other ghosts in the game's world. Some are flat-out in denial, others have embraced it. Some are recently deceased, others are ancient ghosts, still troubled by their tragic (or not) fates. You'll encounter spirits that offer  side quests requiring you to help them figure out the circumstances  of how or why they died.  It's rather interesting if you're into that kind of thing.To nit pick, the game goes on for about an hour longer than it should, revisiting areas previously visited and therefore becoming a bit tedious, but the obligatory mystery genre twist at the end makes it worth it. There's no combat to speak of -- sometimes you have to dispatch "demons" which requires a bit of  stealth combined with quick time events -- that's the extent of Murdered: Soul Suspect's "action". These  scenarios are few and far between, but only serve to slow down your investigative process, and caused me to roll my eyes, particularly at the end of the game, when I just wanted to move forward with solving what I wanted to solve to complete the game. Murdured: Soul Suspect is not a perfect game but if you crave a break from shooting things in the face, instead gathering clues, solving mysteries and exercising the more analytical side of your brain, Murdered: Soul Suspect is for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												In short: Grab it if it's $15-20 or less, it's a unique steal for that price.Just finished this, really enjoyed it even though it was rough and clunky around the edges.The reviews paint it as a train-wreck of a game, but that's because they were comparing it to highly-polished 'AAA' fare out there. If you stack it up against something like Assassin's or The Last Of Us in terms of graphics, animation and mechanics, it doesn't look great, but at it's heart is some nice storytelling and a few fresh ideas.The 'combat' is basic and thankfully there's not much of it. Shouldn't take up more than 5% max of your game time.I had the most fun exploring the town and the locations, learning the history of the place and the stories of the various characters.Big shout outs to the moody, effective, original sound design (even if the mixing means that the cut-scenes are louder than the in-game sound).Biggest shout out of all to the writing and excellent voice acting & performances. Really puts a lot of modern games to shame, and artfully avoids the usual 'Japanese game' melodrama (I'm looking at you, Yakuza). Very understated for the video game, and very effecting. Quite touching at times.The biggest minus? You spend most of the game collecting clues, but once you finish the game you can't keep searching for the rest. Although it might make sense plot-wise... they should at least let you leave the last locations after restoring you final game save, to go 'clean up' before the final sequence. A very poor decision that leaves a bitter taste in your mouth at the end of a nice experience, especially for story fans who want to investigate and get all the clues. Granted, they warn you before you enter the last location that you won't be able to return, but this restriction shouldn't be there in the first place. Massive missed opportunity and we'll never get a patch to fix it, which is a massive shame. :(Anyway, regardless, the journey is great and stays a memorable experience despire this oversight. If this was a $15-$20 'indie' release, it would have been a solid 8/10 in the reviews, but came out as a full priced 'AAA' game and suffered because of it. Enjoy it for what it is - an unusually understated and restrained murder mystery with a lot of interesting fresh ideas and some great acting. Highly recommended, when it's on special... :)

												After seeing the trailer i was really eager to try the game as i am big fan of adventure games. After playing at friend for a few hours Sherlock Holmes: Crimes and Punishments, i was expecting something at least as good. But i was overall disappointed. What i liked about this game:- the story is really interesting  and the concept is newWhat i didn't like:- the clue system: although it has some interesting concepts (like possessing people), it get repetitive really fast. You just need to collect all the clues in each chapter- the stealth/sneak - the addition of demons is just annoying and useless, you just need to sneak behind them and do  quick-time sequence - the menu clearly shows that is a console port- the town could put emphasis on exploration, but seems dead (literally and figuratively) the NPC are always in the same place- the save system- i don't think checkpoints have a place in an adventure gameOverall: 65/100 I recommend playing this only if you don't have anything else to play. If you want a good detective-adventure game, try  Sherlock or L.A. Noire

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I have absolutely nothing but praise for this game. I just want to start this review by saying that.I'm not a massive horror video game fan. Hell, I can't even get through the first level of F.E.A.R. So when I first saw Murdered: Soul Suspect pop up as a pre-order at my local games store, I was fairly hesitant. Upon release, I was still hesitant, and decided against it. Then it popped up in the Steam Summer Sale, so I figured for half the price, why not? If I don't like it, no harm done. Luckily for me, I loved it.The atmosphere of the game is fantastic, the characters extremely well fleshed out (or spirited, I guess), and the story is amazing. You play as Ronan O'Connor, a detective with the Salem Police Department. The opening cinematic sees Ronan fall from a fourth floor window to the street below. After desperately trying to align his spirit with his body, the person who threw Ronan from the window, known only as the Bell Killer, appears. Using Ronan's own gun, the killer fires 7 round into him, and ends his life for good.Only, he doesn't end Ronan's afterlife, and this is where the fun begins. You play through the game trying to solve the mystery behind not only your own murder, but the murder of several young girls throughout the town. What follows is one of the most brilliant gaming experiences I have ever had the pleasure to play. Using an array of otherworldly abilities, and the assistance of a girl who can see and interact with Ronan, you embark on a mission to find the killer, and put your soul to rest.A special mention goes to the collectables throughout the game, especially those required to unlock short horror stories. These just upped the atmosphere of the game, and I felt really immersed in the world of modern day Salem. Whilst the game isn't overly long, it has been thoroughly enjoyable, and I recommend it to anyone who's played L.A. Noire, and seen the movie Ghost (with Patrick Swayze of course). This game, to me, felt like a mashup of those two instances of media, and Square-Enix really pulled it off.So, after all that text, do I recommend this game? Yes. Yes I do. And shame on all those who don't.

												Back hand clapping...I had to give up playing this today after the 30th time of trying to execute the same demon and forgetting that (unlike any other game) you have to hold the button down. For me this game is an endless cycle of: sneak up behind demon, press execute button, run away because "I" let them go (i.e. forgot to hold the button)...No option...Why for the love of god did they not include an auto hold on execute option in controls?! This awful command system is a game ruiner and all the hard work put into this game amounts to nothing because of it. It's very sad because I was enjoying the game. I have no problem sneaking up behind the demons but then in the heat of the moment I forget that it has a weirdly unique and bizarrely abnormal control system that has never been used in any other game. 3rd Party software needed?The only way I could play this was if I used a program like xpadder to make the button toggle or hold for a time, but having to use 3rd party software to overcome a badly thought out and poorly implemented control system is ridiculous (for a 3rd person game, not a flight sim).No patch?If they make a patch I for this I might play it but since having an unplayable game taking up lots of space on my hdd is a stupid idea,  I will be uninstalling it and wont know if there is a patch because I am not going to bother checking (in much the same way they didn't bother putting an alternative to their useless command system).

little collectables to wring out a bit more story but you’re not going to get much more.So the game took me about 8 hours (this is what steam has me clocked at) it may take you a bit less or a bit more if you’re like me and spend ages running round the place trying to find that one collectable you somehow missed.Also on the note of time the ending credits are unskippable and last for about 10 minutes and there is nothing after them it dumps you back on the title screen.So bugbears about the game (well other that the ending credits) it stinks of a console port (not as bad as some mind you) it’s a bit clunky there were several times where items that should have been intractable weren’t (like in the end scene I failed because I was one step to close to have the press E to interact pop-up show up) the FOV is a bit tight, then there is the chose by Square Enix to have combat in the game personally I don’t think it fit well but this is a personal choice thing but after a bit of searching every puzzle in the game) but I would have liked it better if they have closed this story off and had a sequel with a new propagandised as the story sets up the idea that ghost are made when you die and feel there is still stuff you need to do.So yes I recommend it but don’t expect too much from it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I have absolutely nothing but praise for this game. I just want to start this review by saying that.I'm not a massive horror video game fan. Hell, I can't even get through the first level of F.E.A.R. So when I first saw Murdered: Soul Suspect pop up as a pre-order at my local games store, I was fairly hesitant. Upon release, I was still hesitant, and decided against it. Then it popped up in the Steam Summer Sale, so I figured for half the price, why not? If I don't like it, no harm done. Luckily for me, I loved it.The atmosphere of the game is fantastic, the characters extremely well fleshed out (or spirited, I guess), and the story is amazing. You play as Ronan O'Connor, a detective with the Salem Police Department. The opening cinematic sees Ronan fall from a fourth floor window to the street below. After desperately trying to align his spirit with his body, the person who threw Ronan from the window, known only as the Bell Killer, appears. Using Ronan's own gun, the killer fires 7 round into him, and ends his life for good.Only, he doesn't end Ronan's afterlife, and this is where the fun begins. You play through the game trying to solve the mystery behind not only your own murder, but the murder of several young girls throughout the town. What follows is one of the most brilliant gaming experiences I have ever had the pleasure to play. Using an array of otherworldly abilities, and the assistance of a girl who can see and interact with Ronan, you embark on a mission to find the killer, and put your soul to rest.A special mention goes to the collectables throughout the game, especially those required to unlock short horror stories. These just upped the atmosphere of the game, and I felt really immersed in the world of modern day Salem. Whilst the game isn't overly long, it has been thoroughly enjoyable, and I recommend it to anyone who's played L.A. Noire, and seen the movie Ghost (with Patrick Swayze of course). This game, to me, felt like a mashup of those two instances of media, and Square-Enix really pulled it off.So, after all that text, do I recommend this game? Yes. Yes I do. And shame on all those who don't.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game. The perspective was new and exciting. There aere a few features that really made the detective aspect of the game itself far more interesting. There are plenty of side quests for you to do, though I myself am not one for them. The side quests have no effect on the progress of the story but do provide interesting information about the town of Salem and the life of Ronan (you). Some of it gets a little repetitive but seeing as the game isn't that long to begin with it doesn't stay that way for long. The ending is great and the characters you encounter are interesting and relatable. Overall it's a nice game and at a nice price if you can get it on sale. Honestly..$30 is a bit much for me but I managed to get my hands on a cheap copy. Good luck to all who play. d~(^.^)~bWARNING!Graphically the game leaves much to be desired and the combat system is really quite simple making the game feel far too easy. I honestly liked making it more interesting on my own by setting some challenges like killing an enemy this way or not using this ability to do so, but really, get it on sale, it's not worth $30...sorry guys.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is probably best described as a story driven puzzle game. You don't shoot anything and the only time you feel like you are in danger is when you have to face demons that you can destroy by walking up behind them and perform a takedown action.The story revolves around a cop, name Ronan, who dies on duty chasing a serial killer and he can't ascend to the next plane of existence until his business on the mortal realm is resolved, so you have to hunt down the serial killer by solving crime scenes to determine what to do next.Overall I enjoyed the game and story, although once you finish you probably won't touch the game again unless you are trying to obtain 100% of the trophies. My recommendation is to buy the game when it is cheap, maybe around the $20 range or less.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Let me just start by saying that I got this game for free with my video card, so I'm sure that affects my review, but it still left me with plenty to say about it.Now usually I'm the kind of person to play fast paced action games where a story doesn't exist as much as a huge pile of bodies does. Somehow, this game still got to me. I was kind of reluctent to play it at first, but once I started to play, I didn't really know what to think. The story is so original, I've never seen anything even close to it. Basically you play as a cop, and the game starts off with your death. The goal is to find your murderer while you play as a ghost, find clues, and avoid demons. Despite it being a detective game, it doesn't really have many boring/slow part, it keeps you hooked pretty much the whole time. I haven't beat the story yet, but it seems to be really well developed and around 8 hours of gameplay from what I've heard. I know that sounds like it wouldn't interest the majority of players, but don't instantly turn your head away from it, it's definitely a good dame, and not the type I like to play either. Watch some videos, do some research, even wait for it to go on sale if you're really not sure if you want it, but seriously consider it.
